{{YEM}} }} a'''l-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula''' ({{lang-ar-at|تنظيم القاعدة في جزيرة العرب|Tanẓīm al-Qā‘idah fī Jazīrat al-‘Arab|lit=[[al-Qaeda]] Organization in the [[Arabian Peninsula]]}} or {{rtl-lang|ar|تنظيم قاعدة الجهاد في جزيرة العرب}}, ''Tanẓīm Qā‘idat al-Jihād fī Jazīrat al-‘Arab'', "Organization of [[Jihad|Jihad's]] Base in the Arabian Peninsula"), or '''AQAP''', also known as '''[[Ansar al-Sharia (Yemen)|Ansar al-Sharia in Yemen]]''' ({{lang-ar|جماعة أنصار الشريعة}}, ''Jamā‘at Anṣār ash-Sharī‘ah'', "Group of the Helpers of the [[Sharia]]"),{{cite web |title=Terrorist Designations of Ansar al-Sharia as an Alias for Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2012/10/198659.htm |publisher=Department of State |accessdate=26 June 2014}} is a [[militant]] [[Islamism|Islamist]] organization, primarily active in [[Yemen]] and [[Saudi Arabia]]. It was named for [[al-Qaeda]], and states it is subordinate to that group and its now-deceased leader [[Osama bin Laden]], a Saudi citizen of Yemeni heritage.{{cite web |title=Al-Qaeda’s Yemen branch eyes a new haven |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/al-qaedas-yemen-branch-eyes-a-new-haven/2013/08/08/d0efa992-0041-11e3-8294-0ee5075b840d_story.html |website=The Washington Post |date=8 August 2013 |accessdate=23 April 2015}} It is considered the most active{{cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/yemen/al-qaeda-arabian-peninsula-aqap/p9369 |title=Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) – Council on Foreign Relations |publisher=Cfr.org |accessdate=2012-06-04}} of al-Qaeda's [[Military branch|branches]], or "[[franchising|franchises]]," that emerged due to weakening central leadership.{{Cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2011/10/06/the-al-qaeda-brand-died-last-week/ |title=The al-Qaeda Brand Died Last Week |work=[[Forbes]] |date=September 6, 2011 |accessdate=September 7, 2011}} The [[Federal government of the United States|U.S government]] believes AQAP to be the most dangerous al-Qaeda branch.{{cite web |title=What is al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula? |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/01/14/middleeast/yemen-al-qaeda-arabian-peninsula/ |publisher=CNN |date=14 January 2015 |accessdate=23 April 2015}} The group established an [[emirate]] during the 2011 [[Yemeni Revolution]]. The group has been designated as a [[terrorist organization]] by the [[United Nations]] and several countries and international organizations. Since 2015, hundreds of AQAP members were recruited by militias backed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in the war against the Houthis.{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/f38788a561d74ca78c77cb43612d50da|title=AP Investigation: US allies, al-Qaida battle rebels in Yemen|publisher=}} ==Ideology and formation== [[File:Yemeni Civil War.svg|thumb|left|225px|Current territorial situation in Yemen. AQAP territory is shown in white, primarily in the [[Al Bayda Governorate|Al Bayda]] and [[Hadhramaut Governorate|Hadhramaut]] provinces.]] Like al-Qaeda Central, AQAP opposes the [[monarchy]] of the [[House of Saud]].{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE6A70TK20101108 |title=FACTBOX-Al Qaeda's Yemen-based wing |agency=Reuters |date=8 November 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2010}} AQAP was formed in January 2009 from a merger of al-Qaeda's Yemeni and Saudi branches.{{cite web |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula-who-are-they |title=Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula: who are they? |publisher=Channel4 News |accessdate=November 12, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104230819/http://www.channel4.com/news/al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula-who-are-they |archivedate=4 November 2010 |deadurl=no}} The Saudi group had been effectively suppressed by the Saudi government, forcing its members to seek sanctuary in Yemen.{{cite news |url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2009/01/arabian_peninsula_al.php |title=Arabian Peninsula al Qaeda groups merge |last=Novak |first=Jane |date=January 26, 2009 |work=[[Long War Journal]] |accessdate=January 27, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100211172638/http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2009/01/arabian_peninsula_al.php |archivedate=11 February 2010 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/yemen-major-staging-base-al-qaeda/story?id=9478552 |title=Yemen: 'Major Staging Base' for Al Qaeda: Q and A With Former CIA Official and Al Qaeda Expert Bruce Riedel |last=Wong |first=Kristina |date=January 5, 2010 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=January 27, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110063942/http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/yemen-major-staging-base-al-qaeda/story?id=9478552 |archivedate=10 January 2010 |deadurl=no}} In 2010, it was believed to have several hundred members. The group also seeks for the destruction of the [[Israel|Israeli state]] and the liberation of the [[Palestinian territories]]. ==Transformation into an active al-Qaeda affiliate== [[File:AQAP fighters in Yemen, 2014.jpg|thumb|left|225px|AQAP fighters in Yemen, 2014.]] The percentage of terrorist [[Wikt:plot#Noun|plots]] in the West that originated from [[Pakistan]] declined considerably from most of them (at the outset), to 75% in 2007, and to 50% in 2010, as al-Qaeda shifted to [[Al-Qaeda involvement in Africa#Somalia and Kenya|Somalia]] and Yemen.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/8009819/Anwar-al-Awlaki-the-new-Osama-bin-Laden.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Philip |last=Johnston |title=Anwar al Awlaki: the new Osama bin Laden? |date=September 17, 2010}} [[U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] formally designated al-Qaeda in Yemen a [[terrorist organization]] on December 14, 2009.{{cite web |last=Gerstein |first=Josh |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/joshgerstein/0110/Clinton_named_AlQaeda_Yemen_as_terror_group_a_month_ago.html |title=Clinton named Al-Qaeda Yemen as terror group a month ago |publisher=Politico.Com |date=January 18, 2010 |accessdate=April 8, 2010}} On August 24, 2010, The Washington Post journalist Greg Miller wrote that the [[CIA]] believed Yemen's branch of al-Qaeda had surpassed its parent organization, [[Osama_bin_Laden#Formation_and_structuring_of_al-Qaeda|Osama bin Laden's core group]], as al-Qaeda's most dangerous threat to the U.S. homeland.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/24/AR2010082406763.html |title=CIA sees increased threat in Yemen |author=Greg Miller |date=August 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 28, 2014}} On August 26, 2010, Yemen claimed that U.S. officials had exaggerated the size and danger of al-Qaeda in Yemen, insisting also that fighting the jihadist network's local branch remained Sanaa's job.{{cite web |author=Al Arabiya News |url=https://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2010/08/26/117672.html |title=Yemen says US officials exaggerate Qaeda threat |date=26 August 2010 |accessdate=10 February 2017}} A former bodyguard of Osama bin Laden warned of an escalation in fighting between al-Qaeda and Yemeni authorities, and predicted the government would need outside intervention to stay in power. However, Ahmed al-Bahri told the [[Associated Press]] that attacks by al-Qaeda in southern Yemen was an indication of its increasing strength.{{cite web |author=FoxNews |accessdate=March 8, 2014 |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=August 26, 2010 |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/08/26/bin-ladens-bodyguard-warns-escalation-yemen-predicts-involvement/ |title=Bin Laden's Bodyguard Warns Escalation in Yemen}} ==Operations and activities carried out as al-Qaeda in Yemen and Saudi Arabia== {{main article|USS Cole bombing}} al-Qaeda was responsible for the [[USS Cole bombing|USS ''Cole'' bombing]] in October 2000 in the southern port of Aden, killing 17 U.S. sailors. In 2002, an al-Qaeda attack damaged a French supertanker in the [[Gulf of Aden]]. The [[Global Terrorism Database]] attributes the [[2004 Khobar massacre]] to the group. {{cite news |url=http://www.start.umd.edu/gtd/search/IncidentSummary.aspx?gtdid=200405290002 |title=Incident Summary 200405290002 |publisher=[[Global Terrorism Database]] |date=May 29, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.start.umd.edu%2Fgtd%2Fsearch%2FIncidentSummary.aspx%3Fgtdid%3D200405290002&date=2010-01-16 |archivedate=January 16, 2010 |accessdate=January 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In this guise, it is also known as "The Jerusalem Squadron." In addition to a number of attacks in Saudi Arabia, and the kidnap and murder of [[Paul Marshall Johnson Jr.]] in [[Riyadh]] in 2004, the group is suspected in connection with a bombing in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]], in March 2005. {{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/home/energy/2005/03/25/cz_0325oxan_qatarattack.html |title=The Advent Of Terrorism In Qatar |work=[[Forbes]] |date=March 25, 2005 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.com%2F2005%2F03%2F25%2Fcz_0325oxan_qatarattack.html&date=2010-01-16 |archivedate=January 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} For a chronology of recent Islamist militant attacks in Saudi Arabia, ''see'' [[terrorism in Saudi Arabia]]. ==Operations and activities carried out as al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula== {{main article|Northwest Airlines Flight 253|Cargo planes bomb plot|2012 Sana'a bombing|2014 hostage rescue operations in Yemen|Charlie Hebdo shooting}} ===2009=== In the [[2009 Little Rock recruiting office shooting]], [[2009 Little Rock recruiting office shooting|Abdulhakim Mujahid Muhammad]], formerly known as Carlos Leon Bledsoe, a Muslim convert who had spent time in Yemen, on June 1, 2009 opened fire with an [[SKS|SKS Rifle]] in a [[drive-by shooting]] on soldiers in front of a United States [[military recruiting office]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], in a ''jihad'' attack. He killed Private William Long, and wounded Private Quinton Ezeagwula. He said that he was affiliated with and had been sent by al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/22/us/22littlerock.html|title=Man Claims Terror Ties in Little Rock Shooting |last=Dao |first=James |date=January 21, 2010 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=January 22, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125152356/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/22/us/22littlerock.html?hp |archivedate=25 January 2010 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/06/01/arkansas.recruiter.shooting/ |author1=Mike Phelan |author2=Mike Mount |author3=Terry Frieden |title=Suspect arrested in Arkansas recruiting center shooting |publisher=CNN |date=June 1, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2010}}{{cite news |last=Dao |first=James |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/17/us/17convert.html |title=A Muslim Son, a Murder Trial and Many Questions |location=Arkansas;Yemen |work=The New York Times |date=February 16, 2010 |accessdate=June 23, 2010}} AQAP said it was responsible for [[Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab]]'s attempted Christmas Day bombing of [[Northwest Airlines Flight 253]] as it approached Detroit on December 25, 2009. {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/6901918/Detroit-terror-attack-al-Qaeda-regional-group-claims-responsibility.html |title=Detroit terror attack: al-Qaeda regional group claims responsibility |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=December 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.telegraph.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworldnews%2Fnorthamerica%2Fusa%2F6901918%2FDetroit-terror-attack-al-Qaeda-regional-group-claims-responsibility.html+&date=2010-01-16 |archivedate=January 16, 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df= }} In that incident, Abdulmutallab reportedly tried to set off [[plastic explosive]]s sewn to his underwear, but failed to detonate them properly. ===2010=== On February 8, 2010, deputy leader [[Said Ali al-Shihri]] called for a regional [[Jihad|holy war]] and [[blockade]] of the [[Red Sea]] to prevent shipments to [[Israel]]. In an audiotape he called upon [[Somalia]]'s [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|al-Shabaab]] militant group for assistance in the blockade.{{Cite news |title=Yemen: Qaeda Affiliate Urges Joint Blockade of Red Seas |newspaper=The New York Times |location=New York |date=February 9, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/09/world/middleeast/09briefs-Yemen.html |accessdate=February 9, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100211055427/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/09/world/middleeast/09briefs-Yemen.html |archivedate=11 February 2010 |deadurl=no}} The 2010 [[cargo planes bomb plot]] was discovered on October 29, 2010, when two packages containing bombs found on [[cargo aircraft]], based on intelligence received from [[Intelligence agency|government intelligence agencies]], in the United Kingdom and the [[United Arab Emirates]]. The packages originated from [[Yemen]], and were addressed to outdated addresses of two Jewish institutions in [[Chicago]], Illinois, one of which was the [[Congregation Or Chadash]], a [[LGBT]] [[synagogue]].[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703414504575584681982002308?mod=googlenews_wsj Chicago Synagogue Cites Web Visits From Egypt], Wall Street Journal 31-10-2010 On October 30, 2010, On November 5, 2010, al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula took responsibility for the plot.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/11/05/yemen.security.concern/?hpt=T2 |title=Yemen-based al Qaeda group claims responsibility for parcel bomb plot |publisher=CNN |date=6 November 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101113054043/http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/11/05/yemen.security.concern/?hpt=T2 |archivedate=13 November 2010 |deadurl=no}} It posted its acceptance of responsibility on a number of [[Islamic extremism|radical Islamist]] websites monitored by the [[SITE Institute|SITE Intelligence Group]] and the [[Nine Eleven Finding Answers Foundation]], and wrote: {{quote|We will continue to strike blows against American interests and the interest of America's allies.}} It also claimed responsibility for the [[UPS Airlines Flight 6|crash]] of a UPS [[Boeing 747-400]] cargo plane in Dubai on September 3. The statement continued: {{quote|...since both operations were successful, we intend to spread the idea to our ''[[mujahideen|mujahedeen]]'' brothers in the world and enlarge the circle of its application to include civilian aircraft in the West as well as cargo aircraft.{{cite web |author=Updated 22 minutes ago 11/8/2010 12:24:00 PM +00:00 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40031838/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa/ |title=Al-Qaida claims responsibility for cargo bombs |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=November 8, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101107072723/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40031838/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa/ |archivedate=7 November 2010 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |last=Entous |first=Adam |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704353504575596831033307148?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Yemeni al Qaeda Claims Package Bomb Attempts |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=5 November 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2010}}{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/11/05/yemeni-al-qaeda-group-claims-responsibility-failed-mail-bomb-plot-cargo-planes/ |title=Yemeni Al Qaeda Group Claims Responsibility for Failed Mail Bomb Plot on U.S. Cargo Planes |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101108131854/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/11/05/yemeni-al-qaeda-group-claims-responsibility-failed-mail-bomb-plot-cargo-planes/ |archivedate=8 November 2010 |deadurl=no}}}} American authorities had said they believed that al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula was behind the plot. Officials in the United Kingdom and the United States believe that it is most likely that the bombs were designed to destroy the planes carrying them.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/01/world/01terror.html |work=The New York Times |first1=Mark |last1=Mazzetti |first2=Robert F. |last2=Worth |first3=Eric |last3=Lipton |title=Bomb Plot Shows Key Role Played by Intelligence |date=31 October 2010}} In November 2010, the group announced a strategy, called "Operation Hemorrhage", which it said was designed to capitalize on the "security phobia that is sweeping America." The program would call for a large number of inexpensive, small-scale attacks against United States interests, with the intent of weakening the U.S. economy.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/11/21/al-qaeda-threat.html?ref=rss |publisher=CBC News |title=Yemen group vows small-scale attacks |date=21 November 2010}} ===2012=== [[File:AQAP guards outside of a building.jpg|thumb|left|200px|AQAP guards standing out of one of their buildings.]] On 21 May 2012, a soldier wearing a belt of explosives carried out [[2012 Sana'a bombing|a suicide attack on military personnel]] preparing for a parade rehearsal for Yemen's [[Unity Day (Yemen)|Unity Day]]. With over 120 people dead and 200 more injured, the attack was the deadliest in Yemeni history.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2012/05/21/yemen-ruthlessly-symbolic-attack |title=In Yemen, a ruthlessly symbolic attack |author=Jane Ferguson |date=21 May 2012 |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=20 May 2012}} AQAP claimed responsibility for the attack.{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/05/201252175919491219.html |title=Al-Qaeda claims deadly Yemen suicide blast |date=21 May 2012 |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=20 May 2012}} During the June 2012 al Qaeda retreat from key southern Yemen stronghold, the organization planted land mines, which killed 73 civilians.{{cite news |title=Yemen says al Qaeda land mins killed 73 this week |newspaper=The Examiner |date=2012-06-27}} According to the governor's office in Abyan province, 3,000 mines were removed from around [[Zinjibar]] and [[Jaʿār|Jaar]]. ===2013=== On 5 December 2013, an [[2013 Sana'a attack|attack on the Yemeni Defense Ministry]] in Sana'a involving a series of bomb and gun attacks killed at least 56 people.{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/12/05/world/meast/yemen-violence/index.html |title=Militants attack hospital at Yemen's Defense Ministry |publisher=CNN |date=December 5, 2013 |accessdate=2013-12-06}} After footage of the attack was aired on Yemeni television, showing an attack on a hospital within the ministry compound and the killing of medical personnel and patients, the head of al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula released a video message apologizing. [[Qasim al-Raymi]] claimed that the team of attackers were directed not to assault the hospital in the attack, but that one had gone ahead and done so.{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/12/22/world/meast/yemen-al-qaeda-apology/ |title=Al Qaeda: We're sorry about Yemen hospital attack |publisher=CNN |date=2013-12-22 |accessdate=2014-01-22}} ===2014=== On 9 May 2014, several soldiers from Yemen were killed after a skirmish sparked when a vehicle attacked a palace gate.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-27352009# |title=Yemen soldiers killed near Sanaa presidential palace |publisher=BBC |date=9 May 2014 |accessdate=9 May 2014}} The group also publishes the online magazines ''[[Voice of Jihad]]'' and ''[[Inspire (magazine)|Inspire]]''.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} In New Zealand it is listed as a terror group.http://www.police.govt.nz/sites/default/files/publications/designated-entities-26-11-2014.pdf In December 2014, the group released a video depicting [[Luke Somers]], a journalist whom they were holding hostage.{{cite news |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/pentagon-confirms-failed-effort-to-rescue-somers/ |title=Pentagon confirms failed effort to rescue Somers |work= The Seattle Times |date=4 December 2014 |accessdate=10 February 2017}} On 26 November, U.S. Navy SEALs and Yemeni special forces attempted a hostage rescue where eight hostages, none American, were freed, but Luke Somers and four others had been moved to another location by AQAP prior to the raid. The nationalities of the eight hostages rescued were six Yemenis, one Saudi, and one Ethiopian. On 6 December, 40 SEALs used V-22 Ospreys to land a distance from the compound where Somers and Korkie were kept at about 1 a.m. local time, according to a senior defense official. An AQAP fighter apparently spotted them while relieving himself outside, a counter-terrorism official with knowledge of the operation told ABC News, beginning a firefight that lasted about 10 minutes. According to CBS News, dog barking could have alerted the hostage takers of the operation. When the American soldiers finally entered the building where Somers and Korkie were kept, they found both men alive, but gravely wounded. Korkie and Somers died some minutes later despite attempts to save them. ===2015=== On 7 January 2015, [[Charlie_Hebdo_shooting#Ch.C3.A9rif_and_Sa.C3.AFd_Kouachi|Saïd Kouachi and Chérif Kouachi]] attacked French satirical newspaper ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'', resulting in 11 French citizens killed and another 11 injured. The French-born brothers of Algerian descent stated they were members of Al-Qaeda in Yemen, to an eyewitness.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/11330636/Terrorists-shouted-they-were-from-Al-Qaeda-in-the-Yemen-before-Charlie-Hebdo-attack.html |title=Terrorists shouted they were from Al Qaeda in the Yemen before Charlie Hebdo attack |date=7 January 2015 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=7 January 2015}} On 9 January, AQAP confirmed responsibility for the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]] in a speech from top Shariah cleric [[Harith bin Ghazi al-Nadhari]]. The reason given was to gain "revenge for the honor" of the Islamic [[Prophet Muhammad]].{{cite news |title=Al-Qaeda Group Claims Responsibility for Paris Terror Attack |url=http://time.com/3661650/charlie-hebdo-paris-terror-attack-al-qaeda/ |date=9 January 2015 |accessdate=11 February 2017}} ====Mukalla==== {{main article|Battle of Mukalla (2015)|Battle of Mukalla (2016)}} On 2 April 2015, AQAP fighters stormed the coastal city of [[Mukalla]], capturing it on the 16th of April after the two-week [[Battle of Mukalla (2015)|Battle of Mukalla]]. They seized government buildings and used trucks to cart off more than $120 million from the central bank, according to the bank’s director. AQAP forces soon passed control to a civilian council, giving it a budget of more than $4 million to provide services to residents of the city. AQAP maintained a police station in the city to mediate [[Sharia]] disputes, but avoided imposing its rule across the city. AQAP refrained from using its name, instead using the name the 'Sons of Hadhramaut' to emphasize its ties to the surrounding province.{{cite news |title=Al Qaeda Tries a New Tactic to Keep Power: Sharing It |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/10/world/middleeast/qaeda-yemen-syria-houthis.html |website=The New York Times |date=9 June 2015 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} Mukalla was recaptured by the Saudi-led coalition on 25 April 2016. ===2017=== Remarks of Algeria atrocities by France acknowledged by [[Emmanuel Macron]] was mentioned in an article in the publication Al-Masra by the terrorist group Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/Terror_Monitor/status/836282545402593284 |title=#YEMEN Pro-#AQAP's #AlMasra Newspaper Slams #WhiteHouse Chief Strategist #SteveBannon. #TerrorMonitor |last=|first=|date=27 February 2017 |website=Twitter |publisher=Terrormonitor.org |accessdate=27 February 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/Dr_E_Kendall/status/836606118403141632 |title= |last=Kendall |first=Elisabeth |date=28 Feb 2017 |website=Twitter |publisher=}} The French colonial rule in Algeria was mentioned.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/JcBrisard/status/836627297692168192 |title= |last=Brisard|first=Jean-Charles |date=28 Feb 2017 |website=Twitter |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/VegetaMoustache/status/836926031789445120 |title= |last= |first= |date=1 Mar 2017 |website=Twitter |publisher=}}{{cite web |url=http://jihadology.net/2017/02/27/new-issue-of-an%e1%b9%a3ar-al-shariah-in-the-arabian-peninsulas-newspaper-al-masra-41/ |title=New issue of Anṣār al-Sharī’ah in the Arabian Peninsula’s newspaper: "al-Masrā #41" |last= |first= |date=February 27, 2017 |website=Jihadology |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}} ===2018=== In August 2018, ''Al Jazeera'' reported that a [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|Saudi Arabian-led coalition]] "battling Houthi rebels secured secret deals with al-Qaeda in Yemen and recruited hundreds of the group's fighters. ... Key figures in the deal-making said the United States was aware of the arrangements and held off on [[drone strike|drone attacks]] against the armed group, which was created by Osama bin Laden in 1988."{{cite news |title=Report: Saudi-UAE coalition 'cut deals' with al-Qaeda in Yemen |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/08/report-saudi-uae-coalition-cut-deals-al-qaeda-yemen-180806074659521.html |work=Al-Jazeera |date=6 August 2018}}{{cite news |title=US allies, Al Qaeda battle rebels in Yemen |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2018/08/07/unite-with-devil-yemen-war-binds-us-allies-al-qaida.html |work=Fox News |date=7 August 2018}}{{cite news |title=Allies cut deals with al Qaeda in Yemen to serve larger fight with Iran |url=https://www.sfgate.com/world/article/Allies-cut-deals-with-al-Qaeda-in-Yemen-to-serve-13135822.php |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=6 August 2018}} ===Fall of Zinjibar and Jaar=== On 2 December 2015, the provincial capital of [[Abyan Governorate]], [[Zinjibar]], and the town of [[Jaʿār]] were [[fall of Zinjibar and Jaar|captured]] by AQAP fighters. Like Al Mukala, AQAP forces soon passed control to a civilian council, police patrols and other public services.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0TL0BQ20151202|title=Al Qaeda militants take over two south Yemen towns, residents say|author=Mohammed Mukhashaf|date=2 December 2015|work=Reuters|accessdate=12 May 2016}} ===Southern Abyan Offensive=== On 20 February 2016, AQAP [[Southern Abyan Offensive (2016)|seized]] the southern Abyan governorate, linking them with their headquarters in Mukalla.{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/qaeda-kills-three-in-sweep-of-yemen-s-south-116022000534_1.html|title=Qaeda kills three in sweep of Yemen's south|author=AFP|date=20 February 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 May 2016}} ==Ansar al-Sharia== [[File:AQAP fighters, Yemen, 2014.jpg|thumb|right|250px|AQAP fighters in Yemen.]] {{main article|Ansar al-Sharia (Yemen)}} In the wake of the 2011 [[Yemeni Revolution]] and the [[Battle of Zinjibar]], an Islamist [[Insurgency|insurgent]] organisation called [[Ansar al-Sharia (Yemen)]] (Supporters of Islamic Law), emerged in Yemen and seized control of areas in the [[Abyan Governorate]] and surrounding governorates in southern Yemen and declared them an Islamist Al-Qaeda Emirate in Yemen. There was [[Al-Qaeda insurgency in Yemen#2011|heavy fighting]] with the Yemeni security forces over the control of these territories, with Ansar al-Sharia driven out of most of their territory over 2012.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/15/us-yemen-violence-idUSBRE85E0AG20120615 |title=Yemeni army claims major advance in campaign against al Qaeda |agency=Reuters |accessdate=1 August 2015}} In April 2011, Shaykh Abu Zubayr Adil bin Abdullah al-Abab, AQAP's chief religious figure, explained the name change as a re-branding exercise: "the name Ansar al-Sharia is what we use to introduce ourselves in areas where we work to tell people about our work and goals."{{cite web |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2012/09/21/know_your_ansar_al_sharia |title=Know Your Ansar Al Sharia |work=Foreign Policy |date=2012-09-21 |accessdate=2014-01-22}} On 4 October 2012, the United Nations 1267/1989 [[Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee]] and the [[United States Department of State]] designated [[Ansar al-Sharia (Yemen)|Ansar al-Sharia]] as an alias for Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. The State Department described the establishment of Ansar al-Sharia as an attempt to attract followers in areas of Yemen where AQAP had been able to establish territorial control and implement its interpretation of [[Sharia]]. ==U.S. drone strikes== {{Main article|Targeted killing}} [[File:MQ-1 Predator unmanned aircraft.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[MQ-1 Predator|Predator]] drone]] In 2010 the White House was reported to be considering using the CIA's armed [[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator|MQ-1 ''Predator'']] drones to fight Al-Qaeda in Yemen.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} A CIA [[targeted killing]] drone strike killed [[Kamal Derwish]], an American citizen, and a group of al-Qaida operatives (including [[Qaed Salim Sinan al-Harethi]]) in Yemen in November 2002. Drones became shorthand in Yemen for a weak government allowing foreign forces to have their way.{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-08/27/c_13464637_2.htm |title=Yemen rejects U.S. role in fighting al-Qaida |agency=Xinhua News Agency |accessdate=October 31, 2010}} On September 30, 2011, a US drone attack in Yemen resulted in the death of [[Anwar al-Awlaki]], one of the group's leaders, and [[Samir Khan]], the editor of ''[[Inspire (magazine)|Inspire]]'', its English-language magazine.{{cite web |url=http://www.aracneeditrice.it/aracneweb/index.php/pubblicazione.html?item=9788854865440 |title= Laura QUADARELLA SANFELICE DI MONTEFORTE, Il terrorismo “fai da te”. Inspire e la propaganda online di AQAP per i giovani musulmani in Occidente, Aracne Editrice, Roma, 2013}} Both were US citizens.{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/09/30/us-born-terror-boss-anwar-al-awlaki-killed/ |publisher=Fox News Channel |title=Two U.S.-Born Terrorists Killed in CIA-Led Drone Strike |date=30 September 2011}} The pace of US drone attacks quickened significantly in 2012, with over 20 strikes in the first five months of the year, compared to 10 strikes during the course of 2011.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-drone-targets-in-yemen-raise-questions/2012/06/02/gJQAP0jz9U_story.html U.S. drone targets in Yemen raise questions] – ''The Washington Post'', June 3, 2012 Over the period 19–21 April 2014, a series of drone attacks on AQAP killed dozens of militants, and at least 3 civilians.{{cite news |last=MUKHASHAF |first=MOHAMED |title=Air strikes in Yemen kill 40 al Qaeda militants in two days |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/04/20/uk-yemen-violence-idUKBREA3I08T20140420 |accessdate=22 April 2014 |agency=Reuters |date=20 April 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/21/us-drone-strike-al-qaida-militants |title=Third suspected US drone strike kills 'several' al-Qaida militants |date=21 April 2014 |accessdate=22 April 2014 |work=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/04/21/uk-yemen-drones-idUKBREA3K0R420140421 |title=Drone strikes alone won't stamp out al Qaeda in Yemen — analysts |date=21 April 2014 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=22 April 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-27100817 |title=Three suspected militants killed in Yemen drone strike |date=21 April 2014 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=22 April 2014}}{{cite news |last=Raddatz |first=Martha |title=After Celebratory Video, Al Qaeda Pounded By Deadly Airstrikes |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/celebratory-video-al-qaeda-pounded-deadly-airstrikes/story?id=23407443 |accessdate=22 April 2014 |newspaper=abc news |date=21 April 2014}} A spokesperson for the Yemeni Supreme Security Committee described the attacks, which included elements of the Yemeni army as well as US drones, as "massive and unprecedented".{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/04/21/world/meast/yemen-drone-strike/ |title=Yemen strikes may target top al Qaeda leaders |date=21 April 2014 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=22 April 2014 |author=Jamjoom, Mohammed |author2=Smith, Matt}} The attacks were alleged to have targeted AQAP leadership, with a major AQAP base in [[Wadi al-Khayala]] reported to have been destroyed.{{cite news |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2014/04/21/new-drone-strike-in-yemen-kills-al-qaida-militants |title=Yemen said strikes on al-Qaida base in southern mountains kill 55 militants |date=21 April 2014 |publisher=U.S. News |accessdate=10 February 2017}} From March 1 through March 8, 2017, the US conducted 45 airstrikes against AQAP, a record amount of airstrikes conducted against the group by the US in recent history. The airstrikes were reported to have killed hundreds of AQAP militants.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/accelerating-yemen-campaign-us-conducts-flurry-of-strikes-targeting-al-qaeda/2017/03/02/8a9af8cc-ff91-11e6-99b4-9e613afeb09f_story.html|title=Accelerating Yemen campaign, U.S. conducts flurry of strikes targeting al-Qaeda|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.criticalthreats.org/analysis/targeting-aqap-u-s-airstrikes-in-yemen|title=Targeting AQAP: U.S. Airstrikes in Yemen|publisher=}} The US continued its airstrikes afterward. Around 1–2 April 2017, the US carried out another 20 airstrikes, increasing the total number of airstrikes against AQAP in 2017 to 75, nearly double previously yearly record of 41 airstrikes in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/04/us-military-hits-aqap-with-more-than-20-airstrikes.php|title=US military hits AQAP with more than 20 airstrikes - FDD's Long War Journal|publisher=}} ==Senior leaders== [[File:Nasir al-Wuhayshi.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Nasir al-Wuhayshi]], former leader and founder of AQAP, was killed by a drone strike in June 2015.]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! ==Members== The group has taken advantage of Yemen's "slow collapse into near-anarchy. Widespread corruption, growing poverty and internal fragmentation have helped make Yemen a breeding ground for terror." {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/yemen/6927845/Britain-and-US-close-embassies-in-Yemen-over-fears-of-imminent-attack-from-al-Qaeda.html |title=Britain and US close embassies in Yemen over fears of imminent attack from al-Qaeda |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=January 3, 2010 |author1=Adrian Blomfield |author2=Duncan Gardham |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.telegraph.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworldnews%2Fmiddleeast%2Fyemen%2F6927845%2FBritain-and-US-close-embassies-in-Yemen-over-fears-of-imminent-attack-from-al-Qaeda.html&date=2010-01-16 |archivedate=January 16, 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df= }} More than two years later, on April 25, 2012, a suspected US drone strike killed Mohammed Said al-Umdah, a senior AQAP member cited as the number four in the organization and one of the 2006 escapees. He had been convicted of the 2002 tanker bombing and for providing logistical and material support.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-04/D9UBFKBG1.htm |title=Yemen army recaptures center of al-Qaida-held city |agency=Associated Press |date=January 16, 2010 |accessdate=April 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703175324/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-04/D9UBFKBG1.htm |archivedate=July 3, 2015 |df= }} Yemeni analyst, Barak Barfi, discounted claims that marriage between the militant group and Yemeni tribes is a widespread practice, though he states that the bulk of AQAP members hail from the tribes.{{Citation |last=Barfi |first=Barak |title=Yemen on the Brink?: The Resurgence of al Qaeda in Yemen |publisher=New America Foundation |year=2010 |url=http://www.newamerica.net/sites/newamerica.net/files/policydocs/Barfi.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001130303/http://www.newamerica.net/sites/newamerica.net/files/policydocs/Barfi.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-10-01 }} AQAP is a popular choice for radicalized Americans seeking to join Islamist terror organizations overseas. In 2013 alone, at least three American citizens or permanent residents — Marcos Alonso Zea, Justin Kaliebe, and Shelton Thomas Bell — have attempted to join AQAP.{{cite web |title=Long Island Arrest Highlights Continuing Lure Of Terror Groups Abroad |url=http://blog.adl.org/extremism/long-island-arrest-highlights-continuing-lure-of-terror-groups-abroad |work=Access ADL |publisher=Anti-Defamation League |accessdate=2013-10-21}} They count among over 50 Americans who have attempted to join terrorist groups overseas, including AQAP, since 2007. Reportedly, as many as 20 Islamist British nationals traveled to Yemen in 2009 to be trained by AQAP. {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/yemen/6924502/Detroit-terror-attack-Britain-sends-counter-terrorist-forces-to-Yemen.html |title=Detroit terror attack: Britain sends counter-terrorist forces to Yemen |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=January 3, 2010 |author1=Sean Rayment |author2=Adrian Blomfield |author3=Richard Spencer |author4=Philip Sherwell |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.telegraph.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworldnews%2Fmiddleeast%2Fyemen%2F6924502%2FDetroit-terror-attack-Britain-sends-counter-terrorist-forces-to-Yemen.html&date=2010-01-16 |archivedate=January 16, 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df= }} In February 2012, up to 500 Internationalistas from Somalia's Al Shabaab, after getting cornered by a Kenyan offensive and conflict with Al Shabaab national legions, fled to Yemen.http://www.longwarjournal.org/ linked to http://www.mareeg.com/fidsan.php?sid=23090&tirsan=3 It is likely that a number of this group merged with AQAP. revision.text:
{{About|Anti-Fascist Action in Sweden|other groups of similar names|Anti-Fascist Action (disambiguation)|Antifa movements more broadly|Antifa movements}}
'''Antifascistisk Aktion'''—abbreviated as '''AFA'''—is a [[far-left politics|far-left]], [[extra-parliamentary opposition|extra-parliamentary]], [[anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] network in [[Sweden]], whose stated goal is to "smash [[fascism]] in all its forms".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antifa.se/index.php?sida=3|title=antifa.se - Antifascistisk Aktion Sverige|website=Antifa.se|accessdate=2017-08-24}}</ref> Some of its members are influenced by the theory of [[triple oppression]], and all of its members claim to oppose [[sexism]], [[racism]], and [[classism]].{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} The point of the organization is to exchange information and to coordinate activities between local groups.
The groups' activities have included handing out flyers, organizing demonstrations, direct action, and property destruction. In line with their ideology, and as a consequence of being constantly monitored by the [[police]], the group has no central authority. This means it has a [[flat organization]] consisting of many independent groupings, without a board or leader. AFA works with other [[Anti-racism|anti-racist]] groups all over Europe.<ref name="lokalgrupper">{{cite web|url=http://www.antifa.se/index.php?sida=8|title=Antifascistisk Aktion – Mot sexism, fascism, kapitalism och homofobi|website=Antifa.se|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antifa.se/index.php?sida=3#platform|title=Antifascistisk Aktion – Mot sexism, fascism, kapitalism och homofobi|website=Antifa.se|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref> The groups' origins are in the heterogeneous anti-fascist groups of the late 1930s and early 1940s, mostly made up of [[social democrat]]s, [[Communism|communists]], and [[Progressive Christianity|progressive Christians]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Pritchard|first=Gareth|title=Niemandsland: A History of Unoccupied Germany, 1944-1945|year=2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=110701350X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NQVk-cYUOYYC&pg=PA7&dq=liberal+Christian+ANTIFA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pivWUOWTBPG10AGfnYDQCQ&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=liberal%20Christian%20ANTIFA&f=false}}</ref> Their ideology is [[libertarian socialism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://antifa.se/presentation/|title=Presentation – Antifascistisk Aktion|work=antifa.se}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Antifa_Her_zu_uns.svg|thumb|"Come to us" Poster of Antifaschistische Aktion (1932)]] The name ''Antifaschistische Aktion'' (Anti-Fascist Action) was used from the early 1930s in Germany.<ref>Loren Balhorn [https://www.jacobinmag.com/2017/05/antifascist-movements-hitler-nazis-kpd-spd-germany-cold-war The Lost History of Antifa]" ''Jacobin'' May 2017</ref> The name was subsequently used by anti-fascist groups in several other countries.
Antifascistisk Aktion (AFA) was founded in Sweden in 1993. AFA is a part of the "autonomous" (autonoma in Swedish, from [[Autonomism|autonomist marxism]]) subculture, which revolves around many forms of leftist activism like antifascism, environmentalism and animal rights activism. This subculture includes people of many different ideologies, but the ideologies of the movement is always some form of radical leftism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://samtalskompassen.samordnarenmotextremism.se/valdsbejakande-extremism/valdsbejakande-vansterextremism/ideologi/|title=Samtalskompassen - Våldsbejakande vänsterextremism: Ideologi|website=Samtalskompassen.samordnarenmotextremism.se|accessdate=2017-08-24}}</ref> In staunch contrast to the American Antifa,<ref>http://edition.cnn.com/videos/us/2017/08/17/antifa-unmasking-anti-facists-orig-nws.cnn</ref> is Swedish AFA not open for more moderate forms of leftism, and there is even occasions where relative moderates have been assaulted by them.<ref>https://www.hd.se/2017-05-02/tre-garningsman-filmade-och-spottade-mot-vansterpartiets-1-maj-tag</ref>
==Approach== Their ''Activity Guide'' advocates direct action against [[neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antifa.se/files/aktivitetsguide.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=11 February 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=24 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211032651/http://www.antifa.se/files/aktivitetsguide.pdf|archivedate=11 February 2007|df=}}</ref> AFA members have admitted to arson by timed firebombs,<ref>{{cite web|title=Afa riktar ilska mot Migrationsverket|url=http://www.svt.se/nyheter/afa-riktar-ilska-mot-migrationsverket|accessdate=3 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151203193738/http://www.svt.se/nyheter/afa-riktar-ilska-mot-migrationsverket|archivedate=3 December 2015|language=Swedish|date=1 January 2006}}</ref> and have pleaded guilty to burning the [[Tråvad]] spinnery in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|title=Afa tar på sig mordbrand på nazistgård|url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/afa-tar-pa-sig-mordbrand-pa-nazistgard/|publisher=Dagens Nyheter|accessdate=26 November 2015 | language=Swedish | date=2005-12-28 }}</ref> In January 2006, Swedish AFA members attacked the Norrköping immigration office and threatened officials.<ref>{{sv icon}} [http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=53277&a=516807&lid=senasteNytt_611539&lpos=rubrik_516807 Afa riktar ilska mot Migrationsverket] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612062117/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=53277&a=516807&lid=senasteNytt_611539&lpos=rubrik_516807 |date=12 June 2011 }} SVT 10 januari 2006.</ref> In June 2006, AFA members broke windows of an estate of the [[Christian Democrats (Sweden)|Christian Democrats]] in Kalmar.<ref>{{sv icon}} [http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article5784027.ab Slåss med knogjärn] Aftonbladet 13.9.2009.</ref> In October 2006, AFA members threatened to block a municipal council meeting in Gothenburg, because the [[Sweden Democrats]] had been elected to the council.<ref>{{sv icon}} [http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=147&a=585621&previousRenderType=6 Aktivister försökte stoppa möte med Sverigedemokrat] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611115008/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=147&a=585621&previousRenderType=6 |date=11 June 2011 }} DN 2 november 2006.</ref>
In July 2007, AFA members threatened and attacked an immigration judge in Gothenburg.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.se/8043|title=Migration judge threatened by extremists|date=30 July 2007|website=Thelocal.se|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref> The judge's front door was hit with an axe, and the house was vandalized with red spraypaint. Personal information about the judge and other judges was posted on the Internet.<ref>{{sv icon}} [https://archive.is/20120524155311/http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/domare-som-utvisat-irakier-attackerades-1.770951 Domare som utvisat irakier attackerades] ''Dagens Nyheter'' 31 July 2007</ref> On 7 March 2008, Säpo, the Swedish security police agency, reported that AFA or people using its symbols constantly threaten municipal and provincial elected council members.<ref>[http://www.sapo.se/publicerat/nyhetsarkiv/nyheter2007/hotmotfortroendevaldanyrapport.5.59a6ce1f116807f34088000356.html] {{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In August 2008, AFA members spread announcements in [[Uppsala]] with the name and image of an opponent, encouraging people to attack him. For this, AFA promised to pay 500 Swedish kronor and a free "knogjärn" ([[knuckle duster]]).<ref>{{sv icon}} {{cite web|url=http://www.svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d%3D22620%26a%3D1221280%26lid%3Dpuff_1221455%26lpos%3Drubrik |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612102920/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=22620&a=1221280&lid=puff_1221455&lpos=rubrik |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df=dmy }} Ruotsin TV</ref> In February 2009, AFA members attacked the [[National Democrats (Sweden)|National Democrats]] politician [[Vávra Suk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stockholm.expressen.se/nyheter/1.1461755/afa-tar-pa-sig-vald-mot-nd-politiker|title=Afa tar på sig våld mot ND-politiker|website=Stockholm.expressen.se|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref>
===Criticism=== An editorial in the [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] newspaper ''[[Expressen]]'' argued that the label 'anti-fascist' was misleading, because the organization's methods, such as stealing the subscriber list of the [[National Democrats (Sweden)|National Democrats]] newspaper, and threatening the subscribers are counterproductive and similar to methods used by fascists.<ref name="StoppaAFA">{{cite web|url=http://www.expressen.se/ledare/1.1466908/090215-stoppa-afa|title=090215: Stoppa AFA|website=Expressen.se|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Post-WWII Anti-fascism]] *[[Anti-Fascist Action]] *[[Anti-Fascist Action (disambiguation)]] *[[Unite Against Fascism]]

Orient<ref name= 990-2014/> | leader_title2 = [[Executive Director]] | website = {{URL|http://www.aapsonline.org/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Association of American Physicians and Surgeons''' ('''AAPS''') is a [[conservatism in the United States|politically conservative]] non-profit association founded in 1943 to "fight socialized medicine and to fight the government takeover of medicine."<ref name="nyt-2011"/><ref name="Portent">{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,933370,00.html | title=Portent | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=1944-05-08| accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref> The group was reported to have about 4,000 members in 2005, and 5,000 in 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/20/us-usa-health-insurance-idUSKBN0GK17P20140820 | title='I don't take insurance' not always a doctor deal breaker | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date=2005-08-07 | accessdate=2014-08-20 | first=Beth | last=Pinsker}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://time.com/money/3148496/doctor-health-insurance-does-not-accept/| title=What It Really Means When Your Doctor Says He Doesn’t Take Insurance| publisher=[[Time (magazine)|TIME magazine]] | date=2005-08-07 | accessdate=2007-02-14 | first=Beth | last=Pinsker}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1090918,00.html | title=Doctors Who Hurt Doctors | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|TIME magazine]] | date=2005-08-07 | accessdate=2007-02-14 | first=Jeff | last=Chu| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070216123133/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C1090918%2C00.html| archivedate= February 16, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[executive director]] is Jane Orient, an internist and a member of the [[Oregon Institute of Science and Medicine]].<ref name= 990-2014/> AAPS also publishes the ''[[#Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons|Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons]]'' (formerly known as the ''Medical Sentinel'').
The association is generally recognized as politically [[conservatism in the United States|conservative]] or [[far-right|ultra-conservative]], and its publication advocates a range of scientifically discredited hypotheses, including [[AIDS denialism|the belief that HIV does not cause AIDS]], that being gay reduces life expectancy, that there is a [[abortion-breast cancer hypothesis|link between abortion and breast cancer]], and that there is a [[Causes of autism#Vaccines|causal relationship between vaccines and autism]].
==History== During the winter of 1943, the [[Lake County, Indiana|Lake County (Indiana)]] Medical Committee opposed the [[Wagner-Murray-Dingell Bill]], proposed legislation that would provide government health care for most U.S. citizens. Also opposed to the bill was the conservative National Physicians Committee. The committee began a membership drive in February 1944. By May 1944, the AAPS claimed members from all 48 states.<ref name="Portent"/> In 1944, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' reported that the group's aim was the "defeat of any Government group medicine."<ref name="Portent"/> In 1966, ''[[The New York Times]]'' described AAPS as an "ultra-right-wing... political-economic rather than a medical group," and noted that some of its leaders were members of the [[John Birch Society]].<ref name="Rouse">{{cite news | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0714F73F55117B93C2AA178DD85F428685F9 | title = New Power in A.M.A.; Milford Owen Rouse | date = June 30, 1966 |work=The New York Times | accessdate = March 16, 2007}}</ref>
In 2002, AAPS said that its members included [[Ron Paul]] and [[John Cooksey]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aapsonline.org/newsletters/oct02.htm | title=Volume 58, No. 10 October 2002 | author=AAPS |date=October 2002 | accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref> Ron Paul's son, [[Rand Paul]], was a member for over two decades until his election to the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]].<ref name=NYT.antivax>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/05/us/politics/rand-paul-linked-to-association-of-american-physicians-and-surgeons.html|title=Rand Paul Is Linked to Doctors’ Group That Supports Vaccination Challenges|author1=Jeremy Peters|author2=Barry Meier|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2015-02-05}}</ref>
==Positions== While AAPS describes itself as "non-partisan",<ref>{{cite web|title=Membership Information|url=http://www.aapsonline.org/|publisher=AAPS|accessdate=2008-08-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080828001646/http://www.aapsonline.org./| archivedate= August 28, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> the organization is generally recognized as politically conservative or ultra-conservative.<ref name="Rouse"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Hall|first=Mimi|title=Many states reject bioterrorism law|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/healthscience/2002-07-22-states-healthlaw_x.htm|work=USA Today|date=2002-07-22|accessdate=2008-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,837038,00.html | title=Progress Report | date=1967-06-30 |work=Time Magazine}} "...an ultra-conservative political-action group"</ref> The AAPS opposed the [[Social Security Act of 1965]] which established [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and [[Medicaid]], arguing that "the effect of the law is evil and participation in carrying out its provisions is, in our opinion, immoral",<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.aapsonline.org/brochures/princip.htm | title = Principles of the AAPS |publisher = Association of American Physicians and Surgeons| accessdate= March 10, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070310233943/http://www.aapsonline.org/brochures/princip.htm| archivedate= March 10, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and encouraged member physicians to boycott Medicare and Medicaid.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0A11FE3A54177A93C7A91783D85F418685F9 | title = Medicare Boycott Urged for Doctors | date = August 5, 1965 |work=The New York Times | accessdate = March 16, 2007}}</ref> AAPS argues that individuals should purchase medical care directly from doctors, and that there is no right to medical care.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.aapsonline.org/resolutions/2001-1.htm |title = RESOLUTION 2001-1: Medical Care Is NOT a Right | publisher = Association of American Physicians and Surgeons | accessdate = March 10, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070405103847/http://aapsonline.org/resolutions/2001-1.htm| archivedate= April 5, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The organization requires its members to sign a "declaration of independence" pledging that they will not work with Medicare, Medicaid, or even private insurance companies.<ref name="MJ">{{cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2009/11/tea-party-doctors-american-association-physicians-surgeons#comment-243833|title=The Tea Party's Favorite Doctors|last=Mencimer|first=Stephanie|date=November 18, 2009|publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|accessdate=November 19, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091121020124/https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2009/11/tea-party-doctors-american-association-physicians-surgeons| archivedate= November 21, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
AAPS opposes mandated [[evidence-based medicine]] and practice guidelines, criticizing them as a usurpation of physician [[autonomy]] and a fascist merger of state and corporate power driven by the [[pharmaceutical industry]].<ref>[http://www.aapsonline.org/newsletters/jan06.php The Standard of Care], from the AAPS website. Retrieved March 10, 2007.</ref> AAPS also [[Anti-abortion movements|opposes abortion]]<ref>[http://www.aapsonline.org/resolutions/2003-2.htm Resolution passed by the Assembly – Affirming the Sanctity of Human Life], from the AAPS website. Retrieved March 12, 2007.</ref> and [[Over-the-counter drug|over-the-counter]] access to [[emergency contraception]].<ref>[http://www.aapsonline.org/testimony/fda-ab.php Comments re: Docket No. 2005N-0345, RIN 0910-AF72], from the AAPS website. Retrieved March 12, 2007.</ref> AAPS also opposes electronic medical records<ref name=MJ/> as well as any "direct or de facto supervision or control over the practice of medicine by federal officers or employees."<ref> {{ cite web | url = http://www.aapsonline.org/resolutions/2001-2.htm | title = Model Resolutions | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | publisher = aapsonline.org }}</ref>
On October 25, 2008 the AAPS website published an editorial implying that Barack Obama was using [[Neuro-linguistic Programming]], "a covert form of hypnosis", to coerce people to vote for him in his 2008 presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.aapsonline.org/newsoftheday/0089 | title = Oratory—or hypnotic induction? | date = 2008-10-25 | publisher = aapsonline.org | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091023154655/http://www.aapsonline.org/newsoftheday/0089| archivedate= October 23, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Mnookin|first1=Seth|title=The Panic Virus: A True Story of Medicine, Science, and Fear|date=2012|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-1439158654|page=210|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mxqVQQMZzFcC&pg=PA210&lpg=PA210&dq=%22Association+of+American+Physicians+and+Surgeons%22+obama+neuro-linguistic+programming&source=bl&ots=SfBXfb1lwv&sig=furE1mt3o1WOgUEQlnItOqrE67s&hl=en&sa=X&ei=M3POU7nhIeSq0QXkjYDwBQ&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22Association%20of%20American%20Physicians%20and%20Surgeons%22%20obama%20neuro-linguistic%20programming&f=false}}</ref>
==Political and legal activism==
===Gun control=== AAPS's position is that there is no evidence, from a medical stand point, to support [[gun control]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/04/az-aapsguncontrol-idUSnPNDC73885+1e0+PRN20130904 |title=Research Fails to Support Gun Control Agenda, According to Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons |date=September 2013 |accessdate=2010-10-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021015153/https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/04/az-aapsguncontrol-idUSnPNDC73885%2B1e0%2BPRN20130904 |archivedate=October 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
===Social Security===
In 1975, AAPS went to court to block enforcement of a new [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] amendment that would monitor the treatment given to [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and [[Medicaid]] patients.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913792,00.html | title=Review for Doctors | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|TIME magazine]] | date=1975-12-01 | accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref>
===Opposition to health-care reform===
With several other groups, AAPS filed a lawsuit in 1993 against [[Hillary Clinton]] and Secretary of Health and Human Services [[Donna Shalala]] over closed-door meetings related to the [[1993 Clinton health care plan]]. The AAPS sued to gain access to the list of members of [[Bill Clinton|President Clinton's]] health care taskforce. Judge [[Royce C. Lamberth]] initially found in favor of the plaintiffs and awarded $285,864 to the AAPS for legal costs; Lamberth also harshly criticized the Clinton administration and Clinton aide [[Ira Magaziner]] in his ruling.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/us/judge-rules-government-covered-up-lies-on-panel.html | title = Judge Rules Government Covered Up Lies on Panel | first = Robert | last = Pear | work=The New York Times | date = December 19, 1997 | accessdate = January 3, 2008}}</ref> Subsequently, a federal appeals court overturned the award and the initial findings on the basis that Magaziner and the administration had not acted in bad faith.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/25/us/court-clears-clinton-aide-in-lying-case.html | title = Court Clears Clinton Aide In Lying Case | first = Neil | last = Lewis | work=The New York Times | date = August 25, 1999 | accessdate = January 3, 2008}}</ref> AAPS also opposed the Obama Administration's [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], and on March 26, 2010 AAPS filed suit to invalidate the new health care bill.<ref>http://www.aapsonline.org/hhslawsuit/aaps-v-sebelius-03-26-2010.php</ref>
The AAPS was involved in litigation against [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act]] (HIPAA), arguing that it violates the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] by allowing government access to certain medical data without a warrant.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Physicians+sue+to+overturn+HIPAA+privacy+rule.+%28Texas+OB.GYN.+A...-a094158723 |title=Physicians Sue to Block HIPAA Privacy Rule. (Texas OB.GYN. A Coplaintiff) |last1=Peters |first1=Sally |date=November 1, 2001 |newspaper=OB GYN News}}</ref> (Title II of HIPAA, known as the Administrative Simplification (AS) provisions, requires the establishment of national standards for electronic health care transactions and national identifiers for providers, health insurance plans, and employers, and is intended to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the US's health care system by encouraging the widespread use of electronic data interchange in the health care system.)
=== Opposition to investigation of Rush Limbaugh's drug charges ===
In 2004, AAPS filed a brief on behalf of conservative talk show host [[Rush Limbaugh]] in Florida's Fourth District Court of Appeal, opposing the seizure of his medical files in an investigation of [[Rush Limbaugh#Prescription drug addiction|drug charges]] for Limbaugh's alleged misuse of prescription drugs. The AAPS stated the seizure was a violation of state law and that "It is not a crime for a patient to be in pain and repeatedly seek relief, and doctors should not be turned against patients they tried to help."<ref name="Erik M. Conway 2010, p.245">{{cite book |first=Erik M. |last=Conway |first2=Naomi |last2=Oreskes |authorlink=Erik M. Conway |author2link=Naomi Oreskes |title=[[Merchants of Doubt]]: How a Handful of Scientists Obscured the Truth on Issues from Tobacco Smoke to Global Warming |year=2010 |page=245 |quote=[https://books.google.com/books?id=CrtoNFTuPwwC&pg=PA245 The journal, previously known as the ''Medical Sentinel'', is the outlet of the Association of American Physicians and Surgeons, which among other things filed a suit on behalf of Rush Limbaugh when his medical records were seized as a part of his prosecution on drug charges ... (Neither the Web of Science nor MEDLINE/PubMed lists the journal among its peer-reviewed scientific sources.)]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.newsmax.com/archives/articles/2004/2/21/141518.shtml | title=Doctors Group: Limbaugh Medical Records Seizure Unlawful | publisher=[[NewsMax Media|NewsMax.com]] | date=2004-02-22 | accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref>
===Other cases=== In 2006 the group criticized what it called [[sham peer review]], claiming it was a device used to punish [[whistleblowers]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aapsonline.org/peerreview/epidemic.php | title=Sham Peer Review: A National Epidemic | author=Lawrence R. Huntoon | date=2006-05-09 | accessdate=2007-02-14 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070405103915/http://aapsonline.org/peerreview/epidemic.php | archive-date=April 5, 2007 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref> The next year, AAPS helped appeal the conviction of Virginia internist [[William Hurwitz]], who was sentenced to 25 years in federal prison for prescribing excessive quantities of [[narcotic|narcotic drugs]] after 16 former patients testified against him.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1083911-2,00.html | title=Why Is The DEA Hounding This Doctor? | date=2005-07-18 | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|TIME magazine]] | accessdate=2007-02-14 | first=Margot | last=Roosevelt}}</ref> Hurwitz was granted a retrial in 2006, and his 25-year prison sentence was reduced to 4 years and 9 months.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/13/AR2007071301035.html Washington Post story], July 14, 2007.</ref>
==''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons''== The ''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'' (''JPandS''), until 2003 named the ''Medical Sentinel'',<ref name="AAPS website">{{cite web | url=http://www.aapsonline.org/alerts/journalalert.htm | title=Major Changes to AAPS Peer-Reviewed Journal | publisher=AAPS website | accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://haciendapublishing.com/medicalsentinel | title=Medical Sentinel | accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref> is the journal of the association. Its mission statement includes "… a commitment to publishing scholarly articles in defense of the practice of private medicine, the pursuit of integrity in medical research … Political correctness, dogmatism and orthodoxy will be challenged with logical reasoning, valid data and the scientific method." The publication policy of the journal states that articles are subject to a double-blind [[peer-review]] process.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jpands.org/vol10no1/authors.pdf | title=Manuscript information for authors | publisher=JPandS website | accessdate=2007-02-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070221153136/http://www.jpands.org/vol10no1/authors.pdf| archivedate= February 21, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The ''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'' is not listed in academic literature databases such as [[MEDLINE]]/[[PubMed]] or the [[Web of Science]]. The quality and scientific validity of articles published in the ''Journal'' have been criticized by medical experts, and some of the political and scientific viewpoints advocated by AAPS are not held by mainstream scientists and other medical groups.<ref name="nyt-2011">{{cite news |work=The New York Times | first = Barry | last = Meier | date = January 18, 2011 | accessdate = January 24, 2011 | title = Vocal Physicians Group Renews Health Law Fight | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/19/business/19physicians.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111015082017/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/19/business/19physicians.html| archivedate=October 15, 2011<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The U.S. [[National Library of Medicine]] declined repeated requests from AAPS to index the journal, citing unspecified concerns.<ref name="nyt-2011"/> As of September 2016, ''JPandS'' was listed on [[Beall's list]] of potential or probable predatory [[open-access journal]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/09/rogue-doctors-spreading-right-wing-rumors-hillarys-health/|title=The Rogue Doctors Spreading Right-Wing Conspiracy Theories about Clinton’s Health|date=2016-09-23|last=Lapowsky|first=Issie|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-11-01|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Quackwatch]] lists ''JPandS'' as an untrustworthy, non-recommended periodical.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.quackwatch.org/04ConsumerEducation/nonrecperiodicals.html | author=[[Stephen Barrett|Barrett, S.]] | title=Nonrecommended Periodicals | accessdate=2007-02-12 | publisher=[[Quackwatch]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070328231353/http://www.quackwatch.org/04ConsumerEducation/nonrecperiodicals.html| archivedate= March 28, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> An editorial in ''[[Chemical & Engineering News]]'' described ''JPandS'' as a "purveyor of utter nonsense."<ref>{{cite journal |last= Baum|first= Rudy|date=June 2008|title= Defending Science|journal=[[Chemical & Engineering News]]|volume= 86|issue=23 |pages= 5|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/86/i23/Defending-Science.html |doi= 10.1021/cen-v086n023.p005}}</ref> [[Investigative journalist]] [[Brian Deer]] wrote that the journal is the "house magazine of a right-wing American fringe group [AAPS]" and "is barely credible as an independent forum."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://briandeer.com/wakefield/private-eye.htm | title=Bitter Heather Mills defends credibility as Wakefield anti-MMR campaign crumbles | publisher=BrianDeer.com | accessdate=2007-02-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070204045558/http://briandeer.com/wakefield/private-eye.htm| archivedate= February 4, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', science columnist [[Ben Goldacre]] described the ''Journal'' as the "in-house magazine of a rightwing US pressure group well known for polemics on homosexuality, abortion and vaccines."<ref name="goldacre">{{cite web | work = [[The Guardian]] | first = Ben | last = Goldacre | authorlink = Ben Goldacre | url = https://www.theguardian.com/society/2005/nov/02/health.science | title = The MMR sceptic who just doesn't understand science | date = November 1, 2005}}</ref>
=== Advocacy of non-mainstream or scientifically discredited claims===
Articles and commentaries published in the journal have argued a number of non-mainstream or scientifically discredited claims,<ref name="nyt-2011"/> including:
* that [[anthropogenic climate change|human activity]] has not contributed to [[climate change]], and that global warming will be beneficial and thus not a cause for concern;<ref>[http://www.jpands.org/vol12no3/robinson.pdf Environmental Effects of Increased Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide] by Arthur B. Robinson, Noah E. Robinson, and Willie Soon. Published in ''The Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'', 2007; 12(3), 79.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.jpands.org/vol18no3/lindzen.pdf | title=Science in the Public Square: Global Climate Alarmism and Historical Precedents | author=Lindzen, Richard S. | journal=Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons | year=2013 | volume=18 | issue=3 | pages=70–73}}</ref> * that [[AIDS denialism|HIV does not cause AIDS]];<ref name="baueraids">[http://www.jpands.org/vol12no4/bauer.pdf Questioning HIV/AIDS: Morally Reprehensible or Scientifically Warranted?], by [[Henry Bauer]]. Published in the ''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'' 2007: Vol 12, No. 4, p. 116.</ref> * that the "gay male lifestyle" shortens life expectancy by 20 years.<ref>[http://www.jpands.org/vol10no3/lehrman.pdf Homosexuality: Some Neglected Considerations], by Nathaniel S. Lehrman, MD. Published in ''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'', Volume 10, Number 3 (Fall 2005), pp. 80–82.</ref> * that there is a link between [[abortion]] and the risk of [[breast cancer]].<ref name=NYT.antivax/> * that there are possible links between [[autism]] and [[vaccination]]s.<ref name=NYT.antivax/> * that government efforts to encourage [[smoking cessation]] and emphasize the addictiveness of [[nicotine]] are misguided.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/gerth/2015/02/04/rand-paul-in-association-of-american-physicians-and-surgeons/22857153/|title=From the archives: Paul in group with offbeat views|date=2010-09-25|author=Gerth, Joe|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2017-11-01|language=en}}</ref>
A series of articles by [[pro-life]] authors published in the journal argued for a [[Abortion – breast cancer hypothesis|link between abortion and breast cancer]].<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.jpands.org/vol8no2/malec.pdf | format = PDF | title = The Abortion-Breast Cancer Link: How Politics Trumped Science and Informed Consent | first = Karen | last = Malec | work = Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons | volume= 8 | issue = 2 | year = 2003 | pages = 41–45}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.jpands.org/vol10no4/brind.pdf | title = Induced Abortion as an Independent Risk Factor for Breast Cancer: A Critical Review of Recent Studies Based on Prospective Data | format = PDF | first = Joel | last = Brind | work = Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons | volume = 10 | issue = 4 | year = 2005 | pages = 105–110}}</ref> Such a link has been rejected by the scientific community, including the U.S. [[National Cancer Institute]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/abortion-miscarriage | title = Abortion, Miscarriage, and Breast Cancer Risk | publisher = [[National Cancer Institute]] | accessdate = March 11, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070309190555/http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/abortion-miscarriage| archivedate= March 9, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> the [[American Cancer Society]],<ref name="ACS">{{cite web | url = http://www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/content/CRI_2_6x_Can_Having_an_Abortion_Cause_or_Contribute_to_Breast_Cancer.asp | title = Can Having an Abortion Cause or Contribute to Breast Cancer? | publisher = [[American Cancer Society]] | accessdate = March 31, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080325055310/http://www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/content/CRI_2_6x_Can_Having_an_Abortion_Cause_or_Contribute_to_Breast_Cancer.asp |archivedate = March 25, 2008}}</ref> and the [[World Health Organization]],<ref name="WHO">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs240/en/index.html |title=WHO – Induced abortion does not increase breast cancer risk |accessdate=2011-01-11 |work=who.int |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113001029/http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs240/en/index.html |archivedate=January 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> among other major medical bodies.<ref name="JASEN">{{cite journal |author=Jasen P |title=Breast cancer and the politics of abortion in the United States |journal=Med Hist |volume=49 |issue=4 |pages=423–44 |year=2005 |pmid=16562329 |pmc=1251638 |doi=10.1017/S0025727300009145}}</ref>
A 2003 paper published in the journal, claiming that vaccination was harmful, was criticized for poor methodology, lack of scientific rigor, and outright errors by the [[World Health Organization]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/topics/thiomersal/statement/en/index.html | title=Position of the Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety regarding concerns raised by paper about the safety of thiomersal-containing vaccines | publisher=[[World Health Organization|WHO]] | accessdate=2007-02-14}}</ref> and the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]].<ref name="aap-crit">{{cite web| publisher = [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] | url = http://www.aap.org/profed/thimaut-may03.htm | title=Study Fails to Show a Connection Between Thimerosal and Autism | date= 2003-05-16 | accessdate = 2008-10-27 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080420063827/http://www.aap.org/profed/thimaut-may03.htm |archivedate = April 20, 2008}}</ref> A [[National Public Radio]] piece mentioned inaccurate information published in the ''Journal'' and said: "The journal itself is not considered a leading publication, as it's put out by an advocacy group that opposes most government involvement in medical care."<ref name="npr-leprosy"/>
The ''Journal'' has also published articles advocating politically and socially conservative policy positions, including: * that the [[Food and Drug Administration]] and [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] are [[constitutionality|unconstitutional]];<ref>[http://www.haciendapub.com/albright2.html The FDA and HCFA (Part II): Unconstitutional Regulatory Agencies] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070415041218/http://www.haciendapub.com/albright2.html |date=April 15, 2007 }}, by James A. Albright, MD. Published in ''Medical Sentinel'', 2000;5(6) 205–208.</ref> * that "[[Humanism|humanists]]" have conspired to replace the "creation religion of Jehovah" with [[evolution]];<ref>[http://www.jpands.org/hacienda/caine6.html Conspiracy --- Part III], by Curtis W. Caine, MD. Published in ''Medical Sentinel'', 1999;4(6) 224.</ref> * that "[[anchor baby|anchor babies]]" are valuable to undocumented immigrants, particularly if the babies are disabled.<ref name="nyt-2011"/>
=== Leprosy error === In a 2005 article published in the ''Journal'', [[Madeleine Cosman]] argued that [[illegal immigration|illegal immigrants]] were carriers of disease, and that immigrants and [[anchor baby|"anchor babies"]] were launching a "stealthy assault on [American] medicine."<ref name="cosman">[http://www.jpands.org/vol10no1/cosman.pdf Illegal Aliens and American Medicine], by [[Madeleine Cosman]]. Published in the ''Journal of American Physicians and Surgeons'', Spring 2005 (Vol. 10, No. 1, pp. 6–10).</ref> In the article, Cosman claimed that "Suddenly, in the past 3 years America has more than 7,000 cases of leprosy" because of illegal aliens.<ref name="cosman"/> The journal's [[leprosy]] claim was cited and repeated by [[Lou Dobbs]] as evidence of the dangers of illegal immigration.<ref name="npr-leprosy">[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=10141647 Broken Borders? CBS Lambastes, Hires Dobbs], by David Folkenflik. From ''[[All Things Considered]]'', [[National Public Radio]], May 11, 2007. Retrieved August 29, 2008.</ref><ref name="nyt-leprosy">[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/30/business/30leonhardt.html Truth, Fiction, and Lou Dobbs], by [[David Leonhardt]]. Published in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on May 30, 2007; accessed August 29, 2008.</ref>
Publicly available statistics show that the 7,000 cases of leprosy occurred during the past 30 years, not the past three as Cosman claimed.<ref>[http://www.hrsa.gov/hansensdisease/casesusreported.html New U.S. Reported Hansen's Disease (Leprosy) Cases by Year, 1979–2009], from the U.S. National Hansen's Disease (Leprosy) Program. Retrieved June 16, 2014</ref> James L. Krahenbuhl, director of the U.S. government's leprosy program, stated that there had been no significant increase in leprosy cases, and that "It [leprosy] is not a public health problem—that’s the bottom line."<ref name="nyt-leprosy"/> National Public Radio reported that the ''Journal'' article "had footnotes that did not readily support allegations linking a recent rise in leprosy rates to illegal immigrants."<ref name="npr-leprosy"/> The article's erroneous leprosy claim was pointed out by ''[[60 Minutes]]'',<ref name="60minutes-leprosy">[http://www.cbsnews.com/sections/i_video/main500251.shtml?id=2765343n Lou Dobbs' Opinion], from ''[[60 Minutes]]''. Originally broadcast on May 17, 2007; accessed August 29, 2008.</ref> National Public Radio,<ref name="npr-leprosy"/> and ''[[The New York Times]]''<ref name="nyt-leprosy"/> but has not been corrected by the ''Journal''.<ref name="cosman" />
