This is assumed to have been done by her two uncles and a member of the Saudi Embassy. "They weren't Filipino. They looked Arab," Another woman, who declined to give her name told The Australian. A third witness claimed to have seen "A security officer and three middle eastern men doing this". She was later forced on a [[Saudia|Saudi Arabian Airlines]] flight, the pilots and crew of which were reportedly aware and supportive of Dina being returned to Riyadh against her will, siding heavily with her uncles.{{Cite news|url=https://www.niyitabiti.net/2017/04/woman-fleeing-saudi-arabia-detained-at-airport-and-forced-to-return-photos/|title=Woman Fleeing Saudi Arabia ‘Detained At Airport And Forced To Return’….Photos|date=2017-04-13|work=Gistmaster|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/04/13/fleeing-woman-returned-saudi-arabia-against-her-will|title=Fleeing Woman Returned to Saudi Arabia Against Her Will|date=2017-04-13|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-women-rights-idUSKBN17E1WP|title=Saudi woman seeking asylum in Australia returned to Saudi Arabia|date=2017-04-12|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-04-14}} Despite conflicting reports at the time about whether or not Dina was in fact on the flight, while en route to Riyadh social media users began reporting a hostage aboard, prompting the governments of [[Oman]] and [[Qatar]] to refuse the aircraft passage through their airspace. While only confirmed to confidential sources and not officially verified, it is supported by flight path records, which show an abrupt change in direction and trajectory, seeing the plane make almost a full turn.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/AlyaaGad/status/851876810702938114|title=AlyaaGad AfhamTVأفهم on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2017-04-19|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://beta.flightstats.com/flight-tracker/SV/871/2017/4/11/874666785?utm_source|title=(SV) Saudia #871 Flight Tracker|website=FlightStats|language=en-us|access-date=2017-04-17}}https://web.archive.org/web/20170422113623/https://twitter.com/AlyaaGad/status/851876810702938114 == Arrival at Riyadh == {{see also|Wali (Islamic legal guardian)|2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests}} Police presence was heavy outside [[King Abdulaziz International Airport]] the night Dina arrived, Saudi campaigners reported Dina was seen arriving in the country in a wheelchair, while multiple passengers told [[Reuters]] they had seen a woman being carried onto the plane screaming.{{Cite news|url=https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/Saudi_woman_seeking_asylum_in_Australia_returned_to_Saudi_Arabia-TR20170412nL8N1HK37GX2/|title=Saudi woman seeking asylum in Australia returned to Saudi Arabia {{!}} Zawya MENA Edition|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.asianage.com/world/middle-east/130417/saudi-woman-fleeing-home-gagged-dragged-onto-plane-at-manila-airport.html|title=Saudi woman fleeing home gagged, dragged onto plane at Manila airport|date=2017-04-13|work=asianage.com/|access-date=2017-04-13}} A rare gathering of about 10 Saudi activists appeared in the arrivals area of the Riyadh airport around midnight on April 12, 2017, after a hashtag began circulating on social media urging people to "receive Dina at the airport." Two of them, Alaa Anazi a 23-year-old medical student, and a 27-year-old male, were detained after approaching airport security about the case.{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?act=url&depth=1&hl=en&ie=UTF8&nv=1&prev=_t&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=ar&sp=nmt4&tl=en&u=http://okaz.com.sa/article/1539898?rss=1|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.com|access-date=2017-04-14}}{{Cite news|url=http://okaz.com.sa/article/1539898?rss=1|title=ضبط شاب وفتاة صورا رجال الأمن بمطار الرياض|last=OKAZ_online@|first=«عكاظ» (الرياض)|date=2017-04-13|work=Okaz|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-GB}} Alaa's sister confirmed airport officials told her Alaa had been sent to a police station in central Riyadh, but said she was unable to confirm her sister’s whereabouts.{{Cite news|url=http://gulfbusiness.com/saudi-woman-dina-ali-seeking-asylum-australia-forcibly-returned-riyadh/|title=Saudi woman Dina Ali, seeking asylum in Australia, forcibly returned to Riyadh - Gulf Business|date=2017-04-13|work=Gulf Business|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-US}} Saudi-based journalist Vivien Nereim,{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/viviannereim|title=Vivian Nereim (@viviannereim) {{!}} Twitter|website=twitter.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-17}} who was at the airport, said there were no signs of the young girl, but confirmed the Saudi Human Rights Commission was following the case. She did however, collect testimonies from witnesses on the plane who described "a woman being carried on the flight screaming", suggesting that she was brought onto the plane against her will, which is illegal in the Philippines according to the [[Republic Act|Republic Act 9208]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.chanrobles.com/republicactno9208.html#.WPT9c4iGNPY|title=Republic Act No 9208 – An Act to Institute Policies to Eliminate Trafficking in Persons Especially Women and Children, Establishing the Necessary Institutional Mechanisms for the Protection ad Support of Trafficked Persons, Providing Penalties for Its Violations, and for Other|last=Manager|first=RONALD ECHALAS DIAZ, Office|website=www.chanrobles.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-17}} as this happened in the [[International zone]], where Philippine law applies. Two other witnesses stated they heard her cry for help, but it was impossible to determine her condition because she was covered.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ntnews.com.au/news/breaking-news/saudi-woman-seeking-aust-asylum-back-home/news-story/d443336b8edd7acc262c5d2dcee78454|title=Saudi woman seeking Aust asylum back home|access-date=2017-04-13}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/saudi-woman-seeking-asylum-in-australia-returned-to-saudi-arabia/3673360.html|title=Saudi woman seeking asylum in Australia returned to Saudi Arabia|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/saudi-woman-seeking-asylum-australia-returned-saudi-arabia-141542677.html|title=Saudi woman seeking asylum in Australia returned to Saudi Arabia|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-US}} The Saudi embassy in the Philippines confirmed that the citizen had returned to Saudi Arabia, adding that what happened was a "family affair":{{Cite news|url=http://kickerdaily.com/posts/2017/04/saudi-woman-escaping-family-stopped-in-ph-brought-back-to-saudi/|title=Saudi woman escaping family stopped in PH; brought back to Saudi|work=Kicker Daily News|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-us}}
''The Embassy of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques in the Republic of the Philippines confirms the incorrectness of what has been circulated on some social media platforms... what happened was a family matter and the citizen returned home with the family.''{{Cite web|url=https://globalvoices.org/2017/04/17/savedinaali-activists-call-for-release-of-saudi-woman-forcibly-sent-back-to-the-kingdom/|title=#SaveDinaAli: Activists Call for Release of Saudi Woman Forcibly Sent Back to the Kingdom · Global Voices|date=2017-04-17|website=Global Voices|access-date=2017-04-17}}
The event has brought to the forefront women's rights in Saudi Arabia and [[Wali (Islamic legal guardian)|male guardianship laws]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/report/2016/07/16/boxed/women-and-saudi-arabias-male-guardianship-system|title=Boxed In|date=2016-07-16|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-04-12|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://scoopempire.com/savedinaali-why-we-need-to-talk-about-honor-killings/|title=#SaveDinaAli: Why We Need to Talk About Honor Killings {{!}} Scoop Empire|website=scoopempire.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-13}}{{Cite news|url=http://pulse.ng/world/in-saudi-arabia-saudi-womans-fear-they-will-kill-me-id6530800.html|title=In Saudi Arabia: Saudi woman"s fear: "They will kill me"|last=Pulse|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-US}} While some social media users rushed to Dina's aid,{{Cite news|url=http://stepfeed.com/a-saudi-woman-was-returned-to-her-abusive-family-despite-twitter-outrage-5092|title=A Saudi woman was returned to her abusive family despite Twitter outrage|date=2017-04-12|work=StepFeed|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-US}} others called for Dina to be killed for stepping out of line with Saudi [[Patriarchy|patriarchal society]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/04/14/fleeing-woman-returned-saudi-arabia-against-her-will|title=Fleeing Woman Returned to Saudi Arabia Against Her Will|date=2017-04-14|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/04/14/fleeing-woman-returned-saudi-arabia-against-her-will|title=Fleeing Woman Returned to Saudi Arabia Against Her Will|date=2017-04-14|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.carbonated.tv/news/saudi-woman-detained-philippines-killed-return|title=Saudi Woman, Detained In Philippines, May Be Killed On Her Return|website=Carbonated.TV|access-date=2017-04-13}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/forcibly-repatriated-saudi-woman-my-family-will-kill-me/a-38445701|title=Forcibly repatriated Saudi woman: 'My family will kill me' {{!}} News {{!}} DW.COM {{!}} 16.04.2017|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2017-04-21}} == Current whereabouts == {{see also|The Center for Democracy and Human Rights in Saudi Arabia}} Amid ongoing public outcry Dina's current whereabouts remain unknown. Sources stated that she is held at the Correctional Facility for Women in Riyadh while further procedures are being taken by the authorities in her case. On April 19, 2017, a Saudi government official with knowledge of the case, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told [[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]] that Dina Ali was being held in a detention facility for women aged under 30 as a precaution and does not face any charges, and authorities are trying to find "appropriate solutions" to allow her to live a normal life.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-19/saudi-arabian-woman-who-tried-to-flee-put-in-protective-custody|title=Saudi Arabian Woman Who Tried to Flee Put in Protective Custody|date=2017-04-19|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-04-19}} Moudhi Aljohani said Dina's uncles hit her and told her they would kill her when they landed in Saudi Arabia. "It is most likely that she is not alive," Aljohani said in her emotional video. She criticized rights organizations for doing little to aid in the situation and then called on people not to be silent. Mohamed al-Maady from the government-led Human Rights Commission in Saudi Arabia said the organisation would be coordinating with the Saudi ministry of social development to gather information on the case.{{Cite news|url=http://sister-hood.com/moudhy-al-rashid/resistance-solidarity-savedinaali/|title=Resistance, solidarity and Dina Ali - sister-hood magazine. A Fuuse production by Deeyah Khan.|date=2017-05-09|work=sister-hood magazine. A Fuuse production by Deeyah Khan.|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-GB}} No information was available in relation to her physical or mental wellbeing. She is at risk of legal sanctions under the charge of “disobedience” because of her attempt to escape from her guardian.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gc4hr.org/news/view/1549|title=Saudi Arabia: Free Dina Ali Lasloom and repeal the Guardianship System|website=www.gc4hr.org|access-date=2017-04-17}} Human Rights Watch called on Saudi Arabia to reveal whether Lasloom is with her family or is being held by the state at a shelter. "If held by the state, the authorities should disclose under what conditions she is being held, including whether she is at a shelter at her request and whether she has freedom of movement and ability to contact the outside world."{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/04/14/fleeing-woman-returned-saudi-arabia-against-her-will|title=Fleeing Woman Returned to Saudi Arabia Against Her Will|date=2017-04-14|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.india.com/news/agencies/saudi-womans-fear-they-will-kill-me-2030124/|title=Saudi woman’s fear: ‘They will kill me’|last=Feeds|first=PTI|date=2017-04-14|work=India.com|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/forcibly-reptriated-saudi-woman-my-family-will-kill-me/a-38445701|title=Forcibly reptriated Saudi woman: 'My family will kill me' {{!}} News {{!}} DW.COM {{!}} 16.04.2017|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2017-04-16}} == Aftermath == Dina's story triggered protest outside Saudi embassies in several countries around the world, most notably by the [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]] in [[Ireland]].{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/ivanabacik/|title=Ivana Bacik on Twitter|last=|first=|date=|work=Twitter|access-date=2017-05-06|language=en}} The Labour Party also demanded to know if Ireland was among European UN members who voted Saudi Arabia onto the [[United Nations Commission on the Status of Women|UN Commission on the Status of Women]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.twitter.com/labour/status/860068852331417600|title=The Labour Party on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2017-05-07|language=en}} the Irish government responded by refusing to disclose how they voted.{{Cite news|url=https://www.unwatch.org/irish-coverage-u-n-elects-saudi-arabia-womens-rights-commission/|title=Irish Coverage: U.N. elects Saudi Arabia to Women’s Rights Commission - UN Watch|date=2017-05-05|work=UN Watch|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US}} A campaign was also started by Human Rights Watch,{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/SaveDinaAli|title=Urge Saudi Leader to Protect Dina Ali Lasloom|date=2017-04-21|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-05-06|language=en}} instructing social media users to tweet to [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|Saudi King Salman]] using the hashtag #SaveDinaAli, urging a [[Royal Pardon]]. The case continues to receive widespread media coverage due to the extreme and legally questionable nature of Dina's [[extradition]]. On May 7, 2017, [[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]] published an entire segment on the event.{{Citation|last=RT America|title=Saudi Arabia doesn’t want women to flee & speak out ‒ activist|date=2017-05-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rbfUAZSgjt8&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-05-05}} The report came a day after [[United States]] [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] announced a foreign trip to [[Saudi Arabia]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/04/politics/trump-israel-vatican-foreign-trip/index.html|title=Trump to visit the Vatican, Israel and Saudi Arabia on first foreign trip|last=CNN|first=Jim Acosta, Dan Merica and Jake Tapper|website=CNN|access-date=2017-05-05}} highlighting increased [[Saudi Arabia–United States relations|economic and political ties]] with the kingdom, while a deep [[cultural divide]] remains.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ellenrwald/2017/04/14/the-case-of-dina-ali-and-why-business-will-determine-the-future-for-women-in-saudi-arabia/|title=The Case Of Dina Ali And Why Business Will Determine The Future For Women In Saudi Arabia|last=Wald|first=Ellen R.|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-05-06}} A day earlier, a Saudi [[royal decree]] allowing women greater access to government services was passed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/saudi-decree-guardian-system-170505210416738.html|title=Cautious welcome to Saudi decree over guardian system|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-05-06}} On May 28, 2017 [[BBC World Service]] aired a segment chronicling Dina's attempted escape.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p053bmvc|title=Travelling Without Male Consent, BBC Trending - BBC World Service|website=BBC|access-date=2017-05-29}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-40105983|title=Flying without a man: The mysterious case of Dina Ali|date=2017-06-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en-GB}} On 8 June 2017, [http://www.adhrb.org Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain (ADHRB)] organized a side event during the [[United Nations Human Rights Council|UN Human Rights Council’]]s 35th session, where Dina's case was a topic of the discussion.{{Cite news|url=http://www.adhrb.org/2017/06/adhrb-hrc35-event-summary-womens-rights-saudi-arabia/|title=ADHRB at HRC35: Event Summary on Women’s Rights in Saudi Arabia - Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain|date=2017-06-08|work=Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain|access-date=2017-07-06|language=en-US}} After Norwegian Public Broadcaster [[NRK]] referred Dina's story several parliamentarians, including [[Socialist Left Party (Norway)|Socialist Left Party]] Leader [[Audun Lysbakken]] and [[Abid Raja|Abdi Raja]], requested foreign minister [[Ine Marie Eriksen Søreide]] take up the women's rights situation with Saudi Arabia. "This is an extreme form of gender apartheid. I would like to ask, if the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Foreign Minister]] agrees, that Norway raise the matter with Saudi Arabia." said parliamentary representative [[Jan Bøhler]]. A meeting has been set for spring 2018. {{Cite news|url=https://www.dagbladet.no/kultur/et-islamistisk-familieanliggende/67494542|title=Et islamistisk familieanliggende|date=2017-04-18|work=Dagbladet.no|access-date=2018-01-03|language=no}} ==See also== * [[Islamic feminism|Islamic Feminism]] *[[Human rights in Saudi Arabia]] **[[Israa al-Ghomgham]] – Saudi human rights activist facing execution by beheading **[[Nimr al-Nimr|Sheikh Baqir al-Nimr]] – dissident cleric executed for criticism of the Saudi regime **[[Raif Badawi]] – imprisoned Saudi dissident, writer and activist **[[Hamza Kashgari]] – pro-democracy activist and columnist imprisoned for blasphemy **[[Samar Badawi]] – imprisoned Saudi activist **[[Loujain al-Hathloul]] - imprisoned Saudi activist **[[Sara bint Talal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]] - Saudi princess under political asylum in the United Kingdom **[[Fahad Albutairi|Fahad al-Butairi]] – abducted in Jordan and taken to be imprisoned in Saudi Arabia **[[Manal al-Sharif]] – Saudi human rights activist **[[Mishaal bint Fahd bin Mohammed Al Saud]] – Saudi princess executed for alleged adultery ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Feminism|Saudi Arabia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ali, Dina}} [[Category:1993 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kidnapping]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian feminists]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian activists]] [[Category:Human rights in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Women's rights in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Violence against women in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Right of asylum]] [[Category:Human rights abuses]] [[Category:Human rights in the Philippines]] [[Category:Right of asylum in Australia]] [[Category:Philippines–Saudi Arabia relations]]

'''Electronic colonialism''' theory was first started by [[Tom McPhail]], a Canadian who began his career with [[Marshall McLuhan]]. Following a posting with [[UNESCO]] in Paris, McPhail wrote a book for SAGE entitled Electronic Colonialism: the Future of International Broadcasting and Communication in 1981.<ref>Electronic Colonialism: The Future of International Broadcasting and Communication. Thomas L. McPhail. Beverly Hills: Sage, 1981</ref> The [[foreword]] was written by [[Everett Rogers]]. The theory is about the impact on the mind of repeated [[mass media]] messages, including [[television advertisement|commercials]], on audiences around the world. Just as earlier [[colonialism|colonial institutions]], like Great Britain, sought out soil anywhere in the world for [[colony|colonies]], now [[multimedia]] giants seek to capture the eyeballs, ears and minds of millions of viewers, readers, or listeners. [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]], [[MTV]], Netflix, [[Comcast]], Hollywood, [[CNN]], [[BBC]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], [[Google]], the Internet, and others—all seek to influence, not by force of arms, but by packaging media to attract large audiences for advertisers around the globe. The mass media over time will impact more and more individuals—primarily using the English language—to become more similar as indigenous films and artifacts become [[marginalized]] by a cultural tsunami created by high-quality and mass-produced media messages and systems.
Electronic colonialism theory explains how mass media are leading to a new concept of empire. It will not be one based on military power or land acquisition but one based on controlling the mind. It is a psychological or mental empire. It is an evolving global "Empire of the Mind." The global media are collectively influencing the minds, attitudes, values, and languages of individuals around the globe. It is an electronic mass media driven phenomena which over time will not only expand the frontiers of the multi-national communication firms but will far exceed even the vast reach of the declining, once-great [[British Empire]].
Prime examples of electronic colonialism are the initiatives of [[Google|Google Inc]]. The first is to digitize the works of five major [[United States|US]] and [[United Kingdom|UK]] libraries.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/4094271.stm BBC NEWS | Technology | Google to scan famous libraries<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> (The libraries are at [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]], the [[University of Michigan]], [[Oxford University]], and the [[New York Public Library]]—all [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] in language (English), history, focus, framing, and orientation. Google will help define the future of knowledge by its vast network power and global platform. The wealth and impact of other, non-English, libraries around the world will be both diminished and marginalized by the Google project. For example, the 600-year-old [[Bibliothèque nationale de France|National Library of France]] will not contribute to the new data base and thus the 8-year-old-Google suddenly represents a major challenge to [[France]]'s academic, cultural, and linguistic heritage.
The second example is a 2007 project to personalize Google's search results. Using the search history or pattern used by individuals, Google intends to customize information or thinking patterns to select which results to prioritize for each individual researcher. Google and other internet-based search services are attempting to get into the brains of users to aid in presenting more relevant results based on previous research patterns. Other search firms, such as [[Microsoft]] and [[Yahoo!]] are also attempting to develop unique [[algorithm]]s to aid in customizing searches based on user patterns. It is not only the large corporations that are tracking user's'patterns. [[CenturyTel]] Inc. of [[Louisiana]], a small telephone company, is also into behavior targeting. Using equipment installed on the phone lines, CenturyTel will collect data about every web site visited and then sell the information to external online advertisers.
All media and communication firms want a big piece of the $17 billion internet advertising market. By chasing more precise and detailed mapping behavior, via an algorithm, they want to deliver "the minds" of internet customers to a growing list of online advertisers.
The theory of electronic colonialism also examines the [[hegemony|hegemonic]] power of the USA as it applies to the global cultural industries. This includes the American-centric control of the [[Internet]] via [[ICANN]] and the expansion of American media and communication empires around the world.
== Notes and references == {{reflist}} * McLuhan, M. (1964) Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. * McPhail, T. (1981) Electronic Colonialism: The Future of International Broadcasting and Communication. Newbury Park: Sage. * McPhail, T. & McPhail, B. (1990) Communication: The Canadian Experience. Toronto: Copp Clark Pitman. * McPhail, T. (2002) Global Communication: Theories, Stakeholders, and Trends. Boston: Allyn & Bacon. * McPhail, T. (2014) Global Communication: Theories, Stakeholders, and Trends. (4th ed.) London: Blackwell. * Raley, R. (2004) eEmpires. Cultural Critique, 57, 111-150.

{{Infobox website | logo = | logo_caption = | screenshot = | screenshot_alt = | url = {{URL|https://www.foodsharing.de}} | commercial = No | registration = Optional, but required for participants | language = German | num_users = 163.000 foodsharer (november 2017){{cite web|title=Allgemeiner Pressetext über foodsharing|periodical=|publisher=|url=https://wiki.foodsharing.de/Pressetext|format=|accessdate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}
37.917 voluntary foodsavers (1 May 2018){{citeweb|title=statistics on foodsharing.de|url = https://foodsharing.de/statistik|access-date = 2018-05-01|language = de-DE}} | content_license = MIT | owner = Foodsharing e.V. | launch_date = {{start date and age|2012|12|12|df=yes/no}} | current_status = online | name = foodsharing.de | logo_size = | background = | screenshot_size = | programming_language = PHP, HTML, Python, CSS, Ruby, JavaScript, ApacheConf, Shell, Vue }} '''foodsharing.de''' is an online platform that saves and distributes surplus food in [[Germany]] and [[Austria]]. It is managed by the Foodsharing association (foodsharing e.V.) and was founded on December 12, 2012. On foodsharing.de individuals, retailers and producers can offer or collect food that would otherwise be thrown away. This service is completely free, and functions thanks to volunteer work. The projects' goal is to fight everyday [[food waste]] and to raise awareness about this problem in society. == History == The original idea to create a platform against food waste arose between [[Valentin Thurn]], director of the film [[Taste the Waste]], and Sebastian Engbrocks, supervisor of the film's social media campaign, in the summer of 2011. In early 2012 the design students Thomas Gerling and Christian Zehnter, and television journalist Ines Rainer, independently came up with a similar idea. The joint project is the result of the collaboration of all these individuals. From April to July 2012 they raised the necessary starting capital through crowdfunding via [[Startnext.de]]. The goal was to collect 10.000 [[Euro|EUR]] and in the end 11.594 EUR was received from 394 supporters.[https://www.startnext.com/en/foodsharing Project description at Startnext Crowdfunding] (in German), Retrieved: 6 February 2014. On November 16 the platform entered beta phase and launched on December 12, 2012.foodsharing.de: [http://foodsharing.de/newsletters/news_public_view/4 Relaunch of the webpage] (in German), Retrieved: 9 February 2014. A relaunch on May 12, 2013 equipped it with a revised design and new search options. In May 2013 it was also launched in Austria, initially under the name myfoodsharing.at,[http://kurier.at/wirtschaft/marktplatz/myfoodsharing-at-erste-plattform-fuer-lebensmittel-sharing-online/14.317.744 Foodsharing starts in Austria] (in German), Kurier, Retrieved: 31 May 2013. and is now merged with the German platform. As of February 2014 the German foodsharing.de has attracted close to 35.000 active users.foodsharing.de: [http://foodsharing.de/ foodsharing.de] (in German), Retrieved: 9 February 2014. It won the Greentec Award in the communication category on July 10, 2013.Greentec Awards: [http://www.greentec-awards.com/wettbewerb/awards-2013/preistraeger-2013.html Awards 2013 - Category Communication] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151206032549/http://www.greentec-awards.com/wettbewerb/awards-2013/preistraeger-2013.html |date=2015-12-06 }} (in German), Retrieved: 6 February 2014. In December 2014, foodsharing.de and lebensmittelretten.de, a web site founded by [[Raphael Fellmer]] and Raphael Wintrich, merged their operations.{{Cite news|title = Finding Takers for Lonely Leftovers in a Culinary Nook of the Sharing Economy|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/27/world/europe/german-matchmakers-pair-lonely-leftovers-and-rumbling-bellies.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2014-11-26|access-date = 2016-01-18|issn = 0362-4331|first = Sally|last = Mcgrane}} The functionality for sharing food with other individuals was taken from foodsharing.de, while the collaborations with shops and supermarkets was taken from lebensmittelretten.de. == Concept == foodsharing.de enables individuals to share food, whilst also allowing volunteers to pick up food from businesses to distribute it through public storage places. Since most supermarkets are organized as chains and therefore each branch has to follow standardized rules and regulations, the management is contacted directly.[https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/free-food-sharing-leftovers-surplus-local-popular Foodsharing sites and apps stop leftovers going to waste], Retrieved: 18 January 2016 This results in regional and sometimes even national collaborations,foodsharing.de: [http://foodsharing.de/firmen These companies participate] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141116215947/http://foodsharing.de/firmen |date=2014-11-16 }} (in German), Retrieved: 6 February 2014. e.g. with Bio Company.Bio Company: [http://www.biocompany.de/downloads/pressemitteilung-bio-company-setzt-zeichen-gegen-muell.pdf Raises awareness against waste] (in German), Retrieved: 6 February 2014. There are also many local co-operations with single supermarkets or bakeries, which are often started independently by members of the community. == Differentiation from other methods of foodsaving == Other organizations like the German [[Food bank|Tafel]] differ from foodsharing in that the surplus food is given to people before date expires. Whereas with foodsharing.de expired food is also distributed if it is still edible and does not pose a health risk. Volunteers (so-called 'foodsavers') need to sign a legal agreement that renders the businesses not liable and obliges the foodsavers to pass on the food for free. While the main focus of Tafel is to assert if someone is in need, foodsharing.de is interested only in saving food, without focusing on the financial circumstances of the recipient. In contrast to [[dumpster diving]], which is about taking non-spoiled food from waste containers, foodsaving.de wants to prevent food from being thrown away in the first place. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|https://www.foodsharing.de}} [[Category:Crowdfunded projects]] [[Category:Food banks]] [[Category:Sustainable food system]] [[Category:DIY culture]] [[Category:Recycling organizations]] [[Category:Social networking services]] [[Category:Organisations based in Germany]]

{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} '''Force 17''' ({{lang-ar|القوة 17}}) was a commando and special operations unit of the [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian]] [[Fatah]] movement and later of the Office of the [[President of the Palestinian National Authority|Chairman of the Palestinian Authority]]. It was formed in the early 1970s by [[Ali Hassan Salameh]] (Abu Hassan).{{Cite web|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/middle_east/2001/israel_and_the_palestinians/profiles/1691693.stm|title = Who are Force 17?|date = December 4, 2001|accessdate = |website = |publisher = BBC|last = |first = }} Initially, the group was housed in building 17 of Al-Fakhani Street in Beirut. ==History== Force 17 was formed by Ali Hassan Salameh in the 1970s in an attempt to professionalize Fatah's intelligence services.{{cite book |last=Bird| first=Kai |date=2014 |title=The Good Spy}} Force 17 was also initially responsible [[Yasser Arafat]]'s personal security.{{Cite web|url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/holy/combatants/palestinians.html|title = Palestinian Political Organizations|date = |accessdate = October 28, 2014|website = |publisher = PBS|last = |first = }} === Dissolution === In 1994, the unit was largely absorbed into Yasser Arafat’s personal security force, the Palestinian Authority's "Presidential Security".[http://www.miftah.org/Display.cfm?DocId=10400&CategoryId=21 ''The Palestinian Security Services: Past and Present'']. MIFTAH, 30 May 2006.
"Presidential Security: What was Yasser Arafat’s former personal-security force {{sic|comprised|hide=y| of}} a highly trained group of some 3,000 officers, now guards Mahmoud Abbas. Most of these men were members of Force 17, an armed unit whose duties included guarding VIPs and securing important locations such the presidential compound in Ramallah."{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/arabic/news/newsid_1693000/1693528.stm |title=القوة 17والجناح العسكري لفتح |publisher=BBC |date=1 December 2006}} In 2006, the unit was separated, to become the [[Palestinian Presidential Guard|Presidential Guard]] as part of the [[Palestinian Security Services]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=icV4k__xMmgC&pg=PA160 Friedrich, Luethold], 2007: Appendix A, p. 161. In 2007, a plan to dismantle the remnant of Force 17 and incorporate it into the Presidential Guard of President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] was unveiled by [[Ynet]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3457445,00.html |title=''Abbas to dismantle Force 17'' |publisher=Ynet News |date=10 August 2007}} The Force was merged into the Presidential Guard and the [[Palestinian National Security Forces|National Security Forces]] in December 2007.Roland Friedrich, Arnold Luethold and Firas Milhem, [http://www.dcaf.ch/content/download/35601/526419/file/final_EN.pdf ''The Security Sector Legislation of the Palestinian National Authority''], p. 272; Decision No. ( ) of 2007, 6 December 2007 (3,2 MB). Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF), January 2008. [http://www.dcaf.ch/Publications/The-Security-Sector-Legislation-of-the-Palestinian-National-Authority On website] ==Operations== *September 1985: Gunmen allegedly part of Force 17 stormed a yacht moored in [[Larnaca, Cyprus]] killing three Israeli citizens.{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1985/09/26/world/3-israelis-slain-by-palestinians-in-cyprus.html|title = 3 Israelis Slain by Palestinians in Cyprus|date = September 26, 1985|accessdate = |website = |publisher = The New York Times|last = |first = }} [[Palestinian Liberation Organization|PLO]] authorities at the time denied involvement.{{Cite web|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1985-09-27/news/mn-18160_1_israel-asks-cyprus|title = Israel Asks Cyprus to Extradite Pro-Palestinian Gunmen Accused of Killing 3 Aboard Yacht|date = September 27, 1985|accessdate = |website = |publisher = Los Angeles Times|last = |first = }} *December 1985: Force 17 claimed responsibility for the kidnapping and murder of [[Israeli Defense Forces|IDF]] soldier Moshe Levi. His body was found burning near [[Mazor]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.mfa.gov.il/mfa/mfa-archive/1996/pages/kidnapppings%20of%20idf%20soldiers.aspx|title = Kidnappings of IDF Soldiers|date = |accessdate = October 28, 2014|website = |publisher = Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs|last = |first = }} === Rumored operations === * The group has been accused by some of having carried out the 1987 assassination of Palestinian cartoonist [[Naji al-Ali]] in London.{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21727937-reinvestigation-cartoonists-assassination-1987-stirs-rumours-among-londons|title=Can a murder that happened three decades ago now be solved?|website=The Economist|access-date=2017-09-06}} ===Operations against Force 17=== *On January 28, 2001, the IDF captured six members of Force 17, who were believed responsible for the shooting deaths of at least seven Israelis in the Ramallah area, including [[Binyamin Kahane]] and his wife Talya Kahane. Binyamin Kahane was the son of [[Kach and Kahane Chai|Kach]] leader, [[Rabbi Meir Kahane]].{{Cite web|url = http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/2001/Pages/Israel%20Security%20Agency%20-ISA-%20and%20IDF%20forces%20arrest.aspx|title = Israel Security Agency IDF forces arrested terrorists suspected of shootings|date = |accessdate = October 28, 2014|website = |publisher = Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs|last = |first = }} * February 2001, an Israeli helicopter fired a missile killing prominent Force 17 member Massoud Ayyad.{{Cite web|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/1322613/Arafat-aide-killed-in-helicopter-ambush.html|title = Arafat aide killed in helicopter ambush|date = February 14, 2001|accessdate = |website = |publisher = The Telegraph|last = |first = }} ==Leadership== According to most reports Force 17 was founded in the early 1970s by [[Ali Hassan Salameh]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.newsweek.com/wooing-red-prince-251604|title = The Wooing of the Red Prince|date = May 20, 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = Newsweek|last = |first = }} In 1979 Salameh and his bodyguards were assassinated in [[Beirut]] by Israeli intelligence.{{Cite web|url = http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/books/robert-c-ames-and-the-death-of-an-american-view-of-the-middle-east#page1|title = Robert C Ames and the death of an American view of the Middle East|date = June 19, 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = The National|last = |first = }} Mahmoud Awad Damra reportedly commanded Force 17. In 2006, he was sentenced by an Israeli court to 15 years in prison for his role in planning several attacks against Israel. He was released as part of the [[Gilad Shalit prisoner exchange]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Terrorist-released-in-Schalit-deal-named-PA-adviser|title = Terrorist released in Schalit deal named PA adviser|date = January 2, 2012|accessdate = |website = |publisher = The Jerusalem Post|last = |first = }} == See also == * [[Force 14]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Fatah]] [[Category:Defunct Palestinian militant groups]] [[Category:Palestinian National Security Forces]] [[Category:Military wings of political parties]] [[Category:1970s establishments in Lebanon]]

{{About|a [[left-wing|left-wing guerilla]] force|the Bangladeshi Mukti Bahini force|Gonobahini (Mukti Bahini)}} '''Gonobahini''' ({{lang-bn| গণবাহিনী}} " People's Army") was the armed wing of the [[Jatiya Samajtantrik Dal]].<ref name=":1">{{cite web|last1=Staff Correspondent|title=JS sees debate over role of Gono Bahini|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/js-sees-debate-over-role-of-gono-bahini-31691|website=thedailystar.net|publisher=The Daily Star|accessdate=9 July 2015}}</ref> ==History== In 1972, [[Bangladesh Chhatra League]], the student wing of the [[Bangladesh Awami League]] split to form the [[Jatiyo Samajtantrik Dal]], led by [[Serajul Alam Khan]].<ref name=":0">{{cite news|last1=Hossain|first1=Kazi Mobarak|title=Hasanul Haq Inu’s JaSoD splits as he names Shirin general secretary|url=http://bdnews24.com/politics/2016/03/12/hasanul-haq-inus-jasod-splits-as-he-names-shirin-general-secretary|accessdate=11 July 2016|agency=Dhaka Tribune|issue=2|publisher=Dhaka Tribune|date=13 March 2016}}</ref>
The party called for establishing [[socialism]] through an armed revolution. As a result, the Gonobahini was formed and led a violent insurgency against the government of [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]].<ref name=":0" /> In 1974, Hasanul Haq Inu led a group of armed men to attack the residence of then [[home minister]] [[Mansur Ali]], which resulted in a [[1974 Ramna massacre|massacre]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rizvi now blasts Inu at press briefing|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/politics/rizvi-now-blasts-inu-press-briefing-1240042|accessdate=11 July 2016|agency=UNB|issue=1|publisher=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]|date=15 June 2016}}</ref> The Gonobahini is also accused of killing numerous [[Bangladesh Chhatra League]] and [[Bangladesh Awami League|Awami League]] members.<ref name=":1" /> ==Disbandment== When [[Ziaur Rahman]] was freed by members of the Gonobahini, [[Ziaur Rahman]] realized that the disorder set off by them in the [[National Revolution and Solidarity Day|mutiny]] had to be suppressed firmly if discipline was to be restored in the [[Bangladesh Army]]. [[Ziaur Rahman]] declared [[martial law]], cracked down on the [[Jatiyo Samajtantrik Dal]] and Gonobahini, [[Abu Taher]] was sentenced to death and other party figures had various terms of imprisonment slapped on them.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ahsan|first1=Syed Badrul|title=Bourgeois dreams of socialist revolution|url=http://www.observerbd.com/2015/07/07/98425.php|accessdate=13 July 2016|agency=The Daily Observer|publisher=The Daily Observer|date=7 July 2015}}</ref>
==Criticism== In 2016, [[Bangladesh Awami League]] general secretary [[Syed Ashraful Islam]] remarked that [[Jatiyo Samajtantrik Dal|Jatiya Samajtantrik Dal]] and Gonobahini had created the political atmosphere that led to the [[assassination of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Awami League will have to atone for making a JaSoD leader minister, says Syed Ashraf|url=http://bdnews24.com/politics/2016/06/13/awami-league-will-have-to-atone-for-making-a-jasod-leader-minister-says-syed-ashraf|accessdate=11 July 2016|agency=bdnews24.com|publisher=bdnews24.com|date=13 June 2016}}</ref> Opposition party leaders also hold its activities responsible for Sheikh Mujib's killing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Clarify your role in Bangabandhu killing, BNP to Inu|url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/bangladesh/news/76721/No-lecture-on-democracy-please-BNP-to-Inu|accessdate=11 July 2016|agency=[[Prothom Alo]]|publisher=[[Prothom Alo]]|date=24 August 2015}}</ref> Other opposition figures have called it "the [[Al Qaeda]] of its day."<ref>{{cite news|title=Inu, Khairul to be tried in people's court: BNP|url=http://www.newstoday.com.bd/index.php?option=details&news_id=2434364&date=2016-02-03|accessdate=11 July 2016|agency=UNB|publisher=The News Today|date=15 June 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Lal Bahini]]
==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1972 establishments in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Communism in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Military wings of political parties]] [[Category:Far-left politics]] [[Category:Communist terrorism]] [[Category:Terrorism in Bangladesh]]

'''Health 21''' or '''Health21''' is the name given to the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) [[Europe]]an Region [[health policy|policy]] framework derived from the "[[Health For All|health-for-all]] policy for the twenty-first century" passed by the [[World Health Assembly]] in 1998.<ref>World Health Assembly. [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/documentStore/g/w/o/gwo93a99/Sgwo93a99.pdf Resolution WHA51.7. Health for all policy for the twenty-first century.] Geneva: World Health Organization, 1998. Accessed 2013 Apr 9.</ref> The framework was called "Health 21" not only because it dealt with [[health]] in the 21st century, but also because it laid out 21 "targets" for improving the health of Europeans.<ref name=Intro>[http://www.euro.who.int/document/EHFA5-E.pdf Health21: an introduction to the health for all policy framework for the WHO European Region.] (European Health for All series; no. 5.) Copenhagen: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe, 1998. {{ISBN|92-890-1348-6}}. Accessed 2013 Apr 9.</ref><ref name=Framework>[http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/98398/wa540ga199heeng.pdf Health21: the health for all policy framework for the WHO European Region.] (European Health for All series; no. 6.) Copenhagen: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe, 1999. {{ISBN|92-890-1349-4}}. Accessed 2013 Apr 9.</ref>
==Targets==
The Health 21 targets were:<ref name=Intro/><ref name=Framework/>
# "Solidarity for health in the European Region," or "closing the health gap between countries" # "Equity in health," or "closing the health gap within countries" # "Healthy start in life," for example "[[health policy|policies]] should... create a supportive family, with wanted children and good parenthood capacity" # "Health of young people," that is, "young people in the region should be healthier and better able to fulfil their roles in society" # "Healthy aging" as reflected in increases in [[life expectancy]], disability-free life expectancy, and the proportion of older people who are healthy and at home # "Improving [[mental health]]" # "Reducing communicable diseases" # "Reducing [[non-communicable disease]]s" # "Reducing [[injury]] from violence and accidents" # "A healthy and safe physical environment" # "Healthier living" such as "healthier behaviour in such fields as [[nutrition]], physical activity and sexuality" and "increase in the availability, affordability and accessibility of safe and healthy food" # "Reducing harm from alcohol, drugs and tobacco" # "Settings for health," specifically, "people in the region should have greater opportunities to live in healthy physical and social environments at home, at school, at the workplace and in the local community" # "Multisectoral responsibility for health" # "An integrated health sector" with "better access to family- and community-oriented [[primary health care]], supported by a flexible and responsive hospital system" # "Managing for quality of care" by focusing on outcomes # "Funding health services and allocating resources," calling for "sustainable financing and resource allocation mechanisms for [[health care system]]s based on the principles of equal access, cost–effectiveness, solidarity, and optimum quality" # "Developing [[Health Human Resources|human resources for health]]" to ensure that health professionals and others "have acquired appropriate knowledge, attitudes and skills to protect and promote health" # "Research and knowledge for health": "health research, information and communication systems" should "better support the acquisition, effective utilization, and dissemination of knowledge" # "Mobilizing partners for health," including governments, professionals, nongovernmental organizations, the private sector, and individual citizens # "Policies and strategies for [[health for all]]" at "country, regional and local levels"
==See also== *[[Health policy]] *[[Health promotion]] ** [[Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion]] ** [[Bangkok Charter]] ** [[Jakarta Declaration]] * [[Primary health care]] **[[Health for all]] ** [[Alma Ata Declaration]] * [[Public health]] **[[Healthy city]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Department of Health (1999) ''Saving Lives: Our Healthier Nation''. London: DoH. * WHO (1999) ''Reducing inequalities in health''. Copenhagen: WHO.

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=April 2010}} {{underlinked|date=February 2013}} }} [[Image:BusinessofGovernment Logo.jpg|thumb|IBM Center for The Business of Government logo]]
The '''[[ibm.com|IBM]] Center for The Business of Government''' produces and disseminates thought leadership that focuses on public management issues facing government executives at all levels. According to its mission statement, the center seeks to connect public management research to practice in order to improve government effectiveness and performance. It does this by funding independent third-party research,<ref>{{cite web|last=Kelman|first=Steve|title=How IBM supports academic research on the business of government|url=http://fcw.com/blogs/lectern/2012/06/chenok-ibm-center.aspx|publisher=FCW The Business of Federal Technology|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> publishing a bi-annual magazine, producing a weekly radio interview program,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Business of Government Hour|url=http://www.federalnewsradio.com/?nid=159|publisher=FederalNewsRadio.com|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> convening discussions with practitioners and academics, and hosting forums and various blogs and other online content.
==History== The center was originally formed in 1998 as the [[PriceWaterhouseCoopers]] Endowment for The Business of Government. When IBM acquired the management consulting arm of PriceWaterhouseCoopers in 2002, it was renamed. The center is led by Executive Director Dan Chenok,<ref>{{cite web|last=Weigelt|first=Matthew|title=Dan Chenok to take reins at IBM think tank|url=http://fcw.com/articles/2012/06/04/chenok-breul-ibm.aspx|publisher=FCW The Business of Federal Technology|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> a former career federal executive for information policy and technology at the [[Office of Management and Budget]] (OMB).
The IBM Center for The Business of Government is one of several dozen [[good government]] organizations located in Washington, D.C. that provide context and offer insights and practical, actionable recommendations that address federal government mission and management challenges.
== Research and publications == The IBM center includes in its name “Business of Government” to emphasize its focus on the management and operation—not the policies—of government. It seeks to “bridge the gap” between research and practice by helping to stimulate and accelerate the production of actionable research.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Journal of Public Administration, Research and Theory|volume=21|issue=suppl1|pages=i99-i112}}</ref>
"Unlike traditional scholarly outlets, the IBM Center makes explicitly clear that its reports are to be ‘written for government executives and managers’ and that in making the decision to fund research proposals, it looks for very practical findings and recommendations—not just theory and concepts—in order to assist executives and managers to more effectively respond to mission and management challenges." <ref>Journal of Public Administration, Research and Theory, Volume 21, Issue (suppl 1) pp. i99-i112</ref>
Since its inception, the IBM Center for The Business of Government has published more than 250 research reports and books in areas such as public sector management and performance, technology and innovation, security and privacy, acquisition and procurement, and citizen engagement.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hardy|first=Michael|title=The Chenok era dawns at IBM center|url=http://fcw.com/articles/2012/06/30/buzz-chenok-breul.aspx|publisher=FCW The Business of Federal Technology|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> Reports are commissioned through a competitive funding process<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Center for The Business of Government - Research Stipends Synopsis:|url=https://researchfunding.duke.edu/detail.asp?OppID=5127|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> that occurs twice a year, in the spring and fall. Funded researchers have included academics from top schools of public management and business, including Harvard University, the London School of Economics, Syracuse University and Johns Hopkins University.
== Recent research interests == * Leading in an era of complex challenges * Managing collaboration and connectivity * Using data and analytics to make better decisions * Pursuing cost savings and improving performance * Identifying acquisition approaches that engage the private sector more effectively * Managing risks and responding to threats in today’s security environment * Providing insights for the presidential transition from campaigning to governing
== Notable publications == * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/content/business-government-magazine The Business of Government Magazine]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Business of Government Magazine Spring/Summer 2012|url=http://www.federalnewsradio.com/163/2931810/The-Business-of-Government-Magazine-SpringSummer-2012|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> – This bi-annual magazine features interviews with and profiles of government leaders as well as topical articles on management issues facing public sector executives. It also provides summaries of recent reports, radio interviews and events.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Business of Government|url=http://digital.turn-page.com/i/73025/4|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/report/seven-management-imperatives Seven Management Imperatives] – This report identifies seven societal trends that governments will have to manage and the imperatives that will drive governments to manage differently, including performance improvement and greater collaboration with the private sector.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Center for the Business of Government publishes report on seven management imperatives for government|url=http://servicedelivery.fahcsia.gov.au/2011/08/01/ibm-center-for-the-business-of-government-publishes-report-on-seven-management-imperatives-for-government/|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/report/ten-challenges-facing-public-managers Ten Challenges Facing Public Managers]<ref>{{cite web|last=Longley|first=Robert|title=The Next President's Top 10 Challenges|url=http://usgovinfo.about.com/od/thepresidentandcabinet/a/prestopten.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> – This report outlines a set of management issues that government executives will face in the coming years. These are ten “big challenges” for the decade ahead that include not only fiscal concerns of the Government Accounting Office but also the role of results, the impending crisis of competence and the blurring of boundaries in delivering services.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ten Challenges in Public Management Identified for Decade Ahead|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/23781.wss#release|publisher=IBM|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/report/six-trends-transforming-government Six Trends Transforming Government]<ref>{{cite news|last=Davidson|first=Joe|title=Report Offers 6 Keys to a More Successful Government|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/17/AR2006091700506.html|accessdate=5 February 2013|work=The Washington Post|date=18 September 2006}}</ref> – Increasingly, the challenges facing government are more complex and face a new set of imperatives for success. This report identifies six trends that are leading to improved government performance. These trends, often in combination with one another, make it more likely that government will be able to successfully respond to the ever-increasing and complex challenges it faces today and that it will continue to face in the future. * ''[http://www.businessofgovernment.org/book/operators-manual-new-administration Operators Manual]'' ''for the Next Administration'' and ''[http://www.businessofgovernment.org/book/getting-it-done-guide-government-executives Getting It Done]'' – The handbook, ''Operator’s Manual for the Next Administration'', is aimed at senior management, while ''Getting It Done'' is billed as a guide for government executives. The books offer tips on managing the confirmation process, learning about federal agencies and how they work, assembling a leadership team, and developing a vision and an agenda.<ref>{{cite web|title=Center for The Business of Government Lays Out Key Imperatives for Managing the Presidential Transition and Governing in a New Administration|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/25375.wss|publisher=IBM|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref>
==''The Business of Government Hour''== For more than a decade, the weekly radio program ''The Business of Government Hour''<ref>[http://www.businessofgovernment.org/interviews ''The Business of Government Hour'']</ref> has interviewed government executives who are changing the way government does business. As a platform for government executives to discuss their careers, agencies and agency accomplishments, as well as their vision of government in the 21st century, the program provides a forum for government leaders to highlight key initiatives, management challenges and successes.
''The Business of Government Hour'' has interviewed more than 300 government executives from deputy secretaries to C-Suite executives from a range of federal agencies, as well as state and local government executives. The show has interviewed such government executives and thought leaders as Admiral [[Thad Allen]], Dr. [[Francis Collins]], Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]], Governor [[Tim Kaine]], Dr. [[Raymond Orbach]], Dr. [[Robert Braun]], Dr. [[Kathleen Merrigan]], General [[Michael Hayden (general)|Michael Hayden]], General [[James R. Clapper|James Clapper]], [[Robert F. Hale]], [[David M. Walker (U.S. Comptroller General)|David Walker]], [[Eugene Louis Dodaro|Gene Dodaro]], [[Michael J. Astrue|Michael Astrue]], Ambassador [[Elizabeth Frawley Bagley]], [[Craig Fugate]], [[Alec Ross (innovator)|Alec Ross]], Tom Allen, General [[Anthony Zinni|Tony Zinni]] and Professor [[Joseph Nye]].
== Presidential transition activities == The center’s “Governing in the Next Four Years” series, which examines issues facing the new presidential term, continues a series of transition-related materials that began with several publications in 2004{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} and continued in 2007, when Center Senior Fellow John Kamensky began writing a Presidential Transition blog<ref>{{cite web|last=Kamensky|first=John|title=The Presidential Transition|url=http://transition2008.wordpress.com/|publisher=IBM|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> that has been cited in the US and overseas.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Conference on Administrative Development Towards Excellence in Public Sector Performance|url=http://www.fifty.ipa.edu.sa/conf/customcontrols/paperworkflash/Content/pdf/m1/en/7.pdf|publisher=Saudi Arabia Institute of Public Administration|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rollins|first=John|title=2008-2009 Presidential Transition: National Security Considerations and Options|url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/RL34456.pdf|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ogden|first=Benjamin|title=The United States Drug Enforcement Administration: Pertaining to Public Safety and Homeland Security|url=http://digitalcommons.pace.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1009&context=homelandsecurity|publisher=Pace University|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Inauguration: Online Resources|url=http://burma.usembassy.gov/uploads/images/BLh5yEhDh-lDstCR-2-_VQ/InaugurationOnlineResources.pdf|publisher=The American Center|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref>
== The IBM Center Blog == Articles written by center staff and posted to their blog are often syndicated, excerpted or quoted in government-oriented media platforms, such as AOL Gov,<ref>[http://gov.aol.com/ AOL Gov]</ref> Government Executive,<ref>[http://www.govexec.com/ Government Executive]</ref> Federal Times,<ref>[http://www.federaltimes.com/ Federal Times]</ref> Federal Computer Week,<ref>[http://fcw.com/Home.aspx Federal Computer Week]</ref> and Government Computer News.<ref>[http://gcn.com/Home.aspx Government Computer News]</ref>
==See also== *[[Good Government Organizations (United States)]]
