{{Expand Ukrainian|Русифікація України|date=December 2009}}
[[File:Валуєвський циркуляр. Valuev Circular.jpg|thumb|The Valuev Circular, issued by the minister of internal affairs of the Russian Empire, stating that the Ukrainian language "never existed, doesn't exist, and cannot exist."]]
The '''Russification of Ukraine''' was a body of laws, decrees, and other actions undertaken by the Imperial Russian and later Soviet authorities to strengthen Russian national, political and linguistic positions in [[Ukraine]].
== History ==
=== Russian Empire === {{See also|Persecuted bandurists}}
In the opinion of scientist [[Vladimir Vernadsky]] (1863–1945), by the 17th century, Muscovy already had a long-standing policy to absorb Ukraine and liquidate the foundation for local cultural life.<ref name="Vernadskyy">[http://www.ukrcenter.com/library/read.asp?id=4617 Владимир Вернадский «Украинский вопрос и российская общественность»]</ref> In 1720 [[Tsar]] [[Peter I of Russia]] issued a decree in which he ordered the expurgation of all Ukrainian linguistic elements in theological literature printed in Ukrainian typographical establishments.<ref name="ReferenceA">Бандурка О. М. 350 років мого життя. Харків, 2001 р. "Его Императорскому Величеству известно учинилось, что в Киевской и Черниговской типографиях книги печатают несогласно с великороссийскими, но со многою противностью к Восточной Церкви…вновь книг никаких, кроме церковных крещенных изданий, не печатать. А церковныя старыя книги, для совершенного согласия с великороссийскими, с такими же церковными книгами справливать прежде печати с теми великоросскими дабы никакой разны и особаго наречия в оных не было… </ref> Later Empress [[Catherine II of Russia]] issued a secret order to Count Aleksandr Alekseyevich Vyazemsky (the Prosecutor General of the Russian Empire from 1764 to 1792) in which she instructed him to institute a program of Russification for the provinces of [[Ukraine]] ("malorossia"), [[Livonia]] and [[Finland]], "using light-handed methods".<ref>In Russian: "Малая Россия, Лифляндия, Финляндия суть провинции, которыя правятся конфирмованными им привилегиями, нарушать ония отрешением всех вдруг весьма непристойно б было… Сии провинции, также и Смоленскую, надлежит легчайшими способами привести к тому, чтобы они обрусели и перестали бы глядеть как волки в лесу." Лизанчук В. Навічно кайдани кували. Львів, 1995 р. С.57, 60).</ref> In 1862, all Ukrainian Sunday schools, numbering over 100 at the time, were abolished and proscribed. In 1863, minister of internal affairs [[Pyotr Valuyev]] issued the so-called [[Valuev Circular]], in which he stated that the Ukrainian language never existed, doesn't exist, and cannot exist.<ref>«нет, не было и быть не может».''[[Valuev Circular]]''.</ref> In 1876, tsar [[Alexander II of Russia]] issued the [[Ems Ukaz]], a secret decree banning the use of the [[Ukrainian language]] in print, with the exception of reprinting of old documents.
====Russian toponymy in Ukraine (Imperial period)==== Cities with the Russian suffix ''-hrad'' (grad) in their names have never existed in Ukraine prior to Russian rule.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Such cities were built or renamed after the annexation of Ukraine by the [[Russian Empire]] through the [[partitions of Poland]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} Instead, the corresponding suffix ''-horod'' is native to Ukrainian toponymic morphology, for example in [[Myrhorod]], [[Sharhorod]], [[Zvenyhorod]], [[Horodok (disambiguation)|Horodok]], [[Horodyshche]], [[Horodenka]] and others.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} * [[Novohrad-Volynskyi]] (initially known Zvyahel) * [[Kropyvnytskyi|Yelizavetghrad/Kirovohrad]] (initially known as St.Elizabeth Fortress) * [[Pavlohrad]] * [[Yekaterinoslav]] * Yekaterinoslav/[[Novomoskovsk, Ukraine|Novomoskovsk]] * [[Prymorsk]] * [[Zaporizhia|Aleksandrovsk]] * Belyovsk/Konstantingrad * [[Synelnykove]] * Lykhachove
===Soviet period=== {{see also|Ukrainization|Executed Renaissance}} After [[World War I]], [[Ukrainian culture]] was revived due to the Bolshevik policy of [[Korenization]] ("indigenisation"). While it was meant to bolster the power of the Party in local cadres, the policy was at odds with the concept of a Soviet people with a shared Russian heritage. Under Stalin, "korenization" took second stage to the idea of a united Soviet Union, where competing national cultures were no longer tolerated, and the Russian language increasingly became the only official language of Soviet socialism.<ref name="CalicNeutatz2011">{{cite book|author1=Marie-Janine Calic|author2=Dietmar Neutatz|author3=Julia Obertreis|title=The Crisis of Socialist Modernity: The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia in the 1970s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iPkEFdSDqqEC&pg=PA163|year=2011|publisher=Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht|isbn=978-3-525-31042-7|pages=163–4}}</ref>
The times of restructuring of farming and the introduction of industrialization brought about a wide campaign against "nationalist deviation," which in Ukraine translated into the end of "korenization" policy and an assault on the political and cultural elite. The first wave of purges between 1929 and 1934 targeted the revolutionary generation of the party that in Ukraine included many supporters of [[Ukrainization]]. Soviet authorities specifically targeted the commissar of education in Ukraine, [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], for promoting Ukrainian language reforms that were seen as dangerous and counterrevolutionary; Skrypnyk committed suicide in 1933. [[Great Purge|The next 1936–1938 wave of political purges]] eliminated much of the new political generation that replaced those who perished in the first wave. The purges nearly halved the membership of the Ukrainian communist party, and purged Ukrainian political leadership was largely replaced by the cadre sent from [[Russian SFSR|Russia]] that was also largely "rotated" by Stalin's purges.<ref name="Magocsi2010">{{cite book|author=Paul Robert Magocsi|title=History of Ukraine - 2nd, Revised Edition: The Land and Its Peoples|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z0mKRsElYNkC&pg=PT567|date=18 June 2010|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-9879-6|pages=496–7}}</ref>
Russification of Soviet-occupied Ukraine intensified in 1938 under [[Nikita Khrushchev]], then secretary of the Ukrainian Communist Party, but was briefly halted during [[World War II]], when [[Axis forces]] occupied large areas of the country. After the war ended, Western Ukraine was reabsorbed into the Soviet Union, and most prominent Ukrainian intellectuals living there were purged or exiled to Siberia. [[Leonid Brezhnev]] continued the Russification policies of Khrushchev in postwar Ukraine.<ref name="Braithwaite2002">{{cite book|author=Rodric Braithwaite|title=Across the Moscow River: The World Turned Upside Down|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TEb2MzrMPvgC&pg=PA168|year=2002|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-09496-1|page=168}}</ref>
[[File:Book on Russian proverbs and their Ukrainian counterparts.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A bilingual book printed in Kiev in 1969]] In the 1960s, the Ukrainian language began to be used more widely and frequently in spite of these policies. In response, Soviet authorities increased their focus on early education in Russian. After 1980, Russian language classes were instituted from the first grade onward.<ref name="Lewytzkyj1984">{{cite book|author=Borys Lewytzkyj|title=Politics and Society in Soviet Ukraine, 1953-1980|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VTnUONGOPiQC&pg=PA205|date=1 January 1984|publisher=CIUS Press|isbn=978-0-920862-33-9|page=205}}</ref> In 1990 [[Russian language|Russian]] became legally the official all-Union language of the [[Soviet Union]], with constituent republics having rights to declare their own official languages.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Nn3xDTiL0PQC&pg=PA1&dq=official+languages+Soviet+Union&client=firefox-a&cd=6#v=onepage&q=%22official%20language%22&f=false Language Policy in the Soviet Union] by [[L.A. Grenoble]]</ref><ref>[http://legal-ussr.narod.ru/data01/tex10935.htm ЗАКОН СССР ОТ 24.04.1990 О ЯЗЫКАХ НАРОДОВ СССР] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508201331/http://legal-ussr.narod.ru/data01/tex10935.htm |date=2016-05-08 }}</ref>
====Russian toponymy in Ukraine (Soviet period)==== The list includes Russian language names of settlements intentionally adopted in Ukrainian language instead of its Ukrainian correspondents. Ukrainian language names of settlements intentionally being recognized as self-invented and never existed before due to systematic erasing or silencing of local history. * [[Severodonetsk]] * [[Pervomaisk, Ukraine|Pervomaisk]] * [[Pervomaiskyi]] * [[Yuzhnoukrainsk]] * [[Yuzhne]] * [[Stalino]] (on Ukrainian maps of 1920s known as Staline) * [[Mariupol]] (on Ukrainian maps of 1920s known as Mariiupil) * [[Sevastopol]] (on Ukrainian maps of 1920s known as Sevastopil) * [[Simferopol]] (on Ukrainian maps of 1920s known as Simferopil) * [[Arbuzynka]] (initially known as Harbuzynka) * [[Chervonohrad]] (Krystynopil, rename into a hybrid of Ukrainian part Chervono and Russian part hrad) * [[Krasnohrad]] * [[Kirovohrad]] * [[Kuznetsovsk]] (originally known as Varash) * [[Podilsk|Kotovsk]] * [[Bakhmut|Artemivsk]] * [[Toretsk|Dzerzhynsk]] * [[Dniprodzerzhynsk]] * Ordzhonikidze * Illichivsk
=== Outcome ===
Russification policy was more intense in Ukraine than in other parts of the Soviet Union, and the country now contains the largest group of Russian speakers who are not ethnically Russian: as of 2009, there were about 5.5 million Ukrainians whose first language was Russian. Russian speakers are more prevalent in the southeastern half of the country, while both Ukrainian and Russian are used equally in the center, and Ukrainian dominates in the west.<ref name="Besters-Dilger2009">{{cite book|author=Juliane Besters-Dilger|title=Language Policy and Language Situation in Ukraine: Analysis and Recommendations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QeXZYdjB_H0C&pg=PA8|year=2009|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-3-631-58389-0|pages=7–8}}</ref> Some of these "russified Ukrainians" speak Russian, while others speak a mix of Ukrainian and Russian known as "[[surzhyk]]"; many do have some proficiency in Ukrainian. Estimates of their prevalence in the country vary, but according to different studies, "russified Ukrainians" comprise a third to a half of the total population of Ukraine.<ref name="Wanner2008">{{cite book|author=Catherine Wanner|title=Burden of Dreams: History and Identity in Post-Soviet Ukraine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oigSk-9SsnsC&pg=PA17|date=February 2008|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=978-0-271-03001-2|page=17}}</ref>
== In modern-day Ukraine ==
===Post-Independence (1991-2012) === [[File:Russians Ukraine 2001.PNG|thumb|Ethnic Russians by region (Census 2001)]] [[File:Ruslangsup2001.PNG|thumb|Inhabitants with Russian as mother tongue by region (Census 2001)]] In post-Soviet Ukraine, Ukrainian remains the only official language in the country; however, in 2012, President [[Victor Yanukovitch]] introduced a bill recognizing "regional languages", according to which, in particular, Russian could be used officially in the predominantly Russian-speaking areas of Ukraine, in schools, courts, and government institutions. While the bill was supported by Ukrainians in the eastern and southern [[Administrative divisions of Ukraine|regions]], the legislation triggered protests in [[Kiev]], where representatives from opposition parties argued that it would further divide the Ukrainian-speaking and Russian-speaking parts of the country and make Russian a ''de facto'' official language there.<ref name=guardian-elder>{{cite news|last=Elder|first=Miriam|title=Ukrainians protest against Russian language law|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/04/ukrainians-protest-russian-language-law|accessdate=11 November 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=4 July 2012}}</ref> On 28 February 2018 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] ruled this legislation unconstitutional.<ref name ="cKSU10ZZ117">[https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-polytics/2412584-constitutional-court-declares-unconstitutional-language-law-of-kivalovkolesnichenko.html Constitutional Court declares unconstitutional language law of Kivalov-Kolesnichenko], [[Ukrinform]] (28 February 2018)</ref>
Television and other media cater both languages.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4472069.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ukraine divided over language row | date=April 22, 2005 | accessdate=May 23, 2010}}</ref> In Ukraine there have been attempts to make Ukrainian the main language for the media and the press, see [[Ukrainization#Mass media/entertainment|Ukrainization: Mass media/entertainment]] for more details.

{{Infobox organization | image = File:Sahiyo-logo-2.jpg | alt = | caption = | map = | motto = United Against Female Genital Cutting | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = 2015<!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | extinction = <!-- {{End date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | type = <!-- [[Non-profit organization]] --> | status = | purpose = [[Human rights]] | headquarters = | coords = | languages = [[English Language|English]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = | remarks = | name = Sahiyo | former name = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = | merger = | location = [[Mumbai]], [[India]] | region_served = | membership = | general = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = }}
'''Sahiyo''' is a [[non-governmental organization]] founded in 2015 whose purpose is to advocate women rights and end the practice of [[female genital mutilation]], principally among the [[Dawoodi Bohra|Ddawoodi Bohra]] community in [[India]]<ref>[https://edition.cnn.com/2017/05/11/health/fgm-us-survivor-stories-trnd/index.html 3 US women share the horrors of female genital mutilation - [[CNN]]]</ref>. The organization lists its main concerns as females being victims of social norms and old traditions<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-india-genital-mutilation-20160612-snap-story.html A rebellion inside a small Indian sect seeks to end a brutal custom: female genital mutilation - [[Los Angeles Times]]]</ref>, working to eliminate these traditions through media, proper education, collaboration with other human rights organizations and social discussions. Sahiyo aims to empower victims and help them to spread their stories through public awareness campaigns and advocacy initiatives<ref> [https://www.cof.org/blogs/re-philanthropy/2016-12-06/ending-violence-against-girls-summit-fgmc-giving-innovative-leaders Ending violence against girls: The Summit on FGM/C: giving innovative leaders the resources they deserve - [[Council on Foundations]]]</ref>.
==History==
In early 2015, five women started the collective; Mariya Taher, Aarefa Johari, Priya Goswami, Insia Dariwala and Shaheeda Tavawalla-Kirtane, decided to take a step against female circumcision and create a collective<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320710505_REVIEW_OF_WOMEN%27S_STUDIES_Muslim_Women_and_the_Challenge_of_Religion_in_Contemporary_Mumbai Muslim Women and the Challenge of Religion in Contemporary Mumbai - Review of Women's Studies - [[ResearchGate]]]</ref>, they managed to partner with national and international [[NGOs]] such as German-Iraqi NGO Wadi, SpeakOut, Breakthrough and others. In July, Sahiyo launched an exploratory online survey to understand the motive, expanse and effect of female circumcision around the world, significant researchers participated in the survey including [[Gerry Mackie]]. In June, they partnered with Breakthrough to uncover the different connections of violence that are based on gender by highlighting the effects of orthodox ethics and customs that suppresses female sexuality in specific communities.
In August 2016, convened a media workshop in partnership with [[International Association of Women in Radio and Television|IAWRT]]<ref>[https://www.thebetterindia.com/77521/sahiyo-female-genital-circumcision/ No More Khatna: Meet the Five Women Standing against the Ritual of Female Circumcision in India] - The Better India</ref>. In September, Sahiyo collaborated with [[Inclusive Mosque Initiative]], they participated in the “Gender Justice” session at the [[Islamic Society of North America]] [[List of Islamic Society of North America conventions|Annual Conference]]. In October, Sahiyo participated in lecturing, discussing and collaborating over female genital mutilation challenges at Justice and Peace Commission in [[Mumbai]] which is run by [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bombay|Catholic Church in Mumbai]].
In January 2017, Sahiyo launched a worldwide online petition on [[Change.org]] appealing to [[United Nations]] and other establishments to invest in more research and support to push to end female genital mutilation in India and Asia and then to eliminate it globally, the petition was launched in collaboration with 33 non-governmental human rights organizations, including [[Equality Now]], [[Orchid Project]], [[Tahirih Justice Center|Tahirih Justice]].<ref>[http://www.dw.com/en/female-genital-mutilation-still-a-global-concern/a-37363059 Female genital mutilation still a 'global concern' - [[Deutsche Welle|DW]]]</ref>
==Approach==
‘Sahiyo’ is the [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] word for ‘friends’<ref>[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/dawoodi-bohra-female-genital-mutilation-case_us_5900c914e4b0026db1dd72a0 How Muslim Activists Are Working To End Female Genital Mutilation In The U.S. - [[Huffington Post]]]</ref>, which indicates the collective's mission to end female genital cutting through social discussions with the community in order to reach collaborative solutions towards ending the practice. Advocating its views against female genital cutting, Sahiyo uses online media to present stories of women who undergone mutilation to spread awareness of female circumcision, often drawing special attention to survivor stories<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/US/underground-american-woman-underwent-female-genital-mutilation-forward/story?id=39728421 UNDERGROUND: Risk of FGM Increasing for Women in the U.S., says CDC - [[ABC News]]]</ref>. Sahiyo started its first ''Thaal Pe Charcha'' (Discussions over food) in 2017, a meeting for Bohra women to discuss their life challenges concerning social norms and community fear of women sexuality, with an emphasis on female genital mutilation. In July, Sahiyo held the second Thaal Pe Charcha meeting in [[Mumbai]], the third meeting was convened in October, in which the organization received an invitation for speaking at Hilton Humanitarian Symposium in [[Los Angeles]] on their recent work and engagement with local and global communities<ref>[https://www.hiltonfoundation.org/humanitarian-prize/events/icddr-b 2017 Prize Event - [[Hilton Worldwide|Hilton]] Foundation]</ref>.
==Research==
Through its local research, Sahiyo found that 80% of Bohra woman had undergone [[clitoridectomy]] procedure.<ref>[https://www.equalitynow.org/sites/default/files/2016%20Violence%20Against%20Girls%20Summit%20on%20FGM_C%20report_web_cmprsd.pdf End Violence Against Girls - Summit on FGM/C. December 2, 2016. United States Institute of Peace - Washington, D.C. - [[Equality Now]]]</ref> Also it has released an [[Investigative Journalism|investigative report]] revealed publicly for that first time that female mutilation cutting was carrying out in several parts of coastal state [[Kerala]], including cities of [[Thiruvananthapuram]] and [[Kozhikode]]<ref>[https://www.figo.org/news/fgm-revealed-be-widespread-kerala-0015679 FGM revealed to be widespread in Kerala - [[International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics|International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO)]]]</ref>, the reporters and reserchers interviewed clinic doctors who agree on the illegal procedure and also encourage it, which caused controversial reactions among supporters and opposers in India<ref>[https://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/english/asianet+newsable-epaper-asnewsab/female+genital+mutilation+widespread+in+kerala+agents+available+online+report-newsid-72364178 Female genital mutilation widespread in Kerala, agents available online: report - [[Dailyhunt]]]</ref><ref>[http://mattersindia.com/2017/08/female-genital-mutilation-widespread-in-kerala/ Female genital mutilation widespread in Kerala] - Matters India</ref>. The global survey found that female genital cutting is not only present in some African and Asian countries, but happens also among these communities in [[developed countries]] such as the [[United States]]<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/ritarubin/2017/04/14/doctor-charged-with-female-genital-mutilation-has-published-research-overseen-residents/#5bc91dc06224 Doctor Charged With Female Genital Mutilation Has Published Research, Overseen Residents - [[Forbes]]]</ref>, [[United Kingdom]] and [[Canada]].<ref>[https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/785dx4/the-female-genital-mutilation-scandal-tearing-a-community-apart The Female Genital Mutilation Scandal Tearing a Community Apart - [[Vice Media|Vice.com]]]</ref>
==Campaigns==
In February 2016, Sahiyo partnered with NGO Speak Out to run ''Each One Reach One'', a one month campaign was launched to motivate different people to participate in social discussions with Bohra women. In the following year, they have launched the second edition of the campaign<ref>[https://www.hindustantimes.com/static/fgm-indias-dark-secret Shocking! 80% of Bohra women have been subjected to Female Genital Mutilation: Survey - [[Hindustan Times]]]</ref>. In March, they started ''I Am Bohra Photo'' campaign<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/two-dawoodi-bohra-docs-come-out-to-back-khatna/article18620180.ece Two Dawoodi Bohra docs come out to back khatna - [[The Hindu]]]</ref>, encouraging women and men of Bohra to post their photos with comments to condemn khatna activities<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2017/05/25/whether-its-a-nick-or-full-circumcision-female-genital-mutilation-is-about-control-paradkar.html Whether it’s a nick or full circumcision, female genital mutilation is about control: Paradkar - [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]]</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-fgm-men/men-join-campaigns-in-india-against-fgm-rituals-among-the-bohra-idUSKCN0WJ2BV Men join campaigns in India against FGM rituals among the Bohra - [[Reuters]]]</ref>.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{en-CA|date=June 2018}} [[File:Cows on a farm - by Eric Dufresne.jpg|thumb|[[Dairy cattle]] in a barn in [[Québec]]]] '''Supply management''' ({{Lang-fr|Gestion de l'offre}}) (SM) is a national agricultural policy framework used in Canada that coordinates supply and demand of dairy, poultry and eggs through production and import control and pricing mechanisms designed to prevent shortages and surpluses, to ensure farmers a fair rate of return and Canadian consumer access to a high-quality, stable, and secure supply of these sensitive products.
The supply management system was authorized by the 1972 ''Farm Products Agencies Act'', which established the two national agencies that oversee the system. Five national supply management organizations, the SM-5 Organizations — Egg Farmers of Canada (EFC), Turkey Farmers of Canada (TFC), Chicken Farmers of Canada (CFC), the Canadian Hatching Egg Producers (CHEP) and the Ottawa-based [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] (CDC), a [[Crown corporations of Canada|Crown corporation]] — in collaboration with provincial and national governing agencies, organizations and committees, administer the supply management system.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> The [[Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada]] federal department is responsible for both the Canadian Dairy Commission and its analogue for eggs, chicken and turkey products, the [[Farm Products Council of Canada]]. In the dairy industry, the supply management system implements the federated provincial policy through the CMSMC, CDC, three regional [[milk pool]]s — Newfoundland's, the five eastern province (P5) and four western provinces — and provincial milk marketing boards. Since 1970, the CMSMC has set the yearly national industrial raw milk [[production quota]] or Market Sharing Quota (MSQ) and the MSQ share for each province to ensure Canada to match production with domestic need and to remain self-sufficient in [[Butterfat|milk fat]]. Each province allocates MSQs to individual dairy farmers.
Supply management mechanisms such as import controls were recognized as a valid practice and protected under Article XI of the 1947 [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT). During the [[Uruguay round]] of negotiations (1986-1993), Article XI was lost and tariffs were introduced to protect Canada's domestic dairy. The Canadian dairy industry was not part of trade negotiations in 1994 when the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) came into effect. As a result of Canada's forced removal of some export subsidies with the establishment of the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) in 1995, the federal government and the CDC updated the pricing system to be more stringent, a system that remains in place in 2018. During the 2004 WTO [[Doha Development Round]] (DDA) trade negotiations in Geneva, that had begun in 2001, Canada's supply management system was under attack by almost all their trading partners for the first time.
Of the 193,492 farms in Canada in 2017,<ref name="foodandfarming_2017">{{cite web |url=http://www.foodandfarming.ca/census-of-agriculture/ |title=Decline in # of farms & operators, Rise in farm size & age, and more from the Census of Agriculture |date=August 3, 2017 |access-date=July 9, 2018}} 2016 Canadian Census of Agriculture</ref> 16,351, representing approximately 12 per cent, were under supply management. The controls provided by supply management have allowed the federal and provincial governments to avoid subsidizing the sectors directly, in contrast to general practice in the [[European Union]] and the [[United States]].<ref name="dairyfarmers_myths">{{cite web|title=Myths & Realities of Supply Management|publisher=Dairy Farmers of Canada (DFC)|url=https://www.dairyfarmers.ca/what-we-do/supply-management/myths-realities|access-date=June 12, 2018 |date=nd}}</ref>
Supply management's supporters say that the system offers stability for producers, processors, service providers and retailers.<ref name="SPAA_Larue_2012"/>{{rp|2}} Detractors have criticized tariff-rate import quotas, price-control and supply-control mechanisms used by provincial and national governing agencies, organizations and committees. The policy has been described as regressive and [[Protectionism|protectionist]] and costly with money transferred from consumers to producers through higher prices on milk, poultry and eggs which some label as a subsidy. Canada's trade partners posit that SM limits market access.<ref name="OECD_2008"/>{{rp|18}}<ref name="SPAA_Larue_2012"/>{{rp|2}}<ref name="OECD_2008"/>{{rp|18}}
While many federal and provincial politicians from major parties "have long maintained support for a supply-managed system for dairy, poultry and egg farmers,"<ref name="CBC_Payton_2012"/> there has been ongoing debate about SM.<ref name="Gambling_2016">{{cite thesis |last=Gambling |first=Samantha Jane |year=2016 |url=https://open.library.ubc.ca/cIRcle/collections/ubctheses/24/items/1.0228575 |title=Canadian supply management: a food sovereignty policy? British Columbia and New Zealand industry stakeholder” |work=MSc Thesis. Integrated Studies in Land and Food Systems Vancouver: University of British Columbia Library |access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref> A 2018 report based on government data and the 2017 Nielsen's Fresh Milk Price Report, showed that although it has always been claimed that Canadians pay higher dairy prices than other countries, the price of 1 litre of liquid milk in Canadian dollars in Canada was $1.50 compared to $1.57 in Australia it was $1.57, $1.61 in the USA a litre (of rBST -free milk), and $1.83 in New Zealand.<ref name="exportactionglobal_2018"/><ref name="realagriculture_Heppner_2018"/>
The [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) maintained in 2017 that Canada's "export growth would be boosted if Canada phased out its Canadian dairy supply management policies."<ref name="OECD_CA_SM_2017">{{cite report|url=https://www.oecd.org/eco/outlook/economic-forecast-summary-canada-oecd-economic-outlook-june-2017.pdf|title=Canada|date=June 2017|publisher=OECD|access-date=June 22, 2018|format=PDF|series=Developments in Individual OECD and Selected Non-member Economies}}</ref>
Supply management was one of many issues in [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement]] (CETA), a free-trade agreement between Canada, the [[European Union]] and its member states<ref name="EU_CETA_2017">{{cite web |url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2017/september/tradoc_156062.pdf |format=PDF |title=Guide to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership |pages=35 |date=July 2017 |isbn=978-92-79-68000-7 |doi=10.2781/647649}}</ref>{{rp|3}} and [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (CPTPP) negotiations and the [[United States Mexico Canada Agreement]] (USMCA).<ref name="timescolonist_Blanchfield_2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.timescolonist.com/trump-approves-of-new-continental-trade-deal-as-winners-and-losers-are-assessed-1.23447871 |title=Trump approves of new continental trade deal as winners and losers are assessed |first=Mike |last=Blanchfield |newspaper=Times Colonist via The Canadian Press |date=October 1, 2018 |access-date=October 1, 2018}}</ref> Under the October 1, 2018 United States Mexico Canada Agreement, the supply management system remained intact, Canada opened the domestic market by 3.6% and Class 7 was eliminated.
==Mandate== Canada's supply management system, which encompasses "five types of products: dairy, chicken and turkey products, table eggs, and broiler hatching eggs", "coordinates production and demand while controlling imports as a means of setting stable prices for both farmers and consumers."<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015">{{cite web |url=http://publications.gc.ca/collections/collection_2016/bdp-lop/eb/YM32-5-2015-138-eng.pdf |date=December 17, 2015 |title=Canada’s Supply Management System |first=Khamla |last=Heminthavong |series=Library of Parliament Research Publications|publisher=Economics, Resources and International Affairs Division |access-date=June 21, 2018 }}</ref>
In Canada, the dairy supply management system is administered by the federal government through the Ottawa-based [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] (CDC) a [[Crown corporations of Canada|Crown corporation]]. The [[Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada]] federal department is responsible for both the Canadian Dairy Commission and its analogue for eggs, chicken and turkey products, the [[Farm Products Council of Canada]].
==Supply-managed sectors==
In total, there are about 12,000 dairy farms,<ref name="dairyfarmers_2018_about">{{cite web |url=https://www.dairyfarmers.ca/who-we-are/about-us |title=About us |publisher=Dairy Farmers |date=nd |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> 2,800 chicken farmers,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chickenfarmers.ca/about-us/ |title=About us |work=Chicken Farmers of Canada |date=nd |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> 1,000 regulated egg farmers who produce table eggs and broiler hatching eggs,<ref name="About us">{{cite web |url=http://www.eggfarmers.ca/about-us/ |title=About us |work=Egg Farmers |date=nd |access-date=July 9, 2018 |quote="produce close to 732 million dozen eggs annually"}}</ref> and 551 turkey farmers,<ref>{{cite web |title=Canada's Turkey Industry |url=https://www.turkeyfarmersofcanada.ca/industry-information/industry-statistics/ |date= |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> that operate under supply management. According to the 2016 Canadian Census of Agriculture, there are 193,492 farms in Canada;<ref name="foodandfarming_2017"/> about 12 per cent of Canadian farms are under supply management.<ref name="About us"/>
==Regulatory framework==
There are five national organizations, known jointly as the SM-5 Organizations, that administer or support agricultural supply management systems.<ref name="CBC_MacKinnon">{{Cite news|first=Bobbi-Jean |last=MacKinnon |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/border-alcohol-supreme-court-intervene-new-brunswick-1.4291667|title=Tracadie man's beer case before Supreme Court overflows with potential interveners|work=CBC News|access-date=June 22, 2018|date=September 26, 2017|language=en}}</ref> According to a CBC article, "The SM-5 Organizations say federal-provincial agreements for each of the supply-managed sectors weave together the legislative jurisdiction of both levels of government to 'ensure a seamless regulatory scheme'... "designed to enable farmers to get a reasonable return while stabilizing the supply of agricultural products to Canadian consumers."<ref name="CBC_MacKinnon"/>
The supply management system was authorized in 1972 through the Farm Products Agencies Act and subsequently the national agencies that established the system were created.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> The Canadian Milk Supply Management Committee, which is chaired by CDC is "responsible for the administration of supply management for the dairy industry".<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> By 1983 all provinces except Newfoundland had signed the National Milk Marketing Plan (NMMP) which replaced the 1971 Interim Comprehensive Milk Marketing Plan.<ref name="WCDS_2017">{{cite conference |url=https://wcds.ualberta.ca/wp-content/uploads/sites/57/2018/05/Kennelly-2017-WCDS-Past-Present-and-Future.pdf |format=PDF |title=Canadian Dairy Industry, Past, Present and Future |first1=John J. |last1=Kennelly |first2=Mike |last2=Southwood |first3=Bruce |last3=Beattie |conference=Western Canadian Dairy Seminar (WCDS) |journal=WCDS Advances in Dairy Technology |date=2017 |volume=29 |pages=3-16 |location=Edmonton, Alberta}}</ref>{{rp|9}} The goal of the NMMP agreement was to manage the supply of raw industrial milk to meet Canadian needs, to establish provincial MSQs and to raise fees to remove surplus.<ref name="WCDS_2017"/>{{rp|9}}
In 1972, the national marketing agency to administer the supply management system for eggs, Egg Farmers of Canada (EFC), was established.<ref name="EFC_2018_SM">{{cite web |url=http://www.eggfarmers.ca/2018/01/roger-pelissero-in-the-hill-times-supply-management-protects-family-farming/ |title=Roger Pelissero in the Hill Times: "Supply management protects family farming" |date=January 19, 2018 |access-date=June 22, 2018 |work=Egg Farmers of Canada (EFC)}}</ref> In 1974 one was set up for turkey farmers, Turkey Farmers of Canada (TFC), and the chicken marketing agency, Chicken Farmers of Canada (CFC), was created in 1978,<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> and the Canadian Hatching Egg Producers (CHEP) agency was established in 1986.<ref>[http://fpcc-cpac.gc.ca/index.php/en-GB/thesupplymanagement/thenationalagencies National agencies]</ref>
The National Farm Products Marketing Council, now the [[Farm Products Council of Canada]], established by the 1972 Farm Products Agencies Act, oversees the national supply management system agencies for eggs, chicken, and turkey.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/>
The Farm Products Council of Canada "oversees the various agencies in an effort to promote an efficient and competitive agricultural sector while ensuring that the marketing system operates well, in the interests of producers and consumers."<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/>
In Ontario, for example, the 2017 Agricultural Products Marketing Act (FPMA) "allows the Minister of Agriculture and Food to enter into contracts with the federal government to have national marketing agencies perform marketing functions within Ontario on behalf of the Ontario government" through the Ontario Farm Products Marketing Commission.<ref name="omafra_2017">{{cite web |url=http://www.omafra.gov.on.ca/english/farmproducts/factsheets/2overview.htm |title=Overview of the Farm Products Marketing Act |publisher=Queen's printer for Ontario |date=May 2017 |access-date=July 18, 2018}}</ref>
===Milk supply-management===
The milk supply management system is a "federated provincial policy"<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/> with four governing agencies, organizations and committees—Canadian Dairy Commission, Canadian Milk Supply Management Committee (CMSMC), regional milk pools, and provincial milk marketing boards.<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2013">{{cite report|title=Canada’s Supply-Managed Dairy Policy: An Agenda for Reform |first1=Al |last1=Mussell |first2=Bob |last2=Seguin |first3=Janalee |last3=Sweetland |url=http://www.georgemorris.org/publications/Milk_SM_Recommendations_for_Reform_Mar-13_Final.pdf |format=PDF |date=March 5, 2013 |access-date=July 13, 2018 |publisher=George Morris Centre |pages=14}}</ref>{{rp|8}}
====Canadian Dairy Commission (CDC)==== {{main|Canadian Dairy Commission}} The Ottawa-based Canadian Dairy Commission (CDC) composed mostly of dairy farmers, was created in 1966. The federal government is involved in SM through the CDC in the administration of imports and exports.<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/> The CDC establishes "support prices for butter and skim milk powder (SMP) and operates surplus removals at the support prices, removing butterfat and SMP from the market for export or later sale. It also facilitates the process for the setting of [[Market Sharing Quota]] (MSQ) for industrial milk nationally."<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/> According to the CDC website, it operates as an agency supporting "farmers, processors and consumers." CDC, under CEO Serge Riendeau—a former farmer, dairy producer and Agropur Cooperative Director—also "manages programs that target the industry, upholds milk quality standards and supports Canadians working in the dairy industry".<ref name="Agropur_2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.agropur.com/en/nouvelles/serge-riendeau-pr%C3%A9sident-Agropur-de-2002-%C3%A0-2016-est-nomm%C3%A9-au-poste-de-chef-de-la-direction-de-la-Commission-canadienne-du-lait |publisher=AgroPur Cooperative |year=2017 |title=Serge Riendeau to head Canadian Dairy Commission |access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref> Riendeau is responsible for "cooperating and negotiating with dairy industry stakeholders to reconcile their interests and maintain compliance with the supply management system". Riendeau, who was a farmer and dairy producer before becoming President of Agropur Cooperative in 1992, advocates for the "supply management system" and "was instrumental in the establishment of a national strategy to promote the use of Canadian dairy ingredients."<ref name="Agropur_2017"/>
====The Canadian Milk Supply Management Committee (CMSMC)====
In 1970, the Canadian Milk Supply Management Committee (CMSMC), was established to set the national industrial milk Market Sharing Quota (MSQ) which is then allocated among the provinces.<ref name="LOP_Frechette_1986"/>{{rp|31}} The national MSQs "ensure that Canada is self-sufficient in [[Butterfat|milk fat]]."<ref name="LOP_Frechette_1986"/>{{rp|31}}
The CMSMC, which is chaired by the Ottawa-based [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] (CDC), administers SM for the dairy sector with the CDC performing a role of supervision, support and regulation.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/>
====Regional milk pools==== There are three regional [[milk pool]]s—Newfoundland's, the Eastern Canadian Milk Pooling P5 Agreement which includes Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Québec and Ontario and the Western Milk Pooling Agreement (WMP) which includes Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, that operate under the supervision of the CDC. They pool milk sale revenues, costs and markets, and harmonize pricing and establish daily quotas.<ref name="CDC_milk_pools">{{cite web |url=http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?id=3810 |title=Milk pools |work=CDC |date=nd |access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
Under GATT's Article XI supply management enjoyed an exemption. When Article XI was lost during the Uruguay round of negotiations (1986-1993), tariffs were introduced to protect Canada's domestic dairy. The loss of Article XI was one of the driving forces behind the formation of a milk pooling agreement. When the WTO replaced GATT in 1995, it was recognized by Canada's Dairy Industry Advisory Committee that expanded regional milk pools would be needed to adapt to changes.<ref name="WCDS_2017"/>{{rp|10}}
====Provincial marketing boards==== Dairy producers must hold a quota or permit to sell their products to a processing plant.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> These quotas, or Market Sharing Quota (MSQ), avoid overproduction.<ref name="ontariodairies"/> In the SM system, provincial marketing boards, allocate [[production quota]]s or MSQs on milk for example, based on regional milk pools recommendations which include daily milk quotas.<ref name="CDC_milk_pools"/><ref name="CDC_MSQ"/>
The provincial milk marketing boards are responsible for most of the regulation of milk marketing, organization of dairy producers, quota administration and transfers, and producer-processor settlement. Individual provinces regulate their own marketing systems with marketing boards that may engage in product promotion, collective sales, and price negotiation. Marketing boards have regulatory control over the feeding, treatment, and conditions of animals on farms, as the board is in direct control of the quota allotted and can directly sanction farms who violate board policy.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} In Ontario the FPMA authorizes the province to control and regulate the production and marketing of Ontario farm products [except dairy products] including their prohibition.<ref name="omafra_2017"/> The [[Dairy Farmers of Ontario]] regulate the dairy marketing system.<ref name="omafra_2017"/>
During the 2015 TPP negotiations, as the United States, New Zealand and Australia called for an end to SM, the role of the provincial marketing boards was challenged. By October 2015, however, it was agreed that in exchange for an opening the market to other countries, marketing boards could continue to perform their decision-making role in production quotas and farm gate prices.<ref name="CBC_McGregor_2015_TPP"/>
==Background==
A 2001 "NAFTA - Report Card on Agriculture", traces the history of trade disputes to the 1930s. After the United States enacted the [[Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act]] in 1930, US tariffs rose to record levels. This devastated the Canadian economy and resulted in implementation of protectionism at a global level.<ref name="Crane_Historica_2009">{{cite encyclopedia |last=Crane |first= David |year=2009–2015 |title=Canada–US Economic Relations: Economic relations between Canada and the US are of paramount importance to Canada |work= Historica Canada }}</ref> By 1932, Canadian exports dropped from $515 million to $235 million.<ref name="Crane_Historica_2009"/> Canada, the United States, and many other countries erected "high and discriminatory barriers" in the pursuit of "beggar-thy-neighbor" policies.<ref name="AG_Econ_Cox_2001">Cox, Tom L., Le Roy, Danny G., Goddard, and Ellen W. (2001). [http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/16847/1/ag010253.pdf “Dairy Disputes in North America: a Case Study].” NAFTA – Report Card on Agriculture. AgCon Research in Agricultural & Applied Economics.</ref>{{rp|254}} The signing of the first liberal trade agreement, the 1936 Canada–US agreement, by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] and Prime Minister [[William Lyon Mackenzie King|Mackenzie King]] represented the start of an economic relationship between the two countries that resulted in the steady decline of trade barriers such as tariffs.<ref name="Crane_Historica_2009"/><ref name="bloomberg_Mihm_2018">{{cite web |last=Mihm |first=Stephen |date=June 14, 2018 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-06-14/trade-war-history-is-not-on-justin-trudeau-s-side |title=Trade War History is not on Justin Trudeau’s Side: Tariffs could batter the U.S. economy, embolden Canadian nationalists and enrich China |work=Bloomberg |access-date=July 10, 2018}}</ref>
During the economic crisis of the 1930s, Canadian Dairy Farmers’ Federation (now the [[Dairy Farmers of Canada]]), the Saint-Hubert, Québec-based [[Agropur| Agropur Cooperative]], along with hundreds of other dairy cooperatives in Québec [[History of cooperatives in Canada|at that time]], were established.<ref>Content from the Wikipedia [[Agropur]] article. June 21, 2018.</ref>
By 1942, the [[Dairy Farmers of Canada]] (DFC)'s mandate was to stabilize the dairy market and increase revenues for dairy farmers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dairyfarmers.ca/who-we-are/our-history|title=Our History|publisher=[[Dairy Farmers of Canada]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref>
Post-WWII, following the collapse of world trade, negotiators of multilateral trade agreements, including advocates of free trade and protectionism, carved out the [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT), first signed by 23 countries in 1947. Through GATT markets were freer and less discriminatory, market competition became global, benefiting all signatories.<ref name="AG_Econ_Cox_2001"/>
Supply management in its current form dates from Federal legislation passed in December 1971 under the [[Pierre Trudeau|Pierre Elliot Trudeau]] government. Trudeau had expressed support for the system since 1949 when he was as an assistant to [[Robert Gordon Robertson]].<ref name="Geddes_2017" group="Macleans">{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/a-novice-bureaucrat-and-future-pm-on-supply-management/|title=A novice bureaucrat (and future PM) on supply management|work=Maclean's|date=November 15, 2017|language=en-CA |first=John |last=Geddes |access-date=June 26, 2018 }}</ref>
Through the 1958 federal Agricultural Stabilization Act (ASA), an agricultural commodity could be designated by the ASA for direct deficiency payments if the price dropped 80% below the price averaged over the preceding decade. This was the first act of its kind in Canada and a majority of ASA cash subsidies to farmers went to the dairy industry for industrial milk—milk used in making cheese, milk powder and butter.<ref name="CAES_Hedley_2015">{{cite web |url=https://caes.usask.ca/meetings/the-evolution-of-agricultural-support-policy-in-canada.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Evolution of Agricultural Support Policy in Canada |series=CAES Fellows Paper |year=2015 |number=2015-1 |first=Douglas D. |last=Hedley |pages=38 |access-date=July 18, 2018}}</ref>{{rp|13}}
In the 1950s and 1960s there was volatility in dairy prices, dairy producers had more bargaining power relative to dairy farmers, and the [[United Kingdom]] was poised to enter the [[European Common Market]], resulting in the loss of Canada's largest dairy export customer.<ref name="CDC_quality_2010"/> As low milk prices continued into the 1960s, the Canadian Dairy Commission Act was passed in 1967, establishing the [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] (CDC).<ref name="CAES_Hedley_2015"/>{{rp|13}} The CDC's mandate was to ensure producers received a fair return on investment, and to ensure the quality and supply of milk.<ref name="CDC_quality_2010"/>
The Canadian Milk Supply Management Committee (CMSMC) was first introduced in 1970 as the body responsible for setting the national Market Sharing Quota (MSQ).<ref name="LOP_Frechette_1986">{{cite web |url=https://lop.parl.ca/Content/LOP/ResearchPublicationsArchive/bp1000/bp154-e.pdf|format=PDF|title=National Dairy Policy |series=Backgrounder|date=October 14, 1986|number=BP-154E |first1=Frechette |last1=Jean-Denis|first2=Sally |last2=Rutherford|publisher=Research Branch Library of Parliament|pages=39 |access-date=July 18, 2018}}</ref>{{rp|31}} By 1974 every province except [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] had signed on. The dairy industry was the first in Canada to be operated through the national supply management system.<ref name="CDC_supply_management">{{cite web |url=http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?link=114 |title=Supply management |work=CDC |date=nd |access-date=August 17, 2018}}</ref> Following dairy, a national supply management system was implemented for eggs in 1972, [[turkey meat|turkey]] in 1974, [[chicken as food|chicken]] in 1978 and chicken hatching eggs in 1986.<ref name="MHF" /> The national agencies for eggs,<ref name="EFC_2018_SM"/> turkeys,<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> and chickens<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> were also established in the 1970s.
When the [[European Economic Community]] (EEC) adopted Canada's model in introducing its own quotas in April 1984, they were motivated by a milk supply surplus. In Canada, where there was no milk surplus in the 1970s—the MSQs were designed to "guarantee a fair level of return for producers and to promote a stable supply of high-quality dairy products for consumers."<ref name="LOP_Frechette_1986"/>{{rp|31}}
Under the 1947 [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT), "imposing import controls on commodities subject to supply management [was] a valid and recognized practice. Such controls prevent[ed] the displacement of significant quantities of Canadian dairy products on the Canadian market, and thus protect[ed] [Canadian] producers against losses incurred through having to export all production in excess of domestic demand.<ref name="LOP_Frechette_1986"/>
In 1981, American economist [[Thomas Borcherding]] published his 117-page report entitled "The Egg Marketing Board" for the [[Fraser Institute]] in which he used the phrase, the "egg marketing cartel".<ref name="fraserinstitute_Borcherding_1981">{{cite report |url=https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/egg-marketing-board.pdf |format=PDF |first1=Thomas |last1=Borcherding |first2=Gary W. |last2=Dorosh|work=[[Fraser Institute]] |date=1981 |title=The Egg Marketing Board |access-date=September 15, 2018 |pages=117 |isbn=9780889750197 |series=Agricultural economics}}</ref>{{rp|xi}} In the same year, based on his report, he also wrote several 1981 articles and editorials in ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' about the artificially high-prices of eggs in Canada allegedly caused by a supply management mechanism, egg marketing boards, which Borcherding called an "egg marketing cartel".<ref>{{cite news| last =Cox| first =Kevin| title =Be glad to pay farmers fair price for eggs, CEMA tells Canadians,| work =The Globe and Mail | date =Jul 21, 1981}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Cox| first =Kevin| title =Artificially high egg prices linked to marketing| work =The Globe and Mail | date =Jul 16, 1981}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =The unkindest crack| work =The Globe and Mail| date =Jul 22, 1981}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =How to scramble eggs| work =The Globe and Mail | date =Sep 8, 1981}}</ref> According to [[Simon Fraser University]] professor ''emeritus'', [[Donald Gutstein]]<ref name="SFU_profile">{{cite web |url=https://sfu.academia.edu/DonaldGutstein |work=Simon Fraser University |date=nd |access-date=September 15, 2018 |title=Donald Gutstein}}</ref> in his 2014 publication ''[[Harperism: How Stephen Harper and his think tank colleagues have transformed Canada|Harperism]]'', this marked the beginning of an aggressive campaign by the Fraser Institute and other [[think tanks]], that he described as [[neo-liberal]], to eliminate supply management in the ensuing decades.<ref name="Lorimer_Gutstein_Harperism_2014">{{cite book |title=Harperism: How Stephen Harper and his think tank colleagues have transformed Canada |publisher=James Lorimer & Company |location=[[Toronto]], Ontario |isbn=9781459406636 |pages=288}}</ref>{{rp|39-44}}<ref group="Notes">In ''[[Harperism: How Stephen Harper and his think tank colleagues have transformed Canada|Harperism]]'' (2014), Gutstein groups think tanks, such as the [[Fraser Institute]], [[C.D. Howe]], [[Atlantic Institute for Market Studies]] (AIMS), the [[Montreal Economic Institute]] (MEI), [[Frontier Centre for Public Policy]], and the [[School of Public Policy, University of Calgary]] as a pro-economic freedom, neo-liberal think tanks who focus on eliminating supply management because they say it is [[Market distortion|market distorting]].</ref>
The historic Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement (CUSFTA) came into force on January 1, 1989.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.international.gc.ca/trade-commerce/trade-agreements-accords-commerciaux/agr-acc/united_states-etats_unis/fta-ale/background-contexte.aspx?lang=eng |title=Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement (CUSTFA) |date=nd |access-date=January 19, 2018 |publisher=Government of Canada}}</ref> CUSTFA, which built on GATT rights and obligations,<ref name="CUSTFA_1989"/>{{rp|5}} was the largest trade agreement concluded between two countries up to that time.<ref name="CUSTFA_1989">{{cite web |url=http://www.international.gc.ca/trade-commerce/assets/pdfs/agreements-accords/cusfta-e.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=July 19, 2018 |date=January 1, 1989 |pages=315 |title=Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement (CUSTFA)}}</ref>{{rp|xi}}
When the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) came into force on January 1, 1994, the Canadian dairy system was not part of negotiations.<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2018"/>
Following the establishment of the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) in 1995, when Canada was forced to remove some of its export subsidies, dairy farmers underwent a major consolidation. The federal government and the CDC created the a new more stringent pricing system which was still in place in 2018.<ref name="financialpost_Snyder_2017">{{Cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/commodities/agriculture/cheese-ninjas-to-the-rescue-why-canadas-supply-management-system-needs-reform|title=‘Cheese ninjas’ to the rescue: Why Canada’s supply management system needs reform|date=December 20, 2017|work=Financial Post|access-date=July 22, 2018|language=en-CA |first=Jesse |last=Snyder}}</ref> The four sectors in 1995 were grains and oilseeds with 90,000 farmers, beef and hog farmers with 75,000 farmers, supply-managed dairy, poultry and egg sectors with 30,000 farmers, and horticulture with 9000 farmers.<ref name="Barichello_1995">{{cite conference |title=Overview of Canadian Agricultural Policy Systems |url=https://ideas.repec.org/p/ags/ffaf95/16747.html|citeseerx=10.1.1.564.3042 |first=Richard R. |last=Barichello |year=1995 |number=16747 |conference=Understanding Canada\United States Grain Disputes; Proceedings of the 1st Canada\U.S. Agricultural and Food Policy Systems Information Workshop |publisher=Farm Foundation, Agricultural and Food Policy Systems Information Workshops |access-date=June 28, 2018 |pages=37–}}</ref>{{rp|56}}
Canada participated in the WTO [[Doha Development Round]] (DDA) of trade-negotiations that began in 2001 with the objective of facilitating global trade by lowering [[trade barrier]]s. By 2004, whereas previously, Canada's supply management system had some support from other countries, in Geneva, the system was under attack. "In terms of supply management, and in the case of the Wheat Board...we were under attack. It was one against 146. We had absolutely no allies at the negotiating table."<ref name="CDHowe_Hart_WineCheese_2005">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdhowe.org/sites/default/files/attachments/research_papers/mixed/backgrounder_90.pdf|title=Great Wine, Better Cheese: How Canada Can Escape the trap of Agricultural Supply Management|last=Hart|first=Michael|year=2005|series=Backgrounder|publisher=C.D. Howe|location=Toronto|pages=10|format=PDF|access-date=June 26, 2018|number=90}}</ref>{{rp|6}}
A WTO panel ruled in 2002 that Canada "breached its trade obligations through its dairy support, siding with the United States. The result of the WTO ruling is that Canada is not allowed to export much dairy."<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2018">{{cite news |last=Nickel |first=Rod |date=June 8, 2018 |access-date=June 26, 2018 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-canada-dairy-explainer/explainer-trump-sours-on-canadas-sheltered-dairy-system-idUSKCN1J42PL |title=Explainer: Trump sours on Canada's sheltered dairy system |work=Reuters |quote="the United States shipped nearly C$600 million worth of dairy north in 2016, five times greater than Canadian sales to the United States...Farm dairy sales amount to around C$6 billion ($4.6 billion) annually. Processed dairy shipments are worth C$15 billion, according to 2016 government figures."}}</ref><ref name="reuters_Nickel_2017">{{Cite news|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCAKBN17L0KY-OCATP|title=Canada's resilient dairy sector girds for Trump fight|last=Weir|first=Benjamin|date=April 19, 2017|work=Reuters|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref>
In 2005, "MPs voted unanimously in favour of a motion reiterating" their support for supply management. All the parties say it "necessary so farmers can earn a decent living." Liberals published a press release to tell Conservatives that they "must protect supply management." "Canadian politicians have long maintained support for a supply-managed system for dairy, poultry and egg farmers."<ref name="CBC_Payton_2012"/> I
In December 2006, in an interview with the ''Western Producer'', Trade Minister [[David Emerson]] under Conservative Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] predicted that the SM would limit Canada's trading ability and in the end Canada would lose in trade negotiations. In March 2007, Emerson walked back his statement, and reiterated the Harper administration's support for supply management.<ref name="theglobeandmail_opinion_2017">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/supply-management-is-as-bad-as-emerson-said/article1325739|title=Supply management is as bad as Emerson said|date= March 8, 2007|access-date=July 12, 2018 |series=Opinion |work=Globe and Mail}}</ref>
In the 2008 OECD policy brief, "Economic survey of Canada 2008: Modernising Canada's agricultural policies", was highly critical of supply managed sectors especially dairy farming.<ref name="OECD_2008"/>{{rp|18}}
A November 2009 report by the Standing Committee on International Trade (CIIT), in preparation for TPP talks, recommended that "the Government of Canada affirm its unequivocal support of, and commitment to defend, Canada's supply management system."<ref name="CIIT_Richardson_2009">{{cite report |title=Defending Supply Management at the WTO |series=Report of the Standing Committee on International Trade |author=Standing Committee on International Trade (CIIT)|editor-first=Lee |editor-last=Richardson |date=September 17, 2009 |edition=6 |pages=8|access-date=June 25, 2018 |publisher=40th Parliament, 2nd Session |url=https://www.ourcommons.ca/Content/Committee/402/CIIT/Reports/RP4206172/402_CIIT_Rpt06/402_CIIT_Rpt06-e.pdf |format=PDF |location=Ottawa, ON}}</ref> The House of Commons "unanimously passed a resolution instructing Canadian negotiators to defend supply management".<ref name="theglobeandmail_Simpson_2010"/> This "unanimous support for supply management among Canada’s main political parties" was explained in part by the fact that supply-managed sectors employed 232,000 across Canada and contributed "over $13 billion to GDP annually.<ref name="Drache_Trew_2010">{{citation|last1=Drache|first1=Daniel|title=Pitfalls and Promises of the Canada-European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|date=June 24, 2010|url=http://www.yorku.ca/drache/academic/papers/pitfallsandpromises.pdf|pages=33|format=PDF|access-date=June 25, 2018|last2=Trew|first2=Stuart}}</ref>{{rp|13}}
In April 2010, the ''Globe and Mail'' reported that Canada was denied a seat at the TPP negotiating table because New Zealand opposed Canada's "official position in support of supply managed poultry, egg and dairy sectors."<ref name="theglobeandmail_Simpson_2010">{{cite news |last=Simpson |first=Jeffrey |title=Canada’s a double-dealer in world trade |newspaper=Globe and Mail |date=April 21, 2010 |access-date=June 25, 2018 |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/canadas-a-double-dealer-in-world-trade/article4315677/}}{{Subscription required}}</ref><ref name="Drache_Trew_2010"/>{{rp|13}} In 2010, it was expected that in the TPP negotiations, agriculture would be the "game-changer affecting hundreds of thousands of farmers particularly in Canada, particularly in the supply-managed sectors."<ref name="Drache_Trew_2010"/>{{rp|12}}
Against the backdrop of the TPP talks, a series of articles were published that were "highly critical of milk supply management" and supporters of supply management responded with counter-arguments.<ref name="cirano_Doyon_2011">{{cite report |last=Doyon |first=Maurice |date=October 2011 |url=http://www.cirano.qc.ca/pdf/publication/2011DT-01.pdf |format=PDF |title=Canada's Dairy Supply Management: Comprehensive Review and Outlook for the Future |access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref>{{rp|12}}<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2010">{{cite report |last=Mussell |first=Al |year=2010 |title=Making Sense out of a Stale Debate: Milk Supply Management in Canada |publisher=George Morris Centre|url=http://www.georgemorris.org/publications/Supply_Management_112210.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> David E. Bond, the retired chief economist of [[HSBC Bank Canada]], published an opinion piece in the ''Globe and Mail''<ref name="theglobeandmail_Bond_2010">{{cite news |last=Bond |first=David E. |date=October 21, 2010 |access-date=June 22, 2018 |title=How dairy farmers milk Canada's taxpayers |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/economy/economy-lab/how-dairy-farmers-milk-canadas-taxpayers/article4399488/}}{{Subscription required}}</ref><ref group="Notes">Bond wrote that, "The federal government imposes tariffs that run between 200 per cent and 300 per cent on virtually all dairy imports, even from those nations with which we have free-trade agreements." He concluded that, "It is the largest agricultural subsidy given to Québec, and therefore politically untouchable." The highest tariff Bond cited, 300% TRQ on butter, is actually never applied as Canada does not import butter above the TRQ threshold.</ref> stating that the "government sanctioned" National Dairy Policy resulted in a "wealth transfer of more than $2.4-billion annually from consumers and food processors to dairy farmers. That's more than $175,000 for each dairy farmer."<ref name="theglobeandmail_Bond_2010"/> Ed Mussell of the [[George Morris Centre]]<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2010"/> and Maurice Doyon, a professor in the Department of Agricultural Economics and Consumer Science at Laval University<ref name="cirano_Doyon_2011"/> described the series of articles and their counter-arguments from supporters of supply management, as "a great deal of rhetoric, simplistic arguments and invalid and untested assumptions".<ref name="cirano_Doyon_2011"/>{{rp|12}}
[[Sylvain Charlebois]] from [[Dalhousie University]], a well-known critic of supply management, has argued since 1998 that the system needs to be reformed.<ref name="Producer_Briere_2007">{{cite news |url=https://www.producer.com/2007/10/outside-forces-threaten-supply-management-critic |title=Outside forces threaten supply management: critic |first=Karen |last=Briere |publisher=The Western Producer |date=October 11, 2007 |access-date=September 30, 2018 }}</ref> He has published numerous studies on the issue, suggesting the system would need to make sectors more competitive, and open to international trades.<ref name="BritishFood_Charlebois_2007">{{cite journal |last1=Tamilia |first1=Robert D. |last2=Charlebois |first2=Sylvain |date=2007 |title=The importance of marketing boards in Canada: a twenty-first century perspective |journal=British Food Journal |volume= 109 |number=2 |pages=119-144 |doi=10.1108/00070700710725491 |url=https://www.canadianpoultrymag.com/images/stories/george_morris_report.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-commentary/the-many-failings-of-canadas-supply-management-system-are-governments-fault-not-farmers/article34793275/ |title=The many failings of Canada’s supply-management system are government’s fault, not farmers’|first=Sylvain |last=Charlebois |work=The Globe and Mail |date=April 23, 2017}}</ref> However, in an August 2018 CBC interview, Charlebois cautioned that it would be "too dangerous" to abolish the SM system now: Canadian farms are not competitive. As well, the multibillion-dollar quotas held by thousands of individual farmers, have been used as collateral to take out government loans and invest in farm improvements. He called for a debate on an SM phase out instead.<ref name="globalnews_Elliott_2018">{{cite news |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4404306/conservative-supply-management-dairy/ |work=Global |date=August 23, 2018 |title=Phase out supply management? Tories’ debate a ‘healthy exercise,’ expert says |first=Josh K. |last=Elliott}}</ref>
[[Martha Hall Findlay]] ran for the [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 2013|Liberal Party leadership of the Liberal Party in the 2013 race]], on a "mostly one-issue campaign", abolishing supply management. According to the ''[[Washington Post]]'', "her taboo-breaking crusade inspired a deluge of favorable editorials that helped make supply management — the Canadian jargon for dairy protectionism — a household phrase."<ref name="WaPo_McCullough_2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/global-opinions/wp/2018/06/11/why-trudeau-doesnt-have-the-high-ground-on-trade/?utm_term=.edd031222b7f |title=Why Trudeau doesn’t have the high ground on trade In his 2014 paper published by [[Centre for International Governance Innovation]] (CIGI), [[University of Waterloo]] by researcher [[Bruce Muirhead]] and cited in the Library of Parliament, "supply management benefits all Canadians." Muirhead wrote, "To lose it, however, would be a tragedy — it has served dairy farmers, consumers and processors well over the years, providing cost-effective, safe and secure dairy products in a world where those realities are increasingly difficult to guarantee".<ref name="CIGI_Muirhead_2014"/>{{rp|15}}<ref name="CIGI_Muirhead_2014">{{cite web |url=https://www.cigionline.org/sites/default/files/cigi_paper_30.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Centre for International Governance Innovation (CIGI) |date=April 15, 2014 |access-date=August 17, 2018 |title=Crying over Spilt Milk: The History of Dairy Supply Management and Its Role in Recent Trade Negotiations}}</ref><ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/>
In March 2015 [[University of Manitoba]] professors Professors Ryan Cardwell, Chad Lawley, along with then-PhD student, Di Xiang, published an article in the ''[[Canadian Public Policy]]'' (CPP) journal entitled "Milked and Feathered: The Regressive Welfare Effects of Canada’s Supply Management".<ref name="CPP_Cardwell_2015">{{cite journal |title=Milked and Feathered: The Regressive Welfare |newspaper=University of Manitoba News Today}}</ref>
By October 2015, as part of its commitment under the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), Canada, under the Harper administration, had agreed to cut back both dairy tariffs and import quotas.<ref name="brookings_Noll_2018_dairytariffs">{{cite news |url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2018/06/13/a-trumped-up-charge-against-canadian-dairy-tariffs |title=A Trumped-up charge against Canadian dairy tariffs |first1=Roger |last1=Noll |first2=Robert E. |last2=Litan |date=June 13, 2018|access-date=July 11, 2018 |work= [[Brookings Institution]]}}</ref><ref group="Notes">Thus, the only reason import restrictions on dairy products are even an issue is because the U.S. withdrew from the TPP.</ref> In return Canada kept its SM policies in place with provincial marketing boards still deciding the farm gate price of milk and production quotas, but with some adjustments for opening up the Canadian dairy market by 3.25%. The U.S. had asked for 10%.<ref name="CBC_McGregor_2015_TPP">{{cite news |title=Trans-Pacific Partnership offers dairy sector good news, bad news and a question mark: The deal marks a nudge toward competitive change, but more uncertainty than the dairy sector is used to |first=Janyce |last=McGregor |work=CBC News |date=October 5, 2015 |access-date=July 11, 2018 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canada-election-2015-tpp-dairy-analysis-1.3257280}}</ref> When the U.S. under the Trump administration withdrew from TPP on January 24, 2017,<ref name="bbc.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38721056 |title=Trump executive order pulls out of TPP trade deal |date=January 24, 2017 |access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref> the tariff-rate quotas (TRQ) on dairy products remained in effect. No U.S. exports ever pay the 200 to over 300% TRQs because US dairy products are never imported to Canada outside the TRQ.<ref name="brookings_Noll_2018_dairytariffs"/>
In April 2017, President Trump, while visiting Wisconsin, said he would "stand up for our dairy farmers" against Canada's "unfair” practices" without specifying which "parts of Canada’s tariff-protected dairy sector he wanted to change, nor what measures [Trump] would take to make it happen". As a result, Australia and New Zealand "re-ignited" their calls for a "fresh complaint to the [[World Trade Organization|world trade organization]].<ref name="Reuters_Nickel_Weir_2017">{{Cite news|url=https://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCAKBN17L0KY-OCATP|title=Canada's resilient dairy sector girds for Trump fightand |first2=Benjamin|last2=Weir|first1=Rod |last1=Nickel |work=Reuters |date=April 19, 2017|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA |location=Winnipeg/Sydney }}</ref> It evolved into the end of such surplus sales and called for the dismantling of the supply-management system within 10 years, or, at least concessions, to allow greater market access for their country’s products.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
Following his June 3, 2018 interview on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Meet the Press]]'' with Chuck Todd, in which Prime Minister Trudeau clarified Canada's position on newly imposed tariffs, the Dairy Farmers of Canada (DFC) wrote Trudeau to advise against concluding an agreement that would "negatively impact the dairy farming community."<ref name="hilltimes_Lim_Trudeau_2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hilltimes.com/2018/06/04/dairy-farmers-calls-trudeaus-nbcs-meet-press-comments-nafta-talks-deeply-troubling/146478|title=Dairy farmers call Trudeau’s NBC's Meet the Press comments on dairy in NAFTA talks ‘deeply troubling’|work=The Hill Times|access-date=July 22, 2018|language=en-CA |first=Jolson |last=Lim |date=June 4, 2018}}</ref> Trudeau has mentioned that the US "want a better deal on their auto sector from Mexico, and I think they want more access on certain agriculture products like dairy to Canada. On June 13, against the backdrop of NAFTA re-negotiations, [[Andrew Scheer]], the leader of the opposition—the [[Conservative Party of Canada]]—removed [[Maxime Bernier]], [[Member of Parliament|MP]] of the [[Beauce (electoral district)|Beauce]], from his shadow cabinet, allegedly for his party disloyalty for his April 2018 online publication of a chapter from his postponed book ''Doing Politics Differently: My Vision for Canada''.
