In a June 15, 2018 press statement, U.S. Agriculture Secretary [[Sonny Perdue]] at [[Lawrence MacAulay]]'s family farm, Perdue said that he was not attempting to convince Canada to abolish the SM system. He said, "We all have our interests and Canada has an embedded supply management system in their dairy industry, and it's not our desire to do away with that, just to regulate it in a way that does not depress world prices."<ref name="CTV_Bundale_2018_Perdue">{{cite news |title=U.S. not trying to get Canada to end supply management: agriculture secretary |work=CTV News |url=https://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/u-s-not-trying-to-get-canada-to-end-supply-management-agriculture-secretary-1.3974682 |first=Brett |last=Bundale|date=June 15, 2018 |access-date=July 13, 2018}}via The Canadian Press</ref> Back in Wisconsin, Perdue clarified that while the U.S. should not request that Canada eliminate SM, it would be difficult to reach a NAFTA agreement with Class 7 in place.<ref name="Wisfarmer_Laca_2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wisfarmer.com/story/news/2018/07/02/perdue-canada-can-keep-supply-management-not-class-7/753000002/|title=Perdue: Canada can keep supply management, not Class 7|work=Wisconsin State Farmer|access-date=July 13, 2018 |date=July 2, 2018|language=en |first=Anna-Lisa |last=Laca}}</ref>
By July 2018, with Canada and the U.S. "locked in an unprecedented, cross-border trade fight", President Trump said that he would not commit to any new NAFTA agreement until after the November 2018 [[United States elections, 2018|congressional midterm elections]].<ref name="nationalobserver_Blatchford_NAFTA_2018">{{cite news |title=Canada seeks intensive NAFTA talks, even if Trump's in no rush to sign |first=Andy |last=Blatchford |date=July 4, 2018 |access-date=July 22, 2018 |url=https://www.nationalobserver.com/2018/07/04/news/canada-seeks-intensive-nafta-talks-even-if-trumps-no-rush-sign |work=National Observer}}</ref> Trump "has frequently attacked Canadian trade barriers on agriculture — dairy products in particular — as unfairly hurting American farmers...Trudeau has insisted the U.S. president's complaints about Canada's trade barriers are the result of Canada's refusal to give in to Trump's demands to do away with the country's supply-management system, which is designed to protect dairy, poultry and egg producers."<ref name="nationalobserver_Blatchford_NAFTA_2018"/> However, a "vocal contingent" of American dairy farmers support the Canadian supply and management system.<ref name="thestar_Panetta_2017_Divided">{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2017/08/18/us-dairy-divided-over-canadas-supply-management-system-in-nafta.html|title=U.S. dairy divided over Canada’s supply management system in NAFTA|last=Panetta|first=Alexander|date=August 18, 2017|newspaper=Toronto Star|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref> In March 2018, both the [[Wisconsin Farmers Union]] (WFU)<ref name="swnews4u_Pomplun_2018"/> and [[Dairy Farmers of America]] (DFA) were looking at Canada's supply management system to resolve their own problems of low prices resulting in farm failures.<ref name="nationalpost_Blackwell_2018"/>
In 2017, the federal government established a five-year $250 million Dairy Farm Investment Program (DFIP), to lessen the impacts of [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|CETA]]'s implementation on dairy farmers. The first round of funds were distributed to eligible licensed dairy farms in 2018.<ref name="globalnews_Kraig_2018">{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4417114/canadian-dairy-farmers-receive-250-million-boost/|title=Canadian dairy farmers receive a $250-million boost by feds |date=August 29, 2018|work=Global News |first=Kraig |last=Krause|access-date=September 5, 2018|language=en}}</ref> Each applicant is eligible for up to $250,000 in DFIP funds over the five-year period to upgrade milk production equipment.<ref name="">{{cite web |url=http://www.agr.gc.ca/eng/programs-and-services/dairy-farm-investment-program/?id=1491935919994 |title=Dairy Farm Investment Program: 1. What this program offers |publisher=[[Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada]]|access-date=September 23, 2018}}</ref>
After the Conservative convention in August 2018, Scheer denied an allegation that the [[Dairy Farmers of Canada|Dairy Farmers of Canada]] worked with his office to block a motion changing the party stance on supply management after a binder from the Dairy Farmers of Canada was found by a delegate. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-the-dairy-lobbys-vile-plan-to-screw-us-all-revealed|title=Colby Cosh: The dairy lobby’s vile plan to screw us all — revealed!|date=2018-08-28|work=National Post|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Policy== The national supply management system has three basic pillars: production control, pricing mechanism, and import control.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> The five sectors operate in a similar way, even though they operate under separate provincial marketing boards and national organizations.<ref name="lacoop_2018_SM">{{cite web |url=http://web.lacoop.coop/fr/sites/lacoopfr.coop/files/etude_lcf-pwc_supply_management_egg_and_poultry.pdf |format=PDF |title=Supply Management in Egg and Poultry: The Economic Impacts of Changes to Canada’s Supply Management System |date=January 2018 |access-date=July 11, 2018 |publisher=La Coop Fédérée |location=Montréal, Québec}} This study was funded by La Coop Fédérée in partnership with Exceldor coopérative Burnbrae Farms Limited / Fermes Burnbrae Ltée Nutrigroupe and the collaboration of Fédération des producteurs d’œufs du Québec, Les Éleveurs de volailles du Québec, and Producteurs d’œufs d’incubation du Québec</ref>{{rp|3}} All five systems have the following elements in common. A quota system controls production volume, through the [[Market Sharing Quota]] (MSQ), for example. Through [[tariff-rate quota]]s (TRQs), the volume of imported product is limited. Pricing mechanisms that control the [[farm gate price]] that producers receive based on cost of production, are coordinated through provincial marketing boards and national organizations.<ref name="lacoop_2018_SM"/>{{rp|3}}
===Production Control===
National agencies, such as the Egg Farmers of Canada (EFC), Turkey Farmers of Canada (CFC), Chicken Farmers of Canada (CFC), Canadian Hatching Egg Producers (CHEP), and the Canadian Dairy Commission (CDC), are mandated to "prevent surpluses and shortages that can cause significant price fluctuations" by "setting the national production level based on provincial demand." Under the authority of the Farm Products Agencies Act the individual national agencies can "restrict production", "set provincial production quotas" and "impose penalties for overproduction or underproduction".<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/> It is the role of each provincial board to set "minimum quotas and quota transfer rules", to negotiate prices with buyers, for example, the three major processors, Parmalat, Saputo Inc and Agropur, and to allocate production among farmers. If farmers fail to produce within their "allotted quota" they may face penalties.<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015"/>
===Market Sharing Quota (MSQ)=== {{main|Market Sharing Quota}} A permit to sell under supply management caps is called a [[Market Sharing Quota]] (MSQ). By 2001, all Canadian provinces were signatories to the National Milk Marketing Plan (NMMP) which fixes a yearly production quota for industrial raw milk across Canada and each province's share of the [[Market Sharing Quota]] (MSQ). In some provinces, fluid milk quotas were managed separately by provincial marketing boards, while industrial raw milk was managed by CDC's MSQs. Most provinces roll fluid quota and MSQ into a single production quota, held by dairy producers.<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2010"/>{{rp|3}} The [[production quota]] system was designed to prevent overproduction. Each province then allocates MSQs to individual dairy farmers according to provincial policies and based on pooling agreements.<ref name="CDC_MSQ">{{cite web |url=http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?link=116 |title=MSQ |date=nd |access-date=July 10, 2018|publisher=CDC}}</ref> Since the 1970s the Canadian dairy industry SM system matches production with domestic market needs.<ref name="ontariodairies">{{cite web |url=https://www.ontariodairies.ca/Public/DairyProcessingIndustry/Supply_Management/Public/D/Supply_Management.aspx?hkey=73dcef07-a3d1-44b4-af65-600b16b2c615 |title=Supply Management |work=Ontario Dairy Council |date=nd |access-date=June 21, 2018 |series=Dairy Processing Industry}}</ref>
MSQs can be inherited for free or sold, subject to regulations from the respective board.<ref name="CBC_McGregor_July_2015"/>
In Ontario, from 2000 to 2010, quota values increased to $25,000/kg of [[butterfat]], a significant leap. This represents the quota or permit required for one dairy cow's production and therefore represents the right to keep a single dairy cow.<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2010"/>{{rp|3}} By 2015, a MSQ was valued at $30,000.<ref name="CBC_McGregor_July_2015">{{cite news|last1=McGregor|first1=Janyce|title=Supply management in Canada: Why politicians defend farm marketing boards |quote="The boards, a frequent whipping boy in international trade talks, are both a boon and a bogeyman"|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/supply-management-in-canada-why-politicians-defend-farm-marketing-boards-1.3166329|accessdate=May 3, 2017|work=[[CBC News]]|date=July 26, 2015}} Due to the value of the quota, by 2015, most banks would loan Canadian dairy farmers up to $30,000 per cow, while banks in the USA (non-supply managed) will only loan $3,000 per cow.</ref> By 2018, the combined value of MSQs was $CDN35 billion. "Farmers use quota as collateral, and total farm debt across Canada amounts to $102 billion — nearly one-third of it lent through a federal agency."<ref name="financialpost_Wingrove_2018">{{cite web |url=https://business.financialpost.com/commodities/agriculture/trudeau-has-billions-of-reasons-to-dig-in-against-trump-on-dairy |work=Financial Post |first1=Josh |last1=Wingrove |first2=Erik |last2=Hertzberg |date=June 19, 2018 |access-date=July 25, 2018 |title=Trudeau has billions of reasons to dig in against Trump on dairy supply management: Justin Trudeau’s defence of Canadian dairy tariffs isn’t just about farmers and politics, it’s about debt, too — billions of dollars worth}}</ref> An average dairy farm of 70 cattle would hold quotas worth 2,100,000.
According to the annual Dairy Farm Accounting Project report, Ontario dairy farmers saw their net farm profit drop from [[C$]]178,601 in 2012 to [[C$]]90,114 in 2016,<ref name="farmersforum_2018"/> the lowest point since 2006.<ref name="farmersforum_2017">{{cite web |url=https://farmersforum.com/dairy-farmers-net-farm-income-increases-for-first-time-in-six-years/ |title=Profits for Canadian dairy farmers lowest they’ve been in a decade according to report |first=Tom |last=Collins|date=August 22, 2017 |access-date=September 22, 2018 |work= Farmers Forum Newspaper |location=Guelph, Ontario}}</ref> The June 2018 report, showed the that the net farm income in 2017 was [[C$]]128,230, the first increase since 2012.<ref name="farmersforum_2018">{{cite web |url=https://farmersforum.com/dairy-farmers-net-farm-income-increases-for-first-time-in-six-years/ |title=Dairy farmers net farm income increases for first time in six years |date=August 27, 2018 |access-date=September 22, 2018 |work= Farmers Forum Newspaper |location=Ontario}}</ref><ref name="milk_org_2018">{{cite report |url=https://www.milk.org/corporate/pdf/Publications-ODFAPReport.pdf |format=PDF |series=Ontario Dairy Farm Accounting Project |title=Annual Report 2017 |publisher=Co-operative project of the Canadian Dairy Commission and Dairy Farmers of Ontario |location=Ontario |date=June 2018 |pages=22 |access-date=September 22, 2018}}</ref> According to a 2008 OECD policy brief, the median gross income in 2007, before expenses, for a dairy farmer was [[C$]]250,000 a year.<ref name="OECD_2008">{{cite journal | title =OECD Policy Brief: Economic Survey of Canada, 2008 | journal =OECD Observer | volume =| issue =June 2008 | pages = | publisher =[[OECD]] | date =June 11, 2008 | url = https://www.oecd.org/eco/greeneco/economicsurveyofcanada2008achievinglong-termsustainabilityoftheenergysector.htm | accessdate=June 26, 2018 }}</ref> In 2006, milk quota values on their balance sheets soared to over [[C$]]26 billion" or about 2% of total GDP. OECD says that SM's very high milk quota created "barriers to entry for young producers."<ref name="SPAA_Larue_2012"/>{{rp|2}} For farmers wishing to enter the market, the price of the [[Market Sharing Quota|quota]] can be up to 75% of start-up costs. This can leave farmers entering the industry with a heavy debt burden, or effectively exclude them from ever starting.<ref name="The Cow" group="Macleans"/> A Conference Board of Canada report estimated the book value of dairy quota at about $3.6 to $4.7 billion. Speaking at a GrowCanada 2014 agricultural conference, Mulroney said "we should consider "a careful, innovative and generous phase-out of our supply managed programs for dairy and poultry.<ref name="theglobeandmail.com">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/canadians-paying-high-price-for-supply-management-system/article21983265/|title=A strong voice challenges an anchor on the Canadian economy|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref>
===Pricing mechanisms=== [[File:Milk bags at a supermarket in London, Ontario.jpg|thumb|Retail sale of Class 1 4-litre [[milk bag]]s in [[London, Ontario]] (2007). SM sets quotas and support prices at the farm gate for industrial raw milk.]]
To establish a "fair price", the CDC consults with "dairy producers, processors, further processors, restaurateurs and consumers" each fall, then completes an annual study to determine the support price for industrial raw milk. Along with the study, Commissioners also consider factors such as "arguments presented by various stakeholders, an evaluation of the processors' margin, and economic indicators such as the [[consumer price index]]". The support price is posted each December and effective in February of the following year.<ref name="CDC_support_prices">{{cite web |url=http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?id=3809 |title=Support Prices |publisher=Canadian Dairy Commission |date=nd |access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
Producers create the goods (milk, poultry or eggs), and sell them to either processors or consumers at farm gate prices. Farm gate prices are set by negotiations between the farmers and downstream processors and ratified by the Local Marketing Board (one for each Province or Territory).{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The farm gate price that the processors or consumer pay is the minimum legal price, but the farmer could negotiate a higher price with one or more of their customers.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
====End-use classifying price system==== In 1993 multiple component pricing was implemented with dairy farmers were no longer paid based on volume of milk, they were paid based on butterfat, protein and other milk solids.<ref name="WCDS_2017"/>{{rp|9}} In 1995 changes were made in to the Canadian Dairy Commission (CDC) Act to allow the CDC to operate revenue sharing milk pools resulting in a national harmonized milk classification system using end-use pricing.<ref name="WCDS_2017"/>{{rp|9}}
Both the Canadian and American dairy industries apply end-use classified pricing systems.<ref name="agrifoodecon_Mussell_2018_Regime">{{cite report |title=Regime Change in Canadian Dairy Policy: A Cautionary Tale |series=Independent Agri-Food Policy Note |date=July 2018 |first1=Al |last1=Mussell |first2=Douglas |last2=Hedley |url=http://www.agrifoodecon.ca/uploads/userfiles/files/dairy%20policy%20reform-cautionary%20july-18(1).pdf |format=PDF|publisher=Agri-Food Economic Systems |location=Guelph Ontario |pages=6}}</ref>{{rp|3}} In Canada, for example, prices of raw industrial milk purchased by milk processors are based on end-use−fluid consumption, yogurt, ice cream, cottage cheese, butter,<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/><ref name="CRS_Womach_2005"/>{{rp|46}} whole milk powder, skim milk and milk protein concentrates (MPCs). The highest price is for Class A or Class 1 for fluid consumption and the lowest price is for milk products in 'Special Milk Class 7', a new class Canada introduced in February/March 2017. By 2005, the United States had four classes<ref name="CRS_Womach_2005">{{cite report |title = Report for Congress: Agriculture: A Glossary of Terms, Programs, and Laws Agriculture: A Glossary of Terms, Programs, and Laws, 2005 Edition |date=June 2005|url = https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metacrs7246/m1/1/high_res_d/97-905_2005Jun16.pdf |format=PDF|first= Jasper |last=Womach |pages=282 }}</ref>{{rp|46}} and by 2016 Canada had five.<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/> In Canada industrial raw milk is sold to three major processors, Parmalat, Saputo Inc and Agropur.<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/> Class 1 included fluid liquid products; Class 2 included yogurt, ice cream, soft products; Class 3 included Cheese; Class 4 included butter, milk powders and Class 5 included exports under access, permits 5(d) subsidized exports. In April 2016, Ontario began to implement a new milk price (Class 6) and Manitoba did the same in August 2016.<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016">{{cite web |last=Mussell |first=Al |date=May 2016 |title=Understanding the Dynamics of Milk Pricing and Revenue in a Time of Change |series=Independent Agri-Food Policy Note |publisher=Agri-Food Economic Systems Newsletter |location=Guelph, Ontario |access-date=June 21, 2018 |url=http://www.agrifoodecon.ca/uploads/userfiles/files/milk%20pricing%20briefing%20note%20may%2018%202016.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>
By June 2015, skim milk processing plants hit their capacity in Ontario, Québec and the Maritimes. The Dairy Farmers of Nova Scotia, the producers' marketing board, that purchases pools of raw milk from farmers to sell to dairy milk processors, raised their milk quota in March 2015, in response to an "unprecedented" increase in demand for butter and cream. They were left with a surplus of skimmed milk.<ref name="CBC_Withers_2015">{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Withers |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/surplus-milk-may-be-dumped-due-to-nova-scotia-glut-1.3123556 |title=Surplus milk may be dumped due to Nova Scotia glut: Marketing board struggles to manage demand |newspaper=CBC News |date=June 22, 2015 |access-date=September 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name="CBC_NZ_US_CA_2015">{{cite news |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/n-z-u-s-dairy-farmers-call-on-canada-to-open-its-market-amid-deadlocked-trade-talks-1.3184738 |title=N.Z., U.S. dairy farmers call on Canada to open its market amid deadlocked trade talks |work=CBC |date=August 9, 2015 |access-date=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
Canada's supply management system attracted media attention in 2016, when the province of Ontario responded to the exponential increase of the imports of diafiltered milk (UV) from the United States. In April 2016, the Dairy Farmers of Ontario created a new class of milk designed to encourage processors to invest in new facilities in Canada. They adjusted prices for certain milk ingredients such as MPIs, to compete with U.S. proteins.<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2016"/><ref name="nationalpost_2016_dump">{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/its-not-a-pretty-picture-ontario-dairy-farmers-dumping-skim-milk-into-manure-pits-and-sewer-lagoons#comments-area|title=‘It’s not a pretty picture’: Ontario dairy farmers dumping skim milk into manure pits and sewer lagoons|date=June 2, 2016|work=National Post|access-date=June 25, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref>
The Global Dairy Ingredients Market<ref group="Notes">Global Dairy Ingredients Market Dairy ingredients market include [[whey]] ingredients, [[milk powder]], [[milk protein isolates]] (MPI), [[milk protein concentrates]] (MPCs), [[casein]], [[caseinates]], [[lactose]], and others.</ref> is booming and expected to increase<ref>{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/dairy-ingredients-market-grow-swiftly-102000028.html |title=Dairy Ingredients Market to Grow Swiftly Due to Rising Awareness About Benefits of Healthy & Nutritious Diet Till 2024 |work=PR Newswire |date=June 5, 2018 |access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref> as these relatively new milk products, specifically [[milk protein isolates]] (MPIs), [[milk protein concentrates]] (MPCs), also known as [[ultrafiltered milk]] (UV) or diafiltered milk, entered the marketplace.<ref name="Barrett_2017">{{cite news |last=Barrett |first=Rick |date=April 11, 2017 |title=Canada says don't blame it for Wisconsin dairy woes |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel }}</ref> MPC's are produced in facilities in the U.S. along the CA-US border. Compared with raw milk, MPIs are inexpensive and easier to ship and more efficient in cheese production. Because the technology was invented post-NAFTA, and because they were listed as proteins by Canada's border agency,<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2016"/> not milk, at the Canadian border U.S. MPI were both tariff and quota free. The MPIs were a "cheap alternative to skim milk for Canadian processors such as Saputo Inc and Parmalat Canada Inc, who must meet federal standards for milk and protein content in cheese".<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2016">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/canada-dairy-usa-idUSL2N17B1E4 |series=Market News |date=June 7, 2016 |access-date=June 25, 2018 |title=Canada weighs options as farmers spar over U.S. milk proteins |first=Rod |last=Nickel |location=Winnipeg, Manitoba}}</ref> By October 2008, the TRQ for MPIs was put in place and there was a very strong import demand in 2009.<ref name="AAFC_2011"/> By 2010, MPIs were placed under Re-export Program (IREP).<ref name="AAFC_2011">{{citation |last1=Doyle |first1=Pierre |last2=Asgarali |first2=Aamir |last3=Beaulieu-Charbonneau |first3=Olivier |title=Canada’s Dairy Industry's Dairy Industry: Position for the future |work=Department of Agriculture and Agri-Food (AAFC) |year=2011 }}</ref> By 2011, the TRQs for MPCs were always filled and the demand for Re-export Program (IREP) was strong.<ref name="AAFC_2011"/> Over a five-year period ending in January 2016, the quantity of U.S. milk protein isolates imports rose to 2,700 tonnes—an increase of ten times by volume, representing about $150 million a year.
In response to the new Class 6 introduced by Ontario in 2016, Agropur cancelled its MPIs (diafiltered milk) contracts with American facilities, such as Cayuga Milk Ingredients, who claimed they lost $30 million in exports.<ref name="WRVO_Magnarelli_2017"/> Cayuga, Wisconsin-based Grassland Dairy Products Inc<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2016"/> and other US facilities in turn cancelled contracts with dozens of dairy farmers in Wisconsin and the New York.<ref name="agcanada_2016">{{cite web |url=https://www.agcanada.com/daily/agropur-halts-its-diafiltered-milk-imports |title=Agropur halts its diafiltered milk imports: Co-operative has criticized loophole allowing high-protein ingredient |work=AGCanada |date=May 10, 2016 |access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref> There are concerns that "thousands of [US] family farms could be lost without access to Canada's processors' contracts. Politicians in affected states blamed Canada for the threats to dairy farms and asked for intervention from the Trump administration.<ref name="WRVO_Magnarelli_2017">{{cite news |last=Magnarelli |first=Tony |date=April 17, 2018 |title=Schumer calls for an end to Canadian program hurting upstate dairy farmers |work=WRVO Public Media |url=http://wrvo.org/post/schumer-calls-end-canadian-program-hurting-upstate-dairy-farmers |access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref> In June 2016, federal Agriculture Minister [[Lawrence MacAulay]] responded to concerns from Canadian dairy farmers that US MPIs caused a "reduced demand for domestic milk."<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2016"/>
====Class 7==== In March 2017, the Canadian dairy industry implemented a Canada-wide domestic policy, creating a lower-priced class of industrial milk, Class 7, as part of Canada's National Ingredient Strategy negotiated between Canadian processors and producers, to address the surplus of 'non-fat solids' which include milk ingredients such as whole milk powder, skim milk and milk protein concentrates (MPCs)<ref name="ipolitics_Johnson_2017">{{cite web|title=Dairy 101: The Canada-U.S. milk spat explained|last=Johnson|first=Kelsey|url=https://ipolitics.ca/2017/04/22/dairy-101-the-canada-u-s-milk-spat-explained/|date=April 22, 2017|work=ipolitics.ca|access-date=September 7, 2018}}</ref> as "fast-rising volumes of U.S. milk proteins not subject to high tariffs" flowed into Canada.<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2018"/> Class 7 promotes the production of protein substances in Canada using Canadian milk and benefits the domestic cheese-manufacturing sector. According to the media outlets in October 2017, in the list of U.S. requests in the NAFTA negotiations, the phasing out of SM over a ten-year period and the elimination of the Class 7 mechanism, were included.<ref name="agrifoodecon_Mussell_2018_Regime"/>{{rp|2}}<ref name="calgaryherald_Verboven_2018">{{cite news|url=http://calgaryherald.com/opinion/columnists/verboven-its-hard-to-believe-dairy-farmers-hold-the-key-to-nafta|title=It's hard to believe dairy farmers hold the key to NAFTA|last=Verboven|first=Will|date=June 16, 2018|newspaper=The Calgary Herald|access-date=June 25, 2018 }}</ref> In April 2018, a 68-member bi-partisan group of members of Congress wrote a letter to U.S. Trade Representative [[Robert Lighthizer]] calling for the removal of Class 7 and other Canadian dairy policies.<ref name="ipolitics_Johnson_2018">{{Cite news|url=https://ipolitics.ca/2018/04/25/canadas-abusive-dairy-policies-need-to-go-congressmen/|title=Canada's 'abusive' dairy policies need to go|work=iPolitics|language=en-US |first=Kelsey |last=Johnson |date=April 25, 2018 |access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> In their July 2018 report, Canadian agrifood economists, Al Mussell and Douglas Hedley, explained how Canada's SM system, which was bound by a butterfat quota, would become bound by a skim quota because of the "structural surplus of skim" which threatens to overpower the SM system.<ref name="AgriFood_Mussell_2016"/>{{rp|2–3}}
Ten dairy industry organisations, including the [[Dairy Companies Association of New Zealand]] (DCANZ) and other dairy industry leaders from the US, EU, Argentina, Australia, and Mexico, co-signed a letter to request that their governments intervene in ending Canada's "new and harmful" 'Special Milk Class 7' mechanism by potentially entering a complaint through the WTO's [[dispute settlement in the World Trade Organization|Dispute Settlement System (DSS)]],<ref name="radionz_Cook_2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/country/334113/canada-s-policies-depress-milk-prices |title=Canada's policies depress milk prices |date=June 29, 2017 |access-date=July 14, 2018 |first=Alexa |last=Cook |location=New Zealand |work=Radio New Zealand}}</ref> a process which could take several years to conclude.
In 2016, before Class 7 was introduced, Canada exported less than 24,000 tonnes of skim milk powder (SMP). Although the organizations expressed concerns that as Canada moves its surplus skim milk powder onto the global market at low prices in "significant" volumes, this could distort and depress global prices,<ref name="radionz_Cook_2017"/> Statistic Canada reported in 2017 that Canada exported 71,880 tonnes which is valued at C$173 million ($133 million USD) and represents an increase of 47,880 tonnes over 2016.<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2018a">{{cite news |url=https://ca.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idCAKBN1J82NF-OCABS |title=Sheltered Canadian dairy sector skimming global exports, U.S. complains |first1=Rod |last1=Nickel |first2=Julie |last2=Ingwersen |location=Winnipeg and Chicago |work=Reuters |date=June 12, 2018 |access-date=July 14, 2018}}</ref> The US exports "five times more dairy to Canada than vice-versa". Agri-Food Economic Systems' research lead, Al Mussell, said "concerns about Class 7 are overblown" as Canadian SMP sales are "a drop in the bucket." Even though there was an increase in SMP exports in 2017 and 2018, that "growth cannot continue because Canada’s system restricts production".<ref name="reuters_Nickel_2018"/> The price of Class 7 SMP was about $0.5488 USD a lb. in March 2017.
===Retail price of milk===
{{POV|date=November 2018}}
In April 2018 Export Action Global report, co-authored by [[Adam Taylor]], who was a senior advisor for [[Ed Fast]], [[Minister for International Trade (Canada)|Minister for International Trade]] (2011-2015) under [[Stephen Harper]] during negotiations for the Canada-EU trade deal and the TPP, said that, "We’ve always been told this as though it’s actual, verifiable fact — that Canada has higher dairy prices because of supply management. We now know that that is factually not true."<ref name="realagriculture_Heppner_2018">{{cite web |url=https://www.realagriculture.com/2018/04/dairy-price-study-finds-canadians-dont-pay-more-for-milk/ |title=Dairy price study finds Canadians don’t pay more for milk |first=Kelvin |last=Heppner |date=April 9, 2018 |access-date=September 16, 2017 |work=RealAgriculture}}</ref> The 44-page document by Taylor and Fion Anastassiades was based on Canadian government data and the 2017 Nielsen's Fresh Milk Price Report. According to [[Nielsen Corporation|AC Nielson]] Fresh Milk Price Report, which compared the global retail fluid milk price per litre for 12 months ending October 2017, the price of 1 litre of liquid milk in Canadian dollars in Canada was $1.50. In Australia it was $1.57, in the USA a litre of rBST-free milk was $1.61, in France, $1.77, and in New Zealand, $1.83.<ref name="exportactionglobal_2018">{{cite report |series=Dairy systems around the world |title=Are Canadian Consumers and Farmers Better Off with the Canadian Model? |date=April 2018 |url=https://www.exportactionglobal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Dairy-Systems-Around-The-World_Export-Action-Global_April-2018.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=July 25, 2018 |pages=44 |work=Export Action Global |first1=Adam |last1=Taylor |first2=Fion |last2=Anastassiades}}</ref>{{rp|30}}
While farm gate prices are decided by SM mechanisms, other factors affect retail prices across the country. In Québec, the minimum retail price of milk had been frozen for two years by the Régie des marchés agricoles et alimentaires du Québec, which regulates all agricultural and food retail prices in Québec in general and milk in particular. In February 2018, the Régie approved an increase of about 1.2% or c. 2 cents per liter for 2018. Retailers had successfully lobbied for the price increase under the leadership of Association des détaillants en alimentation (ADA) and its CEO Florent Gravel.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://depquebec.com/en/for-the-first-time-the-regie-grants-retailers-an-exclusive-price-increase/ |title=For The First Time, The Régie Grants Retailers An Exclusive Price Increase 3 January 2018 |work=DepQuébec |access-date=July 14, 2018}}</ref> CTV News reported that in Québec City and Montreal consumers could pay from $1.76 ($1.34) to $1.92 ($1.46 USD) a litre for homo milk and from $1.56 (1.18 USD) to $1.72 (1.31 USD) a 1 litre of skim milk.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/bureaucrats-raise-minimum-price-of-milk-in-quebec-1.3786591|title=Bureaucrats raise minimum price of milk in Québec|date=February 2, 2018|location=Montreal|access-date=July 10, 2018|language=en-CA |work=CTV News}}</ref> A 2017 study by [[Nielsen Corporation|AC Nielson]], a global marketing research firm, "commissioned by the [[Dairy Farmers of Canada]], suggests that the prices Canadians pay for milk, for example, are comparable to those in many countries throughout the world, at an average retail price of around $1.30 per litre."<ref name="CBC_Powers_2016" />
===Import control===
SM limits milk imports through [[tariff-rate quota]] (TRQ) to prevent the Canadian market from being flooded by much larger food-producing nations who now have milk surplus.<ref name="DFO_for_Journalists"/> Only seven per cent of all milk produced globally is exported with ninety three per cent "consumed in the country of origin".<ref name="DFO_for_Journalists">{{cite web |url=https://www.milk.org/Corporate/PDF/Media-OntarioMilkIndustry.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Ontario Industry: A Guide for Urban Journalists |date=nd |access-date=July 18, 2018 |location=Mississauga, Ontario |publisher=Dairy Farmers of Ontario}}</ref>{{rp|3}} The DFO says that most countries, including Canada produce milk for domestic consumers.<ref name="DFO_for_Journalists"/>{{rp|3}}
In 2015, the three top dairy imports into the country were specialty cheeses, milk protein substance and whey products. The largest suppliers into Canada were the United States, New Zealand, France and Italy.<ref name="Canadian Dairy Commission">{{cite web|title=Trade|url=http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?id=3803|website=Canadian Dairy Commission|accessdate=April 6, 2017}}</ref>
====Tariff-rate quotas (TRQ)==== {{main|Tariff-rate quota}}
A [[tariff-rate quota]] (TRQ) is an international trade policy tool that combines [[import quota]]s and [[tariff]]s. By 2013, there were approximately 1200 WTO TRQs in the agricultural sector annually among supplying countries under GATT Article XIII.<ref name="UCD_OConnor_TRQ">{{cite journal |url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2272026 |last1=O'Connor |first1=Bernard |last2=Gubel |first2=Sebastien |last3=Bertolotto |first3=Elena |title=The Allocation of Agricultural Tariff Rate Quotas among Supplying Countries under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade |date=May 30, 2013 |access-date=July 18, 2018 |series=UCD Working Papers in Law, Criminology & Socio-Legal Studies Number=05/2013 |doi=10.2139/ssrn.2272026 }}</ref><ref name="lexology"/> TRQs are a result of the "current market access requirements" and the "minimum market access requirements" forming the basis of the "Uruguay Round country schedules for agriculture."<ref name="lexology">{{cite web |url=https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=6707d79e-dcd2-4180-a84f-9adac166d5a7 |title=The EU is in breach of its WTO obligations because of the way it allocates shares in quotas for the import of many agricultural goods |location=European Union |date=April 29, 2013 |access-date=July 18, 2018}}</ref> TRQs are two-tiered tariffs in which quotas of certain sensitive domestic products are assigned a quantitative threshold or WTO "minimum access commitments" for imports during a designated time period.<ref name="CRS_Womach_2005"/>{{rp|254}} Tariffs for imports that are at or below the threshold, are either nonexistent or very low.<ref name="CRS_Womach_2005"/>{{rp|254}} Imports above the quantitative threshold, are much higher, making the cost of importation intentionally prohibitive.<ref name="CRS_Womach_2005"/>{{rp|254}} Once imports exceed the "minimum access commitments" as required by the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO), which allow for imports at no or lower [[tariffs]], in Canada imports face prohibitive tariffs such as 168% for eggs, 285% for chicken, 246% for cheese and over 300% for butter.<ref name="The Cow" group="Macleans"/> These steep tariffs have been often cited to criticize SM for creating barriers to free trade and artificially raising prices by SM critics such as David E. Bond (2010),<ref name="theglobeandmail_Bond_2010"/> Andrew Coyne (2011),<ref name="The Cow" group="Macleans"/> Hall Findlay (2012)<ref name="MHF"/> and President Trump in 2016.
TRQs came into use after [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO)'s 1995 [[Uruguay Round|Uruguay Round Agreement]] with 123 nations as contractual parties.<ref name="CRS_Womach_2005"/>{{rp|254}} By 2018 the United States's quantitative TRQ threshold for the import of milk products is 3% and Canada's is 10%.<ref name="ABmilk_2018">{{cite web|url=https://albertamilk.com/news/2018/06/alberta-dairy-farmers-stand-up-against-president-trump/|title=Alberta Dairy Farmers Stand Up Against President Trump|last=Conway|first=Karlee|date=June 11, 2018|publisher=Alberta Milk|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> By 2018, about 41 countries, including Canada and the U.S., had WTO approved tariff-rate quotas.<ref name="Grey_2018">{{cite web |url=https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/american-dairy-farmers-depend-on-government-subsidies-673374473.html |work=Grey, Clark, Shih and Associates Limited |date=February 8, 2018 |title=American dairy farmers depend on government subsidies |access-date=June 25, 2018 |quote="he study, which focuses on changes introduced by the 2014 Farm Bill, shows that in 2015, the American government doled out approximately $22.2 billion dollars in direct and indirect subsidies to the U.S dairy sector."}}</ref>
High TRQs are only placed on imports above the quota, not on all the dairy products sold to Canada. Below the quantitative threshold, Canadian TRQs on dairy products are often zero or less than 5%.<ref name="brookings_Noll_2018_dairytariffs"/> Canada's milk quota system is butterfat-based so the highest TRQ is on butter at 298.5%. The threshold in 2005 for butter was 3,274 tonnes, of which 2,000 tonnes was allocated to New Zealand. Imports above the quota for butter would pay the steep tariff.<ref name="dairyweb_2007_butter">{{cite web |url=http://www.dairyweb.ca/Resources/WDD82/WDD8204.pdf |format=PDF |date=2007 |publisher=Western Dairy Digest |title=What you should know about butter |access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref> Brookings noted that "[as] a practical matter, no dairy products are sold to Canada outside the quota, so no U.S. exports really pay a high tariff.<ref name="brookings_Noll_2018_dairytariffs"/>
Prior to 1995 Canada employed agricultural import controls in use since the 1983 World Trade Organization's [[Agreement on Agriculture]] (AoA). These were converted to TRQs after 1995.<ref name="GC_TRQ">{{cite web |url=http://www.international.gc.ca/controls-controles/prod/agri/tarif.aspx?lang=eng |title=Tariff Rate Quotas : Agricultural Products |publisher=Government of Canada |date=September 26, 2013 |access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref> By 2011, Canada's WTO-authorized TRQ represented 8% of the cheese market and 1% of the [[yogurt]] market.<ref name="MHF" /><ref name="The Cow" group="Macleans">{{cite web|title=The $25,000 cow|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2011/08/15/the-25000-cow/|first=Andrew |last=Coyne|date=August 15, 2011|publisher=[[Maclean's]] | access-date=October 22, 2013 |quote="These range from 168 per cent for eggs, to 238 per cent for chicken, 246 per cent for cheese...these apply only above certain "minimum access commitments" required by the World Trade Organization (WTO), allowing a certain amount of imports to enter at much lower tariffs."}}</ref><ref group="Notes">The same figures Coyne (2011) uses are cited in Findlay (2012:4) who is citing Hart (2005:3). "The tariff on the over quota (ranging from 168 percent for eggs, 238 percent for chicken, 246 percent for cheese, to almost 300 percent for butter) means that the prices of imports are so high that virtually no one bothers."</ref>
The Canadian supply management system uses these TRQs to ensure that the majority of Canadian dairy and poultry are supplied by Canadian farms shielding Canadian farmers against the "heavily subsidized dairy coming into Canada".<ref name="ABmilk_2018"/> Canada has classified the dairy, poultry and egg sectors as "sensitive" and this has been accepted under WTO trading rules. It established a quota of allowable imports in these sensitive sectors of 4% to fulfill minimum access commitments at low tariffs.<ref name="MHF"/>{{rp|4}} The allowable quota for cheese was 8% of the domestic market and 1% for yogurt.<ref name="CDHowe_Hart_WineCheese_2005"/>{{rp|3}}<ref name="MHF"/>{{rp|4}} In 2009, in preparation for entry into TPP negotiations, Canada was calling for a minimum 6% TRQ threshold on designated 'sensitive' products, dairy, poultry and egg, as opposed to the existing 4% TRQ, which they said was necessary to adequately protect supply management.<ref name="CIIT_Richardson_2009"/>{{rp|3}} At that time, it was proposed "to designate 6% of tariff lines as sensitive in exchange for raising its TRQ threshold on those products – effectively allowing more foreign supply to enter the Canadian market. That proposal was not acceptable to Canada’s supply managed industries."<ref name="CIIT_Richardson_2009"/>{{rp|3}} By October 2015, Canada had agreed to open the dairy market by 3.5% while retaining the SM system.
When the U.S. under the Trump administration withdrew from TPP on January 24, 2017,<ref name="bbc.com"/> the tariff-rate quotas (TRQ) on dairy products remained in effect.<ref name="brookings_Noll_2018_dairytariffs"/>
In 2015, the three top dairy imports into Canada were specialty cheeses, milk protein concentrates (MPCs) and whey products. The largest suppliers into Canada were the United States, New Zealand, France and Italy.<ref name="Canadian Dairy Commission"/>
The [[Business Council of Canada (BCC)]] reported in 2012 that, beginning in 2000, [[New Zealand]] and [[Australia]] phased out their dairy supply management programs and as a result, their dairy industries increased productivity and efficiency and became global industry leaders.<ref name="BCC_SM_20122">{{citation|title=The case for reforming Canada’s supply management systems|date=August 8, 2012|url=http://thebusinesscouncil.ca/publications/the-case-for-reforming-canadas-supply-management-systems/|location=Ottawa, ON|publisher=[[Business Council of Canada (BCC)]]|access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref> Muirhead explained that from 2007 to 2014, the demand for New Zealand's milk intensified with "new consumers in China, India and Indonesia" raising the price by 50 percent.<ref name="CIGI_Muirhead_2014"/>{{rp|14}}
With the supply management system, processors of dairy, poultry, and eggs benefit from predictable supply from the system, while having to pay higher prices for their inputs, which can generally be passed on to the consumer. However, this means they are at a disadvantage on the international market, because their inputs are comparatively expensive. Total dairy exports in Canada amount to only 5% of production. [[New Zealand]] by contrast, which has phased out subsidies and does not have supply management, 95% of dairy is exported. New Zealand's share in world milk markets jumped from 5.8 per cent in 1995 to 16.7 per cent in 2014. Canada's share fell from 0.9 per cent to 0.45 per cent. In 2014, New Zealand produced 21 million tonnes and Australia produced 9.5-million tonnes of milk, compared with Canada's 8.4-million tonnes.<ref name="YYC_policyschool_Beaulieu_2018">{{Cite journal|last1=Beaulieu |last2=Venkatachalam|first1=Eugene |first2=V. Balaji|date=March 2018|title=Nafta Renegotiations: An Opportunity for Canadian Dairy?|url=https://www.policyschool.ca/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/NAFTA-Renegotiations-Beaulieu-final.pdf|journal=The School of Public Policy Publications|volume=11 |number=10|pages=|via=University of Calgary |series=SSR}}</ref><ref name="financialpost_Corcoran_2018">{{Cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-its-trudeau-chance-to-save-us-from-supply-management-hes-blowing-it|title=It’s Trudeau’s chance to save us from supply management. He’s blowing it|last=Corcoran|first=Terence|date=March 23, 2018 |series=Opinion|newspaper=Financial Post|language=en-CA|access-date=June 11, 2018}}</ref> In his 2014 article University of Waterloo's Bruce Muirhead wrote that the liberalized market benefited New Zealand in terms of food exports and economy, but the price of milk for New Zealanders rose so much, a price freeze was placed in 2011 and farmers lost income.<ref name="CIGI_Muirhead_2014"/>{{rp|14}}
===Quality=== One of the mandates of the [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] is to "ensure the quality and supply of milk".<ref name="CDC_quality_2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?id=3787|title=Mandate|date=March 19, 2010|publisher=[[Canadian Dairy Commission]]|accessdate=October 19, 2013}}</ref> According to Hall Findlay, though the responsibility of milk is under the [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] to ensure proper oversight of dairy production and to guarantee that strict standards of biosecurity are upheld."The Council of Canadians cautioned that, "Given the subsidized U.S. industrialized farming industry, allowing U.S. farms more market access [by eliminating supply management] would mean Canadian small farmers would be in competition with larger industrialized U.S. farms. The market would expand to include milk from U.S. farms that may have [[Bovine Growth Hormone]] (BGH) in it, unlike the milk here in Canada, which doesn’t allow BGH."<ref name="CC_NAFTA_">{{cite web |work=Council of Canadians |date=November 20, 2017 |title=Factsheet: NAFTA and Farming |location=Ottawa, Ontario |url=https://canadians.org/factsheet-nafta-farming |access-date=September 7, 2018}}</ref> In an August 21, 2017 article in the ''Globe and Mail'', Martha Hall Findlay wrote that, Canada could demand milk to be hormone-free like Europe does with Canadian beef.<ref name="theglobeandmail_HallFindlay_2017"/>
=== Inter provincial restrictions === [[John Manley]], former deputy prime minister of Canada,<ref name="CCCE_2016">{{cite web|url=http://thebusinesscouncil.ca/news/canadian-council-of-chief-executives-adopts-new-name-elects-linda-hasenfratz-as-chair|title=Canadian Council of Chief Executives adopts new name, elects Linda Hasenfratz as Chair|date=January 28, 2016|publisher=Business Council of Canada|access-date=June 23, 2018}}</ref><ref group="Notes">The BCC, known as the Canadian Council of Chief Executives (CCCE) until c. 2009, was first established as the Business Council on National Issues (BCNI) in 1976 and operated under that name until c.2000. Its membership includes CEOs of 150 of Canada's leading corporations. By 2016, these corporations [http://thebusinesscouncil.ca/news/canadian-council-of-chief-executives-adopts-new-name-elects-linda-hasenfratz-as-chair accounted for over 50%] of the value of the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]].</ref> criticized provincial dairy marketing boards that "control and restrict the sale of dairy products" by setting production quotas and imposing "strict limits on interprovincial shipments".<ref name="nationalpost_Manley_2015">{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/opinion/john-manley-if-ottawa-truly-wants-to-tear-down-provincial-trade-barriers-it-should-start-with-supply-management|title=John Manley: If Ottawa truly wants to tear down provincial trade barriers, it should start with supply management|date=January 13, 2015|work=National Post|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref> However, Ontario MP [[John Nater]], the Conservative critic for interprovincial trade, expressed concerns that changes to "marketing boards and supply management" should not be "to the detriment of farmers."<ref name="Macleans_Geddes_2017" group="Macleans">{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/conservatives-say-free-the-beer-but-not-the-millk/|title=Conservatives say 'Free the beer' but not the milk - Maclean's|last=Geddes|first=John|date=December 6, 2017|work=Maclean's|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref> In [[R v Comeau]], a controversial [[Supreme Court of Canada]] case on the scope of free trade between the Canadian provinces, led some supporters of the supply management system to express concern that if inter-provincial conditions were removed, then it could lead to unintended consequences. The SM-5 Organizations "acting jointly" said that it "could result in the destruction of supply management — a regulatory system in place for generations, on which the livelihood of thousands of farmers across the country depends."<ref name="Macleans_Geddes_2017" group="Macleans" /><ref name="CBC_MacKinnon_2017">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/supreme-court-interprovincial-trade-alcohol-comeau-new-brunswick-1.4381048|title=New Brunswick needs alcohol revenue to cover social costs of drinking, Supreme Court told CBC News|last=MacKinnon|first=Bobbi-Jean|date=December 6, 2017|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>
In a 2013 report by the George Morris Centre, the authors recommended reforms in supply-management system to align with changes in its environment related to market growth, improved efficiency, reduction in costs and liberalized pricing.<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2013"/> To improve efficiency they suggested the elimination of the provincial "balkanization" of the dairy market and the liberalization of milk quota transfers.<ref name="georgemorris_Mussell_2013"/>
Critics claim the supply system has been a major barrier in free trade negotiations, including in inter-provincial trade in Canada.<ref group="Notes">CPTPP is a revised version of TPP.</ref><ref name="PA_Wittman_2012">{{citation |url=https://www.policyalternatives.ca/publications/monitor/food-sovereignty-canada |title=Food Sovereignty In Canada: Movement growing to control our own food and agriculture|first1=Hannah |last1=Wittman |first2=Annette Aurélie |last2=Desmarais |date=September 1, 2012 |access-date=June 24, 2018 |publisher=[[Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives]] (CCPA)}}</ref>
==International trade agreements== While supply management was one of many issues in [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement]] (CETA), a free-trade agreement between Canada, the [[European Union]] and its member states<ref name="EU_CETA_2017">{{cite web |url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2017/september/tradoc_156062.pdf |format=PDF |title=Guide to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership |pages=35 |date=July 2017 |isbn=978-92-79-68000-7 |doi=10.2781/647649}}</ref>{{rp|3}} and [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (CPTPP) negotiations, and the [[United States Mexico Canada Agreement]] (USMCA)<ref name="timescolonist_Blanchfield_2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.timescolonist.com/trump-approves-of-new-continental-trade-deal-as-winners-and-losers-are-assessed-1.23447871 |title=Trump approves of new continental trade deal as winners and losers are assessed |first=Mike |last=Blanchfield |newspaper=Times Colonist via The Canadian Press |date=October 1, 2018 |access-date=October 1, 2018}}</ref> the system remained intact.
The United States Mexico Canada Agreement (USMCA) was reached on October 1, 2018.<ref name="timescolonist_Blanchfield_2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.timescolonist.com/trump-approves-of-new-continental-trade-deal-as-winners-and-losers-are-assessed-1.23447871 |title=Trump approves of new continental trade deal as winners and losers are assessed |first=Mike |last=Blanchfield |newspaper=Times Colonist via The Canadian Press |date=October 1, 2018 |access-date=October 1, 2018}}</ref> Under USMCA, supply management remains in place, the US was granted an expanded 3.6 % market access to the domestic dairy market, similar to what it would have accessed, had the US remained in the CPP, (3.6% vs 3.25%),<ref name="thestar_DealReached">{{cite news |title=Canada, U.S. reach new NAFTA|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2018/09/30/canada-us-reach-nafta-deal.html |work=The Star |location=Ottawa, Ontario |language=en |first1=Daniel |last1=Dale |first2=Tonda |last2=MacCharles |date=September 30, 2018 |access-date=October 1, 2018}}</ref> and Class 7 was eliminated.
==Supply management debate==
Supply management policies provide "stability and wealth" for "primary producers, processors, retailers and input and service providers like equipment manufacturers and financial institutions." They have been "criticized for being costly and regressive tools to transfer dollars from consumers to producers and for creating barriers to entry for young producers." Canada's trade partners say that supply management curbs market access.<ref name="SPAA_Larue_2012">{{cite report |url=http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/125246/2/SM_report__5_2012_wc.pdf |format=PDF |title=A Primer on the Economics of Supply Management and Food Supply Chains |first1=Bruno |last1=Larue |first2=Rémy |last2=Lambert |location=Québec City, QC. |date=2012 |number=2012‐9 |series=Working Paper |publisher=Structure and Performance of Agriculture and Agri-products industry Network (SPAA Network) |access-date=June 29, 2018 |pages=71}}</ref>{{rp|2}}
In a 2014 article by Barrie McKenna, former Prime Minister, [[Brian Mulroney]], who served as Prime Minister from 1984 to 1993 suggested during the 2014 [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|CETA]] negotiations that abolishing supply management would "bolster Canada's case for concessions from the U.S. on government purchasing (Buy America), non-tariff barriers (country labelling for meat) and on agricultural export subsidies." Barrie McKenna notes that "Many Conservative MPs grumble privately about supply management. But on the record, they and members of every other federal party stand as a monolithic block in defence of the status quo."<ref name="theglobeandmail_McKenna_2014">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/canadians-paying-high-price-for-supply-management-system/article21983265/|title=A strong voice challenges an anchor on the Canadian economy|last=McKenna|first=Barrie|date=December 7, 2014|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|access-date=June 11, 2018}}{{Subscription required}}</ref> <ref group="Macleans" name="Milke_2017">{{Cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/its-time-for-the-conservatives-to-abandon-dairy-cow-marxism/amp/|title=It's time for Conservatives to ditch dairy cow Marxism - Macleans.ca|last=Milke|first=Mark|date=September 1, 2017|website=www.macleans.ca|language=en-CA|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref><ref>[https://thewalrus.ca/the-new-life-of-brian-mulroney/ "The New Life of Brian Mulroney"]. ''The Walrus'', Ira Wells, Apr. 19, 2018</ref><ref group="Notes">It was Mulroney's "crucial role" that led to the signing of the controversial 1989 Canada-United States Free Trade Agreement, NAFTA's precursor. In the 1980s, there was "fierce" opposition to free trade in Canada.</ref><ref name="theglobeandmail.com"/> Apart from Bernier, the leaked binder from that Conservative MPs, [[David Anderson (Saskatchewan politician)|David Anderson]], [[Kevin Sorenson]], [[Dan Albas]], [[Alupa Clarke]], [[Tony Clement]], [[Tom Kmiec|Tom Kmeic]], [[Alex Nuttall]] and [[Len Webber]] as not being supportive towards Supply Management.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/full-text-the-dairy-lobby-briefing-binder-found-on-the-floor-of-the-conservative-convention|title=Full text: The dairy lobby briefing binder found on the floor of the Conservative convention|date=2018-08-28|work=National Post|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
One of Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]]'s Policy Advisors for the Minister of International Trade's Global Affairs Canada, Simon Beauchemin, had published an opinion piece in ''[[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]]'' in 2014, in which he stated that Canada's supply management system disadvantaged us in the TPP negotiations particularly in relation to the US, who have been seeking greater access to the Canadian dairy and poultry market for many years. Beauchemin suggested that Canada revisit our commitment to supply management.<ref name="LaPresse_Beauchemin_2014">{{cite news|title=Opinion|last=Beauchemin|first=Simon|date=November 17, 2014|newspaper=[[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]]}}</ref> When this was publicized in 2018, Trudeau's senior press secretary Chantal Gagnon said that Beauchemin "now fully supports the Liberal government's policy on supply management.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lapresse.ca/affaires/economie/canada/201805/28/01-5183589-un-conseiller-de-trudeau-favorable-a-labolition-de-la-gestion-de-loffre.php|title=Un conseiller de Trudeau favorable à l'abolition de la gestion de l'offre {{!}} Joël-Denis Bellavance {{!}} Canada|date=2018-05-29|work=La Presse|access-date=2018-07-12|language=fr-CA}}</ref>
