===Farmers===
Supporters said that supply management is effective at keeping revenue stable for farmers. For this reason, farmers lobby to protect supply management from any challenges, both domestic and international.<ref name="MHF" />
Supporters have stated that supply management protects farmers but critics say that there are other ways for the government to impact farmers without removing supply management, such as changing [[Canada's Food Guide]] to shift from a dairy-based diet to a plant-based diet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/opinion/columnists/charlebois-milking-nafta-why-supply-management-may-finally-be-doomed|title=Charlebois: Milking NAFTA – Why supply management may finally be doomed|date=2017-08-08|work=Ottawa Citizen|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en-CA}}</ref>
According to a 2015 Boston Consulting Group study, New Zealand's production costs are half those of North American dairy farmers whose cattle spend most of their lives indoors, because New Zealand's "free-roaming", "grass-eating cows" live outdoors year-round.<ref name="CBC_NZ_US_CA_2015" /> Critics state that [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Wisconsin]] have colder climates than Canada and their industries are thriving without supply management.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
Supporters of supply management say that it protects customers from US milk produced by cattle injected with [[growth hormone]]s that enables United States dairy farms to be more productive than those in Canada. John Barber, a supporter says that family farms in Canada that milk an average of 80 cows a day.<ref name="theguardian_Barber_2018">{{cite news |last=Barber |first=John |date=June 9, 2018 |title=Why Canadian milk infuriates Donald Trump |newspaper=The Guardian |location= UK |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/commentisfree/2018/jun/09/milk-canada-us-trade-war |access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> Critics say that [[Washington (state)|the state of Washington]] (whose own cows are rbST-Free) produces {{convert|10800|kg|lb}} milk per year per cow compared to Wisconsin (which permits the use of hormones) at {{convert|10000|kg|lb}} per cow. Canada produces {{Convert|8500|kg|lb}} of milk per year per cow.<ref group="Macleans" name="Macleans_Tombe_2017">{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/economy/economicanalysis/now-is-our-chance-to-scrap-the-milk-tax-once-and-for-all/|title=Now is our chance to scrap the milk tax once and for all|date=April 20, 2017|work=Maclean's|access-date=2017-11-26|language=en-CA |first=Trevor |last=Tombe}}</ref><ref name="CDC_support_prices" /><ref group="Notes">According to the [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] (CDC), "[http://www.cdc-ccl.gc.ca/CDC/index-eng.php?id=3801 The overall number of cows has decreased over the past 5 years], however the production per cow has increased by 9.7%. In 2011, there were 965,600 cows in Canada producing an average of 80.5 hl of milk per cow. In 2016, there were approximately 959,100 dairy cows in Canada, producing an average of 88.3 hl of milk per cow."</ref>
Taxpayers do not pay direct subsidies to supply-managed industry products, such as dairy, poultry and egg farmers. Agricultural subsidies are common in many developed countries. The majority of Canadian farmers in sectors that are not supply-managed, including grain, beef, pork, food oils and pulses, receive few if any subsidies.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The [[OECD]] estimated the subsidy equivalent in 2012 ([[producer support estimate]]) in all Canadian agriculture represented 18% of the value of the industry with most of this amount going to supply managed sectors which represent only a percentage of Canadian agriculture. Critics say that this results in a "much higher effective subsidy" for supply-managed industries.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} According to Hall Findlay's 2012 study, in the [[European Union]], the effective subsidies were 27%,{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} with the United States at 10%,{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} [[Australia]] (6%),{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} [[New Zealand]] (1%),{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} [[Brazil]] (6%),{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} and [[China]] at 9%.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}<ref name="MHF" />
===Legal principles === Calgary-based lawyer, Michael Osborne wrote in a July 2018 ''Financial Post'' article that "Supply management may be lawful, but it is undoubtedly an equal assault on the market...The only difference between supply management and price-fixing cartels is the web of federal and provincial laws that support the first and make the second a criminal offence."<ref name="FP_Osborne_2018"/> Osborne cited the example of a 2012 decision on auto parts price-fixing by Federal Court Judge Paul Crampton in which Crampton described price-fixing cartels, in general, as "an assault on our open-market economy."<ref name="FP_Osborne_2018">{{Cite web|url=https://business.financialpost.com/opinion/its-really-time-to-kick-canadas-2-6-billion-dairy-cartel-er-habit|title=It really is time to kick Canada’s $2.6-billion dairy habit |newspaper=Financial Post|last= Osborne|first=Michael|date=July 6, 2018|language=en-CA|access-date=July 19, 2018}}</ref>
Critics such as the Frontier Centre for Public Policy's Eric Merkley,<ref name="Merkley_2013" /> Canada West Foundation's Martha Hall Findlay,<ref name="MHF" /> ''Bloomberg'''s Stephen Mihm,<ref name="bloomberg_Mihm_2017">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-04-29/milk-wars-curdled-u-s-canada-relationship-long-ago|title=Milk Wars Curdled U.S.-Canada Relationship Long Ago|last=Mihm|first=Stephen|date=April 29, 2017|work=Bloomberg L.P.|access-date=June 21, 2018|language=en|quote="Trump blames Canada, but both sides have been fighting dirty since the 1930s. ... But the U.S. is equally guilty of treating its dairy industry as a sacred cow. Indeed, both countries have gone to extraordinary lengths to prop up their dairies since the 1930s."}} Paywall</ref> and [[Maxime Bernier]]<ref name="CBC_Powers_2016">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/milk-dairy-cost-supply-management-1.3612834|title=Does supply management really mean Canadians pay more for milk? A new look at global retail milk prices says Canucks pay a fair price for milk|last=Powers|first=Lucas|date=June 3, 2016|work=CBC News|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> have described SM as a "[[cartel]]".<ref name="Merkley_2013" /> [[Jonathan Kay]] called it a "milk racket."<ref name="foreignpolicy_2018">{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/06/11/canada-is-running-a-milk-racket/|author=[[Jonathan Kay]] |title=Justin Trudeau Is Running a Milk Racket|website=Foreign Policy|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref> Bernier explained in his chapter that “The word cartel applies to a system, not to individuals, and it doesn’t necessarily describe criminal behaviour,”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/opinion/christie-blatchford-how-much-do-i-love-max-bernier-let-me-count-the-cartels|title=Christie Blatchford: How much do I love Max Bernier? Let me count the cartels|date=2018-08-29|work=National Post|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
Articles in and the ''Globe and Mail'' in 2017 and in the ''Toronto Star'' in 2018 compared supply management to the [[bread price-fixing in Canada]] scandal. ''The Star'' editors wrote that consumers are "penalized through the absolutely legal, indeed highly valued, practice of supply management."<ref name="globeandmail_McKenna_2017">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-commentary/worried-about-price-fixing-check-out-the-dairy-aisle/article37394007/|title=Loblaw’s behaviour is outrageous. But so are other schemes to fix the cost of food|last=McKenna|first=Barrie|date=December 20, 2017|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|access-date=June 11, 2018}}{{Subscription required}}</ref>
===Protecting farms===
Proponents of supply management claim that it is effective at keeping small family farms viable instead of having them crowded out by large [[intensive animal farming|factory farms]].<ref name="go5quebec_2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.go5quebec.ca/en/gestion.php|title=WTO and Agriculture — Supply management|year=2013|publisher=GO5, Coalition for a Fair Farming Model, Supply Management|accessdate=October 22, 2013}}</ref>
The number of dairy farms decreased from 500,000 just after WWII to 18,500 in 2005.<ref name="CDHowe_Hart_WineCheese_2005" />{{rp|8}} According to Hall Findlay, the numbers continued to decrease from 135,000 in 1971 to 13,000 in 2011, representing a 91 percent loss. The number of chicken farms has declined 88 percent; while in the same period of time in the [[United States]], the number of dairy farms dropped by 88 percent.<ref name="MHF" /><ref name="CBC_Payton_2012">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/don-t-fear-political-fallout-from-dairy-farmers-ex-mp-says-1.1217862|title=Don't fear political fallout from dairy farmers, ex-MP says|work=CBC News|access-date=April 1, 2018|language=en |first=Laura |last=Payton}}</ref> Supply-managed farms represent 8% to 13% of all farms in the country.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/en/type/data?text=40200|title=Data|last=Canada|first=Government of Canada, Statistics|website=www150.statcan.gc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref> Hall Findlay says that even with supply management, "[t]here has been more consolidation in dairy, poultry and eggs than in almost every other agricultural sector".<ref group="Macleans" name="HallFindlay_2014_Part1">{{cite web |url=https://www.macleans.ca/economy/economicanalysis/why-your-milk-costs-so-much-in-canada/ |work=Maclean's |title=Why your milk costs so much and what to do about it: It’s time to put Canada’s most sacred cow, supply management, out to pasture |date=May 12, 2014 |first=Martha |last=Hall Findlay}}</ref><ref group="Notes">This is Part 1 of a series of three, Part 2: "Why the dairy industry’s defence of supply management is so flawed", Part 3: How to scrap supply management—a lesson from down under</ref> Supporters, such as the [[Broadbent Institute]], say that the supply management system "allows Canada a degree of food security and food sovereignty that is remarkable". The "global dairy is in the throes of a massive downturn, which has created havoc everywhere" except Canada. Without the stability of the supply management system, farmers could lose their livelihood while "consumers do not necessarily benefit from lower prices given the activities of supermarkets (and others) to keep prices as high as possible."<ref name="broadbent_Muirhead_2015" /><ref name="theglobeandmail_Elton_2018" /> Though Hall Findlay has stated hypocritical to support supply management and claim to support "progressive, "social justice" values.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thewalrus.ca/youre-paying-too-much-for-milk/|title=You’re Paying Too Much for Milk|work=The Walrus|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-CA}}</ref>
In her 2014 ''Maclean's'' article Hall Findlay wrote that the "average dairy farm’s net worth was well more than $2.5 million" in 2010 and "the average poultry/egg farm’s net worth was almost $4 million—far more than all other Canadian farmers, and far, far more than the average Canadian family."<ref group="Macleans" name="HallFindlay_2014_Part2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/economy/economicanalysis/why-the-dairy-industrys-defence-of-supply-management-is-so-flawed/|title=Why the dairy industry's defence of supply management is so flawed|last=Hall Findlay|first=Martha|date=May 14, 2014|work=Maclean's|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref>
=== Lobbyisim === One of the lobby groups that oppose supply management as an impediment to the pursuit of "reciprocal trade and investment liberalization" is the [[Business Council of Canada (BCC)]]—Canadian Council of Chief Executives (CCCE)— a registered lobbyist on Canadian public policy. Since at least 2012, when Harper announced his intention to enter into TPP trade talks, the former Liberal deputy prime minister [[John Manley]] as BCC CEO, has led the call for review and reform of Canada's supply management system to increase productivity, exports, and employment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thebusinesscouncil.ca/publications/the-case-for-reforming-canadas-supply-management-systems/ |title=The case for reforming Canada’s supply management systems |date=August 8, 2012 |access-date=July 13, 2018 |publisher=[[Business Council of Canada (BCC)|Business Council of Canada]] |location=Ottawa, Ontario}}</ref>
The [[Canadian Dairy Commission]] (CDC), a [[Crown corporations of Canada|Crown corporation]] composed mainly of dairy farmers, and its analogue for eggs, chicken and turkey products, the [[Farm Products Council of Canada]], are just some of the organizations that defend supply management. DFC partners who publish articles in support of supply management include the [[Canadian Federation of Agriculture]], the GO5, Coalition for a Fair Farming Model, Supply Management, FarmGate5, and the five national marketing agencies that administer or support agricultural supply management systems, known jointly as the SM-5 Organizations, such as, [[Dairy Farmers of Canada]] (DFC),<ref name="dairyfarmers_myths" /> Egg Farmers of Canada (EFC),<ref name="EFC_2018_SM" /> Turkey Farmers of Canada (TFC), Chicken Farmers of Canada (CFC)<ref name="LOP_Heminthavong_2015" /> Canadian Hatching Egg Producers (CHEP) support the system.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dairyfarmers.ca/who-we-are/our-partners|title=Partners|date=nd|work=Dairy Farmers of Canada|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref> Other supporters include [[Québec Federation of Milk Producers]], and the [[Union des producteurs agricoles|Union of Agricultural Producers]] (UPA) that represent dairy farmers and turn up at protests.<ref name="dairyfarmers_2018_about"/> In March 2018, the [[Wisconsin Farmers Union]] (WFU) hosted events for Wisconsin dairy farmers and lawmakers in five Wisconsin cities in which [[Dairy Farmers of Ontario]] (DFO) representatives explained Canada's dairy supply management system.<ref name="swnews4u_Pomplun_2018">{{cite news|url=http://www.swnews4u.com/archives/37536/|title=Canada’s Dairy Supply Management Can Offer Farmers A Stable Pay Price|last=Pomplun|first=Gillian|date=April 20, 2018|access-date=July 18, 2018|location=Vernon County, Wisconsin}} Participants included Wisconsin State Senator [[Jennifer Shilling]], State Representative [[Lee Nerison]], aides of U.S. Senators [[Tammy Baldwin]] and [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]], and U.S. Representative [[Ron Kind]], as well as Darrin Von Ruden, President of Wisconsin Farmers Union, Kevin Walleser of the Wisconsin Milk Marketing Board, Al Hass of Organic Valley and more.</ref><ref name="milkboard_2018_NAFTA">{{cite web|url=http://milkboard.dgtlpub.com/issues/2018-04-30/pdf/milkboard_2018-04-30.pdf|title=Optimism Amidst Challenges: Canada’s dairy industry experiences resurgence and renewed interest as it faces threats to system and its future prosperity|date=April 30, 2018|editor-last=Laidlaw|editor-first=Sharon|series=Milk Producer|publisher=Dairy Farmers of Ontario|location=Mississauga, Ontario|pages=56|format=PDF|issn=0030-3038|access-date=July 18, 2018|volume=94|number=4}}</ref>{{rp|4}} At the end of the presentation, by a show of hands 70 to 80% of participants indicated that there were elements of Canada's SM "that would make sense in the U.S." When asked if they believed Canada caused the "challenges dairy farmers in the U.S. [were] experiencing, there were "no hands raised at any of the five meetings."<ref name="swnews4u_Pomplun_2018" /> Hall Findlay described the dairy lobby as a small group with out-sized power, that pose a threat to the political careers of those who oppose SM.<ref name="Walrus_HallFindlay_2017">{{Cite news|url=https://thewalrus.ca/youre-paying-too-much-for-milk/|title=You’re Paying Too Much for Milk|last=Hall Findlay|first=Martha|date=August 1, 2017|work=The Walrus|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref><ref name="MHF" />{{rp|11}}
The [[Dairy Farmers of America]] (DFA), the largest cooperative of milk-producers in the United States, representing 14,000 farmers, faced with the increasing number of dairy farm bankruptcies, low milk prices, voted at their annual meeting in March 2018, to look into Canada's supply management system.<ref name="nationalpost_Blackwell_2018">{{cite news |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/world/growing-number-of-u-s-dairy-farmers-look-to-supply-management-to-solve-crisis-as-trump-urges-canada-to-kill-it |title=Growing number of struggling U.S. dairy farmers look to supply management, as Trump urges Canada to kill it |date=July 25, 2018 |first=Tom |last=Blackwell |access-date=August 17, 2018 |newspaper=National Post}}</ref>
Agropur, which is one of three milk processors in Canada that control 80% of production−the others are Montreal-based [[Saputo Inc]] and [[Parmalat Canada]]−defends the "supply management system, both in the public arena and with various levels of government."<ref name="Agropur_2015AnnualReport">{{cite report|url=https://www.agropur.com/sites/default/files/2018-01/RapportAnnuel_2015_ANG_PDF_final.pdf|title=Annual Report|pages=72|access-date=June 26, 2018|format=PDF|work=Agropur|year=2015}}</ref> In preparation for TPP negotiations, Agropur had commissioned the Boston Consulting Group to produce the 2015 report, "Analysis of the potential impacts of the end of supply management on the Canadian dairy industry", and distributed it widely, which they said, "had a significant impact on decision makers and the media alike."<ref name="Agropur_Benoit_Corriveau">{{cite report|url=https://www.agropur.com/sites/default/files/documents/Analysis_of_%20impacts_of_supply_management_Canadian_dairy_inudstry-EN.pdf|title=Analysis of the potential impacts of the end of supply management in the Canadian dairy industry|last1=Benoit|first1=Dominique|last2=Corriveau|first2=Alexandra|date=December 2015|pages=55|access-date=June 26, 2018|format=PDF|work=[[Boston Consulting Group]] via Agropur (BCG)}}</ref><ref name="Agropur_2015AnnualReport" />{{rp|9}} The report estimated that a complete and abrupt abolition of supply management would put 40% of Canadian dairy production at risk, resulting in the loss of about 5,000 dairy farms.<ref name="Agropur_Benoit_Corriveau" />{{rp|51,54}} "Agropur Cooperative and Saputo Inc., have expanded into the U.S. or even Brazil to boost revenues."<ref name="financialpost_Snyder_2017"/>
Dairy farmers have greater political influence because "[as] producers, [they] are very involved in [their] regional economy and regional politics. Each producer has more impact than the average voter, because [they] buy supplies from local companies, [they] sell to local processors, [they] are at the base of the regional economy."<ref group="Macleans" name="macleans_Wherry_2015">{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/why-the-dairy-lobby-is-so-powerful/|title=Why the dairy lobby is so powerful - Macleans.ca|last=Wherry|first=Aaron|date=October 5, 2010|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=June 25, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref> Dairy farmers have been major players in international trade talks such as NAFTA and TPP talks.<ref group="Macleans" name="macleans_Wherry_2015"/> In 2015, during TPP negotiations, dairy farmers and their cows "converged on Parliament Hill to protest the mere possibility that supply management would be significantly affected by TPP negotiations."<ref group="Macleans" name="macleans_Wherry_2015 />
A 2015 ''Maclean's'' article, "Why the dairy lobby is so powerful", described an incident during the September 28, 2015 federal leaders [[Munk Debate]] on foreign affairs, then-NDP Leader [[Tom Mulcair]] asked Stephen Harper if they could assure the [[Union des producteurs agricoles|Union des producteurs agricoles du Québec]] (UPA) President [[Marcel Groleau]], reached out to the New Democrats, Liberals and Bloc Québécois, of his full support for supply management. Harper immediately complied.<ref name="macleans_Wherry_2015" group="Macleans"/> In his 2018 on-line political memoir, [[Maxime Bernier]] grouped together supporters of supply-managed sectors under a combined dairy lobby. Bernier described the UPA as an "extension" of Québec's [[Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Quebec)|Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food]]. He wrote that the combined dairy lobby funds millions of dollars in university graduate programs and research on "collective marketing of agricultural products" across the country in support of SM policies.<ref name="manitobacooperator_bernier_2018">{{cite web |url=https://www.manitobacooperator.ca/comment/how-the-supply-management-lobby-influences-politics/ |title=Comment: How the supply management lobby influences politicsMy unsuccessful federal leadership campaign is proof the sector has outsized political influence — for now |first=Maxime |last=Bernier |date=July 10, 2018 |access-date=July 13, 2018 |publisher=[[Glacier Media]] Glacier Farm Media Limited Partnership |series=Manitoba Co-operator}}</ref>
According to the Federal lobbyist registry, from January to September 2012, the Chicken Farmers of Canada had 92 contacts with federal officials making it on the list of top ten lobby groups with the most contacts that year. They lobbied on poultry import tariffs, medicated feed mixing regulations, meat inspection regulations and food safety programs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/in-the-lobby/ |title=The 10 lobby groups with the most contact with federal officials |work=Maclean's |date=November 27, 2012 |access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
===Dairy industry-related jobs=== According to their 2015 Boston Consulting Group comprehensive report, there are about 12,000 dairy farms in Canada that produce about 8 billion litres of milk annually which is sent for "treatment and processing to approximately 450 dairy plants".<ref name="Agropur_Benoit_Corriveau" />{{rp|5}} Critics state supply management can be used to deter manufacturing jobs away from Canada. In 2010, 22,650 people were employed in the dairy processing sector. Critics state that number could be, and should be, much higher.<ref name="MHF" />
Another study stated an estimate for dairy input "costs of Canadian manufacturers, which produce everything from frozen pizza to ready-made lasagna, to be between five and 30 percent higher than those of U.S. companies."<ref name="financialpost_Snyder_2017" />
In 2017, the Chinese corporation, Feihe International, invested $225 million to construct an infant formula plant in Kingston, Ontario in 2017, citing one of the main reasons for choosing Canada, was the supply management system though it was mainly for the quality of milk.<ref>{{cite news |last=McGregor |first=Janyce |date=August 2, 2017 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/feihe-plant-kingston-construction-1.4228501 |title=A winning formula? China invests in Canadian dairy to help feed its baby boom: Feihe International investing $225 million to build infant formula plant in Kingston, Ontario |work=CBC News|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref><ref group="Notes">Feihe chose Canada instead of New Zealand, despite its proximity, because of the bad press surrounding New Zealand's Fonterra, which owned a 43% stake in Sanlu, the company whose product poisoned hundreds of thousands of babies in the [[2008 Chinese milk scandal|melamine scandal]] in 2008. As a result Chinese consumers no longer trust milk from New Zealand.</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Klaudia |date=September 16, 2008 |access-date=June 26, 2018 |url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/nz-pm-alerted-china-to-tainted-baby-milk-20080915-4gfh.html |title=NZ alerted China to tainted milk, PM says |newspaper=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong}}</ref>{{rp|A1}}<ref>{{cite news |last=Ritchie |first=Kerri |date=December 28, 2009 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-01-28/fonterra-denies-advocating-melamine-use-in-milk/275912 |title=Fonterra denies advocating melamine use in milk scandal |location=New Zealand |work= ABC |access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref> In 2013, [[Chobani, LLC|Chobani,]] a yogurt maker from the US, abandoned plans to build a $76 million plant in [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]], which would have created 1,300 direct and indirect jobs based on quota limitation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/legal-post/yoplait-danone-battle-to-keep-chobani-yogourt-out-of-canada|title=Yoplait, Danone battle to keep Chobani yogourt out of Canada|date=2012-04-02|work=Financial Post|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thewhig.com/2013/01/29/chobani-sours-on-canada|title=Chobani sours on Canada|last=nurun.com|website=The Kingston Whig-Standard|language=en-CA|access-date=2017-12-10}}</ref>
Critics state that the high cost associated with supply management had led to Canada's food processing industry bleeding "market share to U.S. competitors and several major companies such as Campbell Soup Co, Kraft Heinz Co., and Kellogg Co. closing Canadian plants in recent years."<ref name="financialpost_Snyder_2017" /> In addition, they state that dairy processors establish operations outside the country to meet global demand due saturation in the Canadian market caused by the tariffs.<ref name="MEI_Moreau_2017" />
====Butter 2015 crisis==== [[Postmedia]] columnist Joe Childley wrote in his November 2017 article in the ''Financial Post'' that the [https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crise_fran%C3%A7aise_du_beurre_de_2017 butter crisis] in France, was an "object lesson" for Canada's SM system in NAFTA renegotiations.<ref name="financialpost_Chidley_2017">{{Cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/investing/theres-a-global-butter-boom-but-supply-management-has-canada-stuck-on-the-sidelines|title=There’s a global butter boom, but supply management has Canada stuck on the sidelines|date=November 1, 2017|work=Financial Post|access-date=September 23, 2018|language=en-US |first=Joe |last=Chidley}}</ref> In March 2017, the ''[[Wisconsin Agriculturist]]'' reported that butter consumption in the United States was increasing and was nearing a fifty-year record high which was pushing the price of butter higher.<ref name="wisconsinagriculturist_2017">{{cite news |url=http://www.wisconsinagriculturist.com/dairy/us-butter-consumption-nears-50-year-record-high |title=U.S. butter consumption nears 50-year record high: Dairy Outlook: Butter consumption is forecast to jump 8% in 2017 |first=Fran |last=O'Leary |date=March 27, 2017 |access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref> Europe also experienced a butter shortage.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/08/09/news/economy/butter-shortage-europe/index.html |title=Europe is running out of butter |first=Ivana |last=Kottasová |date=August 10, 2017|access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref>
In Canada, starting in 2015 there was also an "unprecedented" demand for butter (and cream) in Canada resulting in a brief but "severe butter shortage" that some blamed on supply management.<ref name="financialpost_Chidley_2017"/><ref name="nationalpost_Hopper_2016">{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/canada/how-canadas-zany-dairy-system-affects-daily-life-from-cheese-bandits-to-dessert-starved-newfoundlanders#comments-area |first=Tristin |last=Hopper|title=How Canada’s zany dairy system affects daily life, from cheese bandits to dessert-starved Newfoundlanders|date=November 15, 2016|work=National Post|access-date=June 26, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref> Provincial marketing boards raised their milk quotas to respond to demand.<ref name="CBC_Withers_2015"/> By April 2017, there was enough growth in the Canadian domestic butterfat output to meet demand.<ref name="milkbusiness_2018">{{cite web|first=Fran |last=Howard |date=April 27, 2018 |url=https://www.milkbusiness.com/article/canadas-growing-milk-output-outpacing-demand |title=Canada's Growing Milk Output Outpacing Demand |website=milkbusiness.com}}</ref>
===Consumers===
Supply management limits the production of dairy product in Canada, and imposes tariffs on imports. The direct consequence of these policies is to increase the retail prices of dairy products. According to the Conference Board of Canada's March 2014 report, "Canada's Reforming Dairy Supply Management: The Case for Growth", Canadian households paid on average about $276 more annually than those from other countries for dairy products because of SM.<ref name="CBoC_2014">{{cite report |publisher=Conference Board of Canada |date=March 2014 |title=Canada's Reforming Dairy Supply Management: The Case for Growth |location=Ottawa, Ontario |first1=Michael |last1=Grant |first2=Richard |last2=Barichello |first3=Mark |last3=Liew |first4=Vijay |last4=Gill}}</ref> According to the CPP 2015 article "Milked and Feathered", the average cost for Canadian households was $444 annually based on StatsCan's 2001 data.<ref name="CPP_Cardwell_2015"/> The OECD estimated that the [[consumer support estimate]] (CSE)<ref>The CSE represents the value of annual transfers between consumers of agricultural commodities and producers, measured at the farm gate resulting from agricultural policy mechanisms that support agriculture.</ref> from 2001 to 2011 represented about $2.6 billion annually. Based on a rough estimate of 9.4 million households in 2011, this represented about $276 per household annually.<ref>{{cite report |publisher=OECD |title=Producer and Consumer Support Estimates |url=https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=MON20123_2 |date=2012 |access-date=September 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="CBoC_2014"/>
Hall Findlay has been saying since 2012 that Canadian consumers pay one and a half to three times as much for dairy, poultry and eggs than they otherwise would without the supply management system, or pay up to around [[C$]]450/year per household and $600/year for households with children.<ref name="MHF" /><ref group="Macleans" name="Macleans_Tombe_2017" /> This has been criticized as a [[regressive tax]] on the poor (around 37 cents per litre),<ref group="Macleans" name="Macleans_Tombe_2017" /> for whom food is a large portion of their budget, and who are in effect subsidizing well-off farmers.<ref name="thestar_SM_Findlay">{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorials/2017/04/23/trump-is-wrong-about-dairy-protectionism-but-canada-should-still-scrap-it-editorial.html|title=Trump is wrong about dairy protectionism, but Canada should still scrap it: Editorial|date=April 23, 2017|newspaper=The Star|access-date=June 22, 2018|location=Toronto|series=Editorial}}</ref>
In addition, a study pointed out that supply management was costing Canadian consumers $2.6 billion per year (compare to supply management dairy product bringing in $970 Million into the economy). The study stated that supply management impacts the poorest households five times (2.4% of income or almost 25% of income on food) more than wealthy families (0.5% of income or almost 6% of income on food) in relative household income, while another study point to that around 133,032 to 189,278 Canadians (or 67,000 to 79,000 households) are pushed into poverty due to burden of SM.<ref name="nationalpost_Csanady_2015">{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/politics/supply-management-costs-poor-families-five-times-more-relative-to-household-income-study|title=Supply management costs poor families five times more relative to household income: study|last=Csanady|first=Ashley|date=February 26, 2015|work=National Post|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/opinion/supply-management-is-literally-driving-tens-of-thousands-of-canadians-into-poverty|title=Supply management is literally driving tens of thousands of Canadians into poverty|date=2016-08-31|work=Financial Post|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016|editor-last=Geo-JaJa|editor-first=MacLeans A.|editor2-last=Majhanovich|editor2-first=Suzanne|title=Effects of Globalization on Education Systems and Development|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-94-6300-729-0|doi=10.1007/978-94-6300-729-0}}</ref>
===Farmers not covered by supply management=== Canadians farm products that are not supply managed do as well as their American or European competitors, who receive more support from their government.<ref name="MEI_Moreau_2017">{{Citation|title=Nearly all Canadian farmers prosper without supply management |work=[[Montreal Economic Institute]] |via=Newswire|first=Alexandre |last=Moreau|date=August 21, 2017|url=https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/nearly-all-canadian-farmers-prosper-without-supply-management-640869313.html|accessdate=2018-01-15}}</ref> Nearly 60% of Canada's agricultural and agri-food production is bound for foreign markets, with nearly half of this going to the U.S. market.<ref name="MEI_Moreau_2017" /> Hall Findlay wrote that "other agricultural sectors in Canada (grain, beef, pork, etc.) do not have similar controls or subsidies, and for the most part compete as a normal product on the international market.<ref name="theglobeandmail_HallFindlay_2017">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-commentary/canadas-supply-management-system-for-dairy-is-no-longer-defensible/article36029788/|title=Canada’s supply management system for dairy is no longer defensible|access-date=September 17, 2018 |date=August 18, 2017 |first=Martha |last=Hall Findlay}}</ref>
Montreal Economic Institute's public policy analyst, Alexandre Moreau, said that Canadian farmers who are not under SM would "pay the price" if President Trump is unable to deliver on his 2017 promise related to NAFTA re-negotiations, to increase "market access to U.S. dairy farmers" in a direct "aim at Canada's supply management."<ref name="CBC_MacNamara_2017"/> Wheat farmer Kevin Auch, former chair of the [[Alberta Wheat Commission]] does not want the 90% of Canadian farmers who are not under SM to put at risk to preserve SM for the 10% who are.<ref name="CBC_MacNamara_2017">{{Cite news|date=August 18, 2017|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/farmers-nafta-supply-management-dairy-farmers-renegotiation-1.4251369|title=Western farmers worry they'll pay the price of saving supply management under NAFTA |first=Kate |last=MacNamara|work=CBC News|access-date=June 22, 2018|language=en-CA}}</ref> In other sectors of agriculture. There are ten times more farmers that benefit from increased trade.<ref name="CBC_Payton_2012" />
Supply management make farmers poorer by limiting options for farmers when selling dairy products as well as missing opportunities to prevent food shortages when supplying the growing population.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-commentary/why-is-canada-letting-dairy-farmers-imperil-nafta/article37089835/|title=Why is Canada letting dairy farmers imperil NAFTA? |newspaper=Globe and Mail |first=Aaron |last=Gairdner |date=November 26, 2017|access-date=June 22, 2018}} Paywall</ref>
In a 2015 anti-SM article by the Ottawa-based [[Centre for International Policy Studies]]' [[Alan Freeman (journalist|Alan Freeman]] described SM as a "bizarre system of agricultural market protection that seems to have been lifted from a five-year economic plan in 1950s Communist Romania". Freeman cited the [[University of Guelph]]’s Food Institute's [[Sylvain Charlebois]], who is also a "trenchant" SM critic, saying Canadian dairy farmers under SM are not as productive as their American counterparts and it costs them twice as much to produce milk as it does in the United States.<ref name="ipolitics_Freeman_2015">{{Cite news|url=https://ipolitics.ca/2015/12/05/supply-management-is-expensive-irrational-and-doomed/|title=Supply management is expensive, irrational — and doomed |publisher=iPolitics|date=December 5, 2015|work=iPolitics|access-date=November 14, 2017|language=en-US |first=Alan |last=Freeman}}</ref> Canada's supply management forces Canada, Canadian farmers, and Canadians to give up billions in GDP, exports, prosperity, jobs, and tax revenue.<ref name="Agropur_Benoit_Corriveau" />

{{Infobox company | name = V-KEY | logo = File:V-Key_Logo.png | caption = | type = Private | industry = B2B, mobile security, [[cybersecurity]], deep technology | foundation = 2011 | dissolved = | location =Singapore | location_city = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Eddie Chau (Co-founder and Chairman), Benjamin Mah (Co-founder), Joseph Gan (Co-founder and President), Er Chiang Kai (CTO) | products = | services = [[Mobile security]], [[digital security]], [[cryptography]], software [[authentication]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 51 - 100 (2017) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | location_country = Singapore | homepage = [http://www.v-key.com www.v-key.com] }} {{ad|date=July 2018}} '''V-Key''' is a software-based digital security [[solution]]s provider. Headquartered in [[Singapore]], it provides back-end to front-end [[solution]]s to financial institutions, [[mobile payment]] providers and governments to implement cloud-based payments, [[authentication]] for [[mobile banking]], and secured [[mobile app]]lications for user access and data protection.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pymnts.com/news/security-and-risk/2016/ant-financial-partners-with-v-key-to-secure-mobile-payments/|title=Ant Financial, V-Key Partner On Mobile Security {{!}} PYMNTS.com|website=www.pymnts.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://sbr.com.sg/co-written-partner/sponsored-articles/securing-and-extending-digital-economy-trust-and-user-experien|title=Securing and extending the digital economy with trust and user experience|website=Singapore Business Review|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref>
== Background & founders == V-Key was founded in 2011 by entrepreneur Eddie Chau, Benjamin Mah and Joseph Gan.Eddie Chau, who also formed digital agency Brandtology,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/brandtology-founder-eddie-chau-at-it-again-starts-v-key-a-mobile-security-company|title=Tech in Asia - Connecting Asia's startup ecosystem|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> acquired by [[iSentia]] in 2014, started V-Key primarily to secure [[mobile device]]s and applications with [[patent]]ed technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=59230854&privcapId=217765341|title=Eddie Chau: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theasianbanker.com/updates-and-articles/interview-convenient-security-without-compromise?&lang=Chinese|title=Interview: "Convenient security without compromise"|last=Ping|first=Foo Boon|website=The Asian Banker|language=en|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref>
Benjamin Mah is the co-founder and chief executive officer of V-Key. He was general manager at e-Cop (acquired by a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Temasek Holdings]]) and regional director at [[Encentuate]] (acquired by [[IBM]]), before he co-founded V-Key.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=217861271&privcapId=217765341&previousCapId=217765341&previousTitle=V-Key%2520Inc|title=Benjamin Mah: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref> He is concurrently venture partner of Venture Craft, chairman of JumpStart Asia and a mentor at UOB Finlabs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sis.smu.edu.sg/newsletter/25451|title=The new digital economy where software security and convenience meet|last=|first=|date=|website=www.sis.smu.edu.sg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref>
Joseph Gan is the third co-founder of V-Key. Before joining V-Key, he was at the Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT) as the head of the Cryptography Lab, where he oversaw research and development into cryptographic solutions for the [[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=217861317&privcapId=217765341&previousCapId=217765341&previousTitle=V-Key%2520Inc|title=Joseph Gan: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/singapore-based-v-key-secures-us4m-in-series-a-funding-from-ipv-capital/|title=Singapore based V-Key secures US$4M in Series A funding from IPV Capital|work=e27|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
Companies that have funded V-Key are IPV Capital and [[Ant Financial Services Group|Ant Financial Services]], which runs the [[Alipay]] mobile wallet app.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/asia/2012/09/26/mobile-security-startup-v-key-secures-4m-series-a-funding-ipv-capital/|title=Mobile Security Startup V-Key Closes $4 million Series A Round|last=Russell|first=Jon|date=2012-09-26|work=The Next Web|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/alibaba-unit-takes-stake-in-singapore-based-mobile-security-software-firm|title=Alibaba unit takes stake in Singapore-based mobile security software firm V-Key|last=migration|date=2014-11-18|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2017-04-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Technology == V-Key provides security [[solution]]s to businesses to support cloud-based payments, [[digital identity]] and authentication for [[mobile banking]] as well as other secured mobile applications<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dealstreetasia.com/stories/v-key-raises-12m-series-b-funding-from-alipay-arm-905/|title=V-Key raises $12m in Series B from Alipay arm - DealStreetAsia|website=www.dealstreetasia.com|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> via its core technology—V-OS.
V-OS is a virtual secure element that is globally patented. It is certified by industry bodies including the Info-communications [[Media Development Authority|Media Development Authority of Singapore]] (IMDA)<ref name=":10" /> and the [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (for [[FIPS 140-2]] validation) in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/STM/cmvp/documents/140-1/140val-all.htm|title=Validated FIPS 140-1 and FIPS 140-2 Cryptographic Modules|website=csrc.nist.gov|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imda.gov.sg/industry-development/programmes-and-grants/startups/accreditation-at-imda|title=Accreditation@IMDA - Infocomm Media Development Authority|website=Base|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> The technology provides a secure data transmission solution that can be used for encrypted communications, a mobile [[Multi-factor authentication#SOFT-TOKEN|soft token]] to replace hardware tokens, as well as mobile [[authentication]] solutions<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/hub/singapores-future-economy/case-study-pioneering-cybersecurity-solutions-for-mobile|title=Case study: Pioneering cybersecurity solutions for mobile|last=Cheok|first=Jacquelyn|work=The Business Times|access-date=2017-04-06|language=en}}</ref>
== Solutions == V-Key’s partners are financial institutions, governments and mobile payment providers in various markets.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/technology/alibaba-backed-spore-firm-has-key-to-new-mobile-security-lock|title=Alibaba-backed S'pore firm has key to new mobile security lock|last=Lee|first=Jamie|work=The Business Times|access-date=2017-04-10|language=en}}</ref> Its technology has been used by: * digibank by [[DBS Bank]] India, Indonesia and Singapore: digibank built V-Key’s security solution into its authentication system for user authentication.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/business/embracing-the-fintech-mentality|title=Embracing the fintech mentality|last=hermes|date=2016-11-14|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smartnation.sg/happenings/speeches/committee-of-supply-cos-debates-2017|title=Committee of Supply (COS) Debates 2017|website=www.smartnation.sg|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.enterpriseinnovation.net/article/dbss-cloud-conundrum-matter-priorities-1368268275|title=DBS’s cloud conundrum: A matter of priorities|work=Enterprise Innovation {{!}} Asia's Premier Business and Technology Publication|access-date=2017-03-31|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[United Overseas Bank|UOB]]: V-Key developed the security [[solution]] for UOB’s Mighty app with V-OS. The app is a secured mobile wallet for all UOB debit and credit card holders. Customers are able to make transactions from the app via NFC by tapping their phones against the merchants’ payment terminal and entering a PIN, or authenticating through an SMS [[One-time password|OTP]] system.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/what-is-the-key-to-building-a-fort-knox-for-the-mobile-payment-space-20160204/|title=What is the key to building a Fort Knox for the mobile payment space?|work=e27|access-date=2017-04-10|language=en-US}}</ref> * ChinaPnR - financial payment provider: V-Key integrates a virtual secure element into "ChinaPnR POS Acquirer" ([[Point of sale|Point-of-Sale]] payment acquisition query platform) to protect mobile applications' runtime environment, program logic and important data.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/chinapnr-and-v-key-strategic-alliance----securing-over-1-million-merchants-253352521.html|title=ChinaPnR and V-Key Strategic Alliance -- Securing over 1 Million Merchants|last=Inc.|first=V-Key|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> * [[Ant Financial Services Group|Ant Financial Services]] - streamlines payment services for e-commerce website [[AliExpress]]: V-Key provides a virtual software solution V-OS for [[Ant Financial Services Group|Ant Financial]] to secure transactions on [[AliExpress]], and provides [[cryptographic]] services and trusted environments to secure payments that are processed by [[Alipay]] on [[AliExpress]], as well as risk management for every transaction.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-based-v-key-to-secure-e-commerce-transactions-on/3287134.html|title=Singapore-based V-Key to secure e-commerce transactions on AliExpress|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bankingtech.com/643252/v-key-teams-with-ant-financial-for-mobile-payments/|title=V-Key teams with Ant Financial for mobile payments » Banking Technology|website=www.bankingtech.com|language=en:gb|access-date=2017-04-10}}</ref> * [[Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore|Assurity Trusted Solutions]]: V-Key provides a mobile soft token application for Assurity’s OneKey Mobile [[Authentication protocol|authentication]] solution. It has multi-layered protection against advanced threats that target [[mobile app]]lications, so that end-users can authenticate themselves via an [[One-time password|OTP]] that is secure.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/technology/assurity-to-offer-extra-layer-of-digital-protection|title=Assurity to offer extra layer of digital protection|last=Choudhury|first=Amit Roy|work=The Business Times|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en}}</ref>

{{Infobox political party | country = Estonia | name = Vaps Movement | native_name = Eesti Vabadussõjalaste Liit | colorcode = #50a7f7 | logo = VapsLogo.png | logo_size = 100px | leader = [[Andres Larka]] and [[Artur Sirk]] | foundation = 1929 | ideology = [[Estonian nationalism]]{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U3L6H8eOIb0C&pg=PA1&dq=vaps+movement+nationalist|title=The Radical Right in Interwar Estonia|publisher=|accessdate=14 March 2015}}
[[Anti-communism]]
[[Populism]] | youth_wing = | headquarters = | europarl = | international = | members = | website = }} '''Vaps Movement''',{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/topic-623213/Vaps|title=Vaps|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=14 March 2015}} ({{lang-et|Eesti Vabadussõjalaste Keskliit}}, later ''Eesti Vabadussõjalaste Liit'', ''vabadussõjalased'', or colloquially ''vapsid'', a single member of this movement was called ''vaps'') the '''Union of Participants in the Estonian War of Independence''' [http://www.historycommission.ee/temp/conclusions.htm Conclusions of Estonian International Commission for Investigation of Crimes Against Humanity] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629035526/http://www.historycommission.ee/temp/conclusions.htm |date=29 June 2008 }} was founded as an [[Estonia]]n association of veterans of the [[Estonian War of Independence]] (1918–1920). Later non-veterans were accepted as its supporter-members. The organisation was founded in 1929, emerged as a mass anti-socialist and anti-parliamentary movement. The leaders of this association were [[Andres Larka]] (formal figurehead and presidential candidate) and [[Artur Sirk]]. ==Ideology== The Vaps Movement was a paramilitary anti-socialist organisation with most of its base being the lower middle class. They had no elaborate ideology or any connection with foreign fascist movements, their goal was simply a more authoritarian and nationalist government in Estonia.[https://books.google.com/books?id=9wHNrF7nFecC&dq A History of Fascism, 1914-1945 By Stanley George Payne] {{ISBN|1-85728-595-6}}T. Parming, ''The Collapse of Liberal Democracy and the Rise of Authoritarianism in Estonia'', London, 1975 The league rejected [[Nazi eugenics|racial ideology]] and openly criticized the Nazi [[persecution of Jews]], it also lacked the willingness to use [[violence]], or the goal of territorial expansion.Marandi, Rein "Must-valge lipu all : Vabadussõjalaste liikumine Eestis 1929-1937. 1. Legaalne periood (1929-1934)" Stockholm : Centre for Baltic Studies at the University of Stockholm, 1991 However, they were known for sharing some aspects of fascist movements of the time, such as the wearing of a black [[beret]] as their uniform headgear, and the use of the Roman salute. Moderate members of the movement such as [[Johan Pitka]] gradually left the organization and new members were allowed to join, who were not veterans. The organization issued its own newspaper, Võitlus ('The Struggle'). ==Constitutional reform== [[File:VapsMovement.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Vaps Movement meeting in [[Pärnu]] [[Estonia]], [[Artur Sirk]] speaking]] The movement strongly supported constitutional reform that would enable a strong President to address Estonia's problems. Estonian patriots had been advocating such a change since the mid 20s, but it was not until October 1933 that the government was forced to allow the Vaps movement to put forward its own [[referendum]] on constitutional reform, after watered down centre-right proposals failed to win any support.{{cite|title=Fascism by Popular Initiative: The Rise and Fall of the Vaps Movement in Estonia|author=Andres Kasekamp|work=Journal of Comparative Fascist Studies (voeventl 4)|pages=157-158}} This was approved by 72.7 percent of the voters. The organization was banned by the government of [[Jaan Tõnisson]] (who opposed the constitutional reform) under a state of emergency imposed before the referendum, but after this the organization was re-established and became even more radically patriotic. The league spearheaded replacement of the [[parliamentary system]] with a [[presidential system|presidential form of government]] and laid the groundwork for an April 1934 presidential election, which it expected to win. After the League won absolute majorities in local elections in the three largest cities at the beginning of 1934, but not in the most rural self-governments nor small towns and boroughs, the recently elected constitutional "State Elder" (head of government and head of state) [[Konstantin Päts]] declared a state of emergency in the whole country (in certain parts, this was already in effect since 1918) on 12 March 1934, disbanding the Vaps movement and arresting its leading figures. Konstantin Päts established a moderate regime that the historian Georg von Rauch has called Authoritarian Democracy. In 1935, a National Association was formed to replace political parties and series of state corporate institutions were introduced. The league was banned and disbanded in December 1935. On 6 May 1936, 150 members of the league went on trial; 143 of them were convicted and sentenced to lengthy terms of imprisonment. They were granted an amnesty and freed in 1938, by which time the league had lost most of its popular support. By 1 January 1938, a new constitution took effect and new parliament was elected in February 1938.S. Payne, ''A history of Fascism, 1914-1945'', Routledge, 1995[http://www.estonica.org/est/lugu.html?menyy_id=639&kateg=8&alam=79&leht=9 Eesti Vabariigi arengulugu aastatel 1918–1940] The new constitution combined a strong President with a partly elected and partly appointed, officially non-partisan Parliament. ==Symbols== [[File:Estonian League of Freedom Fighters - Vaps Movement - Roman salute 1.jpg| thumb | 220px | General [[Andres Larka]] speaking 1933.]] Members of the movement used the [[Roman salute]] and wore black berets as symbols of their allegiance to the organisation. ==Foreign relations== They had maintained good relations with [[Finland|Finnish]] nationalist movements such as the [[Lapua Movement]], [[Patriotic People's Movement (Finland)|Patriotic People's Movement]] and [[Academic Karelia Society]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U3L6H8eOIb0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Radical Right in Interwar Estonia|publisher=|accessdate=14 March 2015}} ==In recent times== Jüri Liim claimed to be restoring the original Vaps Movement.[[Postimees]] 15 April 2009 22:27: [http://www.postimees.ee/?id=107535Reporter.ee: Jüri Liim taastab vapsiliikumise] But he didn't get a registration and his organization is illegal.{{cite web|url=http://www.postimees.ee/?id=139219|title=Vabadussõjalaste Keskliit jätkab tegevust ajaloolise nimega|date=7 July 2009|work=Postimees|accessdate=14 March 2015}} ==See also== *[[Estonian War of Independence]] *[[History of Estonia]] *[[Lapua Movement]] ==References== {{reflist}} *[[Andres Kasekamp]]. 2000. ''The Radical Right in Interwar Estonia''. {{no footnotes|date=May 2012}} '''Widening participation''' ('''WP''') in [[higher education]] is a major component of [[government]] education policy in the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Europe]]. It consists of an attempt to increase not only the numbers of young people entering higher education, but also the proportion from under-represented groups (those from lower income families, [[Disability|people with disabilities]] and some [[Minority group|ethnic minorities]]).
In this way it is hoped to redress the inequalities in participation between [[social class]]es. Widening participation is one of the strategic objectives of the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]] (HEFCE). The issue of widening participation became a [[Politics|political]] issue after the [[Laura Spence Affair]] which hit the headlines in 2000, and after the [[University of Bristol admissions controversy]] in 2003, which concerned alleged biases in favour of the state sector.
HEFCE is pursuing this policy through a number of measures, including the payment of financial incentives to [[university|universities]] and by funding the [[Aimhigher]] programme.
This policy is linked to the previous [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour government's]] target of increasing participation in higher education to 50% by 2010.
